{{milestone:{label:5.56,id:UT23703-093-001-16878}}}Having rejoiced, saying “excellent” to those who have set out perfectly with wisdom, they are connected with true reality when they are 
“motivated.”
{{milestone:{label:5.57,id:UT23703-093-001-16880}}}At the end, they are
“caused… to enter into… and established”
in the result. Construe them like that. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-1-2}}}How should bodhisattva great beings stand in the perfection of wisdom?
{{milestone:{label:5.58,id:UT23703-093-001-16883}}} After that, in reference to the question, ‘How should they stand?’ it teaches{{note:{index1096,id:UT23703-093-001-16884}}} that they should forsake where 
“they should not stand,”
and, standing where they should stand, they
“should stand in the perfection of wisdom.”
{{milestone:{label:5.59,id:UT23703-093-001-16888}}}“Form is empty of form,”
and so on, teaches that the realization of emptiness is where they stand. 
{{milestone:{label:5.60,id:UT23703-093-001-16890}}}“By way of apprehending something”{{note:{index1097,id:UT23703-093-001-16891}}}
is where they should not stand. Therefore, this teaches that because these falsely imagined phenomena, form and so on, do not exist through the intrinsic nature of form and so on, bodhisattvas also do not exist through the intrinsic nature of a bodhisattva, and their emptinesses are not different, they are one. Therefore, form and so on in its true dharmic nature is a thoroughly established phenomenon, and a bodhisattva furthermore is
“not two,”
so to stand in their same true dharmic nature is to stand in the perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.61,id:UT23703-093-001-16895}}}In the section of the text explaining where not to stand, furthermore, the teaching is in three parts. First they should not stand in the dharmas; second they should not stand in the true nature of dharmas; and third they should not stand as persons. 
{{milestone:{label:5.62,id:UT23703-093-001-16896}}} There, the section on the dharmas is again a teaching in two parts: teaching the dharmas and teaching the mark of the dharma.{{note:{index1098,id:UT23703-093-001-16897}}} From,{{note:{index1099,id:UT23703-093-001-16898}}}
“they should not stand in form by way of apprehending something,”
up to
“they should not stand in buddhahood by way of apprehending something,”
is teaching the dharmas. {{page:{number:352,id:UT23703-093-001-22019,folio:F.177.a}}} From 
“Kauśika, they thus should not dwell on the idea of form by way of apprehending something, up to… they thus should not dwell on the idea of buddhahood by way of apprehending something”
is teaching the mark of the true nature of dharmas.
{{milestone:{label:5.63,id:UT23703-093-001-16905}}} The section on the true nature of dharmas is again a teaching in three parts: teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of all-knowing, teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of the knowledge of path aspects, and teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of the knowledge of all aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.64,id:UT23703-093-001-16906}}} Teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of all-knowing is from{{note:{index1100,id:UT23703-093-001-16907}}}
“they should not dwell on the idea that form is permanent… they should not dwell on the idea that form is impermanent,”
up to
“they should not dwell on the idea that the tathāgata, worthy one, perfectly complete buddha is worthy of gifts by way of apprehending something.”
{{milestone:{label:5.65,id:UT23703-093-001-16911}}} Teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of the knowledge of path aspects is from they{{note:{index1101,id:UT23703-093-001-16912}}}
“should not stand on the first level… up to the tenth level,”
up to they
“should not dwell on the idea ‘I will establish infinite, countless beings beyond measure in unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening’ by way of apprehending something.”
{{milestone:{label:5.66,id:UT23703-093-001-16916}}} Teaching the true nature of dharmas on the side of the knowledge of all aspects starts from{{note:{index1102,id:UT23703-093-001-16917}}}
“ ‘I will make the five eyes perfect,’ ”
up to
“they should not dwell on the idea ‘I will make the eighty minor signs perfect on the body.’ ”
{{milestone:{label:5.67,id:UT23703-093-001-16921}}} Again, construe the section teaching persons{{note:{index1103,id:UT23703-093-001-16922}}} in three parts, based on the all-knowledge side and so on. The dharmas where it says,{{note:{index1104,id:UT23703-093-001-16923}}}
“I will, standing on the four legs of miraculous power, become completely absorbed in meditative stabilization,”
and so on, are on the side of the level of the knowledge of all aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.68,id:UT23703-093-001-16926}}} What is the elder Śāriputra thinking where it says,
“Then it occurred to [him] to think, ‘Well then, however could bodhisattva great beings stand in the perfection of wisdom?’ ” {{page:{number:353,id:UT23703-093-001-22020,folio:F.177.b}}}
He was thinking that it has said “they should not stand in all dharmas,” and that it has said it is not possible to stand in emptiness, hence “they should not stand” in it either. How could that be right? 
{{milestone:{label:5.69,id:UT23703-093-001-16929}}} Then the elder Subhūti establishes that they do not stand. The teaching that that is standing in the perfection of wisdom is 
“the tathāgatas have totally nonabiding minds.”{{note:{index1105,id:UT23703-093-001-16931}}}
It is teaching that they stand in nonabiding nirvāṇa. 
{{milestone:{label:5.70,id:UT23703-093-001-16933}}} It has explained the achievement, standing without standing like that, and in the explanation based on those to be trained has said it is inexpressible. So those to be trained come to harbor doubts. Therefore, taking them as its point of departure, it sets the scene for another explanation with,
“O gods, is what is said incomprehensible?”
and so on, asking the gods the question, “Why have you not understood what has been said?” They then reply,
“Incomprehensible, Ārya Subhūti!”
{{milestone:{label:5.71,id:UT23703-093-001-16937}}} Then, because the perfection of wisdom is inexpressible, the elder says
“not even one syllable is said here,”
teaching that since this is the case, the apparent talking and apparent hearing are falsely imagined phenomena, like a 
“magical creation… a dream… an echo… and a magical illusion,”
thus making the gods happy.
{{milestone:{label:5.72,id:UT23703-093-001-16942}}}“A magically created buddha”{{note:{index1106,id:UT23703-093-001-16943}}}
is a magically created body of a tathāgata. 
{{milestone:{label:5.73,id:UT23703-093-001-16945}}}“O gods, form is not deep and is not subtle.”{{note:{index1107,id:UT23703-093-001-16946}}}
Because a falsely imagined form is a not real form, it “is not deep and is not subtle.” Again,
“it is because the intrinsic nature of form is not deep and is not subtle,”
and so on, teaches that because the true dharmic nature of form does not, in its intrinsic nature, move,{{note:{index1108,id:UT23703-093-001-16950}}} it “is not deep and is not subtle.” So here the section of the text is in two parts: the dharma section and the intrinsic nature section. 
{{milestone:{label:5.74,id:UT23703-093-001-16951}}}“Well then, in this Dharma teaching has nothing been designated form?”{{note:{index1109,id:UT23703-093-001-16952}}}
and so on. {{page:{number:354,id:UT23703-093-001-22021,folio:F.178.a}}} The gods ask: if all dharmas are inexpressible, well then, is nothing “designated” or explained as “form”? Then the elder Subhūti says,
“Exactly so, gods, exactly so,”
teaching that they are indeed not designated and not explained. 
{{milestone:{label:5.75,id:UT23703-093-001-16956}}} They
“cannot, without having resorted to this forbearance,”{{note:{index1110,id:UT23703-093-001-16958}}}
which is to say, to this explanation of the inexpressible. 
{{milestone:{label:5.76,id:UT23703-093-001-16960}}}“[Then it occurred to those gods to] think, ‘What would the elder Subhūti accept those listening to the Dharma to be like?’ ”{{note:{index1111,id:UT23703-093-001-16961}}}
This is teaching that if they are ultimately inexpressible there will be no speaker and no hearer, so there will be no listening to the Dharma.
{{milestone:{label:5.77,id:UT23703-093-001-16963}}}“Gods, I would accept those listening to the Dharma to be like illusory beings,”
and so on, teaches that ultimately a speaker and a hearer are nonexistent. 
{{milestone:{label:5.78,id:UT23703-093-001-16965}}}“Venerable monk Subhūti, who will be the recipients of this perfection of wisdom so deep, so hard to behold,”{{note:{index1112,id:UT23703-093-001-16966}}}
and so on—it is “deep” because it is hard to fathom; “hard to behold” because it is not an object of the five collections of consciousnesses; 
{{milestone:{label:5.79,id:UT23703-093-001-16968}}}“hard to understand”
because it is not an object of thinking-mind consciousness; 
{{milestone:{label:5.80,id:UT23703-093-001-16970}}}“peaceful”
because all the afflictions and secondary afflictions have calmed down; 
{{milestone:{label:5.81,id:UT23703-093-001-16972}}}“sublime”
because up to{{note:{index1113,id:UT23703-093-001-16974}}} “all suffering” has calmed down;
{{milestone:{label:5.82,id:UT23703-093-001-16975}}}“subtle”
because all conceptual thought constructions have calmed down; 
{{milestone:{label:5.83,id:UT23703-093-001-16977}}}“private”
because it is self-reflexive analytic knowledge;
{{milestone:{label:5.84,id:UT23703-093-001-16979}}}“not an object of speculative thought”
because it transcends the path of thinking;
{{milestone:{label:5.85,id:UT23703-093-001-16981}}}“brilliant”
because it is the cause for brilliance in the realization of all dharmas as they really are;
{{milestone:{label:5.86,id:UT23703-093-001-16983}}}“absolutely noble”
because it is the supreme place for the realization of extraordinary dharmas; and
{{milestone:{label:5.87,id:UT23703-093-001-16985}}}“an object to be known by the learned and wise”
because it is not an object within the range of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and it is not{{note:{index1114,id:UT23703-093-001-16987}}} an object to be known by the irreversible bodhisattvas. {{page:{number:355,id:UT23703-093-001-22022,folio:F.178.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.88,id:UT23703-093-001-16988}}} They
“will be the recipients”{{note:{index1115,id:UT23703-093-001-16990}}}—
they will be those who take it up. With 
“persons who have seen the truths, or worthy ones with outflows dried up,”
and so on, it first teaches those who are seeking conventionally. There, in the ultimate sense, bodhisattvas are spoken of as those “who have seen the truths”; when they are awakened, they are called “worthy ones.” Having taught them conventionally, those being taught ultimately are from{{note:{index1116,id:UT23703-093-001-16994}}}
“they will not construct the idea that form is empty,”
up to
“so too no being at all will be the recipient of it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.89,id:UT23703-093-001-16998}}}This teaches that just those who have directly realized the nonconceptual perfection of wisdom are those who are seeking. Ultimately there is nothing they will have sought for, so they are not those who are seeking.
{{milestone:{label:5.90,id:UT23703-093-001-16999}}} Then venerable Śāriputra says the assertion that a talker and a hearer are nonexistent contradicts scripture:{{note:{index1117,id:UT23703-093-001-17000}}}
“Venerable Subhūti, is it not the case that in this perfection of wisdom the three vehicles… are taught in detail?”
and so on. The explanation of the three vehicles; and the teaching about
“the ten levels… the assistance,”
and 
“the bodhisattva path”
of the perfections and so on; and about these dharmas: birth in the family of a tathāgata, sporting with 
“the clairvoyances,”
hearing, not forgetting, being without distraction, and the sevenfold
“confident readiness,”
and so on—he is saying ‘We ourselves have heard about these.’
{{milestone:{label:5.91,id:UT23703-093-001-17011}}} After that, the elder Subhūti, to teach that the explanation of these dharmas is by way of not apprehending anything, to teach they do not exist ultimately and hence that even talking is mere illusion, says,{{note:{index1118,id:UT23703-093-001-17012}}}
“Exactly so, Venerable Śāriputra, exactly so,”
and so on. About the reason they are empty, it says{{note:{index1119,id:UT23703-093-001-17015}}}
“because of inner emptiness,”
up to
“because of the emptiness that is the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature,”
and so on. {{page:{number:356,id:UT23703-093-001-22023,folio:F.179.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.92,id:UT23703-093-001-17020}}} It says the gods worship with flowers to teach the gods the sign of the emergence of the light of transcendental knowledge.{{note:{index1120,id:UT23703-093-001-17021}}} This is in order to set the scene for the thought that comes next,
“these flowers have been magically created,”{{note:{index1121,id:UT23703-093-001-17023}}}
and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.93,id:UT23703-093-001-17025}}}“Kauśika… these flowers have not come about”
is saying that they are not marked as thoroughly established, that they have emptiness as their intrinsic nature, and are not flowers as their intrinsic nature.
{{milestone:{label:5.94,id:UT23703-093-001-17027}}}“Kauśika, form also has not come about, and what has not come about is not form.”
It says “form also has not come about” because an ultimate form does not have the production of a compounded form. Thus, it says “what has not come about is not form” because an uncompounded phenomenon that has not come about does not have the mark of a falsely imagined form.
{{milestone:{label:5.95,id:UT23703-093-001-17029}}}“Does not contradict designation and gives instruction in the true nature of dharmas”{{note:{index1122,id:UT23703-093-001-17030}}}
means he gives instruction without contradicting the ultimate or the conventional. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-1-3}}}How should bodhisattva great beings train in the perfection of wisdom?
{{milestone:{label:5.96,id:UT23703-093-001-17033}}}“Kauśika, bodhisattva great beings, having thus understood how all dharmas are mere designations, should train in the perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1123,id:UT23703-093-001-17034}}}
This indicates the last of the three earlier questions,{{note:{index1124,id:UT23703-093-001-17036}}} “How should a bodhisattva great being train in the perfection of wisdom?”
{{milestone:{label:5.97,id:UT23703-093-001-17037}}}“Do not train in form,”{{note:{index1125,id:UT23703-093-001-17038}}}
and so on—this is saying they train without training, just as, to illustrate, they stand without standing.
{{milestone:{label:5.98,id:UT23703-093-001-17040}}} In order to teach that “they do not train in form and so on because they see that form and so on are nonexistent things,” it says
“because they do not see the form in which they train,”
and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.99,id:UT23703-093-001-17043}}}“Śatakratu… inquired… why do bodhisattva great beings not see form,”{{note:{index1126,id:UT23703-093-001-17044}}}
and so on, and to teach that “they do not see form because it is empty,” it says{{note:{index1127,id:UT23703-093-001-17046}}}
“form is empty of form.” {{page:{number:357,id:UT23703-093-001-22024,folio:F.179.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.100,id:UT23703-093-001-17048}}}It says,{{note:{index1128,id:UT23703-093-001-17049}}}
“Kauśika, it is because the emptiness of form does not train in the emptiness of form,”
and so on, as the reason they do not train. It means both a training and something that is trained in are nonexistent, so they do not train. 
{{milestone:{label:5.101,id:UT23703-093-001-17052}}} Then,{{note:{index1129,id:UT23703-093-001-17053}}}
“Kauśika, those who do not train in the emptiness of form… up to those who do not train in the emptiness of the knowledge of all aspects, train in the emptiness of form without making a division into two, up to train in the emptiness of the knowledge of all aspects without making a division into two,”
says that just those who do not train are the ones who train. “Without making a division into two” means they are the same as emptiness, so, when they have trained in the emptiness of a single dharma, they have trained in the emptiness of all. Hence it is explaining that the emptiness of a single dharma is the emptiness of all. 
{{milestone:{label:5.102,id:UT23703-093-001-17056}}} Then it says,{{note:{index1130,id:UT23703-093-001-17057}}}
“Those who train in the emptiness of form without making a division into two, up to train in the knowledge of all aspects without making a division into two… train in countless, infinite buddhadharmas.”
This is teaching that those who thus train in the emptiness of all dharmas train in the six perfections and so on, up to train in all the buddhadharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.103,id:UT23703-093-001-17060}}} Then,
“do not train in order to increase or decrease form,”
teaches that training in the perfections and so on, up to the buddhadharmas, is not to increase or decrease form and so on. It means that training is not to increase the bright side or decrease the dark side. 
{{milestone:{label:5.104,id:UT23703-093-001-17063}}} Then,
“[do] not train in order to get hold of or get rid of form”{{note:{index1131,id:UT23703-093-001-17065}}}
is teaching that where there are thus no dharmas to be increased or decreased, there are no special dharmas to be gotten hold of {{page:{number:358,id:UT23703-093-001-22025,folio:F.180.a}}} and no bad dharmas to be reduced. 
{{milestone:{label:5.105,id:UT23703-093-001-17067}}} It says that, and then with
“Venerable Subhūti, why do bodhisattva great beings not train in order to get hold of or get rid of form?”
the elder Śāriputra asks him why, given that bodhisattvas eliminate bad dharmas and obtain special dharmas, there is nothing for them to get hold of or get rid of. After he asks that, the elder Subhūti says
“form does not get hold of form,”
teaching that there are no grasped and grasper. It gives as the reason for that,
“based on… emptiness.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.106,id:UT23703-093-001-17073}}}“Does not see the production… of form,”{{note:{index1132,id:UT23703-093-001-17074}}}
and so on—something plucked out of thin air has no “production.” Something lasting in its nature does not change so there is no
“stopping.”
{{milestone:{label:5.107,id:UT23703-093-001-17077}}}In suchness there is no production so there is no
“acceptance”
of something not there before. There is no stopping so there is no
“rejection”
of something gotten hold of. There is nothing to get hold of so there is no
“purification”
of something not there before. There is nothing to reject so there is no
“defilement”
to eliminate. Since there is no purification there is no 
“increase,”
and since there is no defilement there is no 
“decrease.”
{{milestone:{label:5.108,id:UT23703-093-001-17089}}}“Venerable monk… where should you look for the perfection of wisdom?”{{note:{index1133,id:UT23703-093-001-17090}}}
He asks about the perfection of wisdom to teach, in regard to the perfection of wisdom itself, the knowledge of path aspects and the knowledge of all aspects.
{{milestone:{label:5.109,id:UT23703-093-001-17092}}}“In Subhūti’s chapter”—
“Subhūti’s chapter” is all of the intermediate exegesis of the perfection of wisdom.{{note:{index1134,id:UT23703-093-001-17094}}} This is saying that the knowledge of all aspects has originated based on the perfection of wisdom, so you should grasp the explanation of it also from there. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-1-4}}}The sustaining power of the tathāgata
{{milestone:{label:5.110,id:UT23703-093-001-17095}}} Given that the exegesis of the deep dharmas is within the range of a tathāgata, the chief of the gods does not accept that it is Subhūti’s explanation, so, setting the scene for the noble Subhūti to have given such an exegesis, {{page:{number:359,id:UT23703-093-001-22026,folio:F.180.b}}} he asks,{{note:{index1135,id:UT23703-093-001-17096}}}
“Is it through your noble might, is it through your sustaining power…?”
{{milestone:{label:5.111,id:UT23703-093-001-17098}}}First the elder Subhūti, in conventional mode, teaches that these are
“the Tathāgata’s sustaining power,”
that is, worthy ones give explanations of doctrine through the Tathāgata’s sustaining power. Then the chief of the gods, not accepting that either, says
“Venerable monk Subhūti, given that all dharmas are without anything that sustains them, why do you say ‘this is the Tathāgata’s sustaining power, it is the Tathāgata’s might’?”
{{milestone:{label:5.112,id:UT23703-093-001-17102}}}Then the elder, having rejoiced in that statement, to teach that in ultimate mode the tathāgata is to be taken as tathatā,{{note:{index1136,id:UT23703-093-001-17103}}} with
“the tathāgata cannot be apprehended in the true nature of dharmas that is without anything that sustains it,”
and so on, teaches that there is no dharma called tathāgata at all. There are no false imagined dharmas in the true nature of dharmas, so “in” that “true dharmic nature” of all dharmas “without anything that sustains it” there is no “tathāgata.” And because there are no dharmas unincluded in the true nature of dharmas,
“nor can the tathāgata be apprehended elsewhere than the true nature of dharmas that is without anything that sustains it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.113,id:UT23703-093-001-17107}}}Because the true nature of dharmas does not abide in falsely imagined phenomena,
“the true nature of dharmas that is without anything that sustains it cannot be apprehended in the tathāgata.”
{{milestone:{label:5.114,id:UT23703-093-001-17109}}}And because there is no true nature of dharmas elsewhere than dharmas, 
“nor can the true nature of dharmas that is without anything that sustains it be apprehended elsewhere than the tathāgata.”
{{milestone:{label:5.115,id:UT23703-093-001-17111}}} Construe the 
“suchness”
section like this,{{note:{index1137,id:UT23703-093-001-17114}}} and construe the
“true dharmic nature”
and
“suchness”
of 
“form,”
and so on, ending with
“the knowledge of all aspects”
section like this as well.
{{milestone:{label:5.116,id:UT23703-093-001-17123}}}“The true dharmic nature of the tathāgata is not conjoined with or disjoined from the true dharmic nature of form. … It is not conjoined with or disjoined from something other than the true dharmic nature of form.”
{{milestone:{label:5.117,id:UT23703-093-001-17124}}}It says so because they are not different, {{page:{number:360,id:UT23703-093-001-22027,folio:F.181.a}}} they are the same. The alternatives when a basis is conjoined with something on a basis or with something else, or disjoined from them, are that they are acceptable if they are different and not acceptable if they are not. Construe 
“thus, Kauśika, not being conjoined with and not being disjoined from all dharmas—this is its might, this is its sustaining power,”
in the suchness section, in the same way. It is the “might” of emptiness, the “sustaining power” of emptiness, in the sense that the explanation has come about taking emptiness as the point of departure. 
{{milestone:{label:5.118,id:UT23703-093-001-17127}}}“They also should not look for it in form”{{note:{index1138,id:UT23703-093-001-17128}}}— 
it says this because form and so on do not exist— 
“and they should not look for it elsewhere than form.”
{{milestone:{label:5.119,id:UT23703-093-001-17131}}}It says this because the perfection of wisdom is something that does not exist, so it is not something else either. Therefore, it is teaching that because something does not exist it is not something else. It says
“all dharmas… are not conjoined, are not disjoined… and have… no mark.”
{{milestone:{label:5.120,id:UT23703-093-001-17133}}}“Form is not the perfection of wisdom”{{note:{index1139,id:UT23703-093-001-17134}}}
teaches that both form and the perfection of wisdom are things that do not exist;
“and there is no perfection of wisdom other than form”
means you cannot say it is different, because it is something that does not exist. And so it says,
“Kauśika, it is because all these dharmas do not exist and cannot be apprehended.”{{note:{index1140,id:UT23703-093-001-17139}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-1-5}}}The perfection of wisdom is great, immeasurable, infinite, and limitless
{{milestone:{label:5.121,id:UT23703-093-001-17140}}} Then Śatakratu, to teach again that this exposition of the doctrine should be taken to be amazing, makes a fourfold statement that{{note:{index1141,id:UT23703-093-001-17141}}}
“The perfection of wisdom… is great… the perfection of wisdom… is immeasurable… the perfection of wisdom… is infinite… [and] the perfection of wisdom… is limitless.”
{{milestone:{label:5.122,id:UT23703-093-001-17143}}}Connect{{note:{index1142,id:UT23703-093-001-17144}}}
“you cannot apprehend a prior limit of form”
with you cannot apprehend at that time “it was there” or “was not there”; {{page:{number:361,id:UT23703-093-001-22028,folio:F.181.b}}}
“you cannot apprehend a later limit”
with at that time “it will be there” or “will not be there”; and
“you cannot apprehend a middle”
with “it is there” or “is not there.” Thus, it is “great” because it is not divided into three time periods.
{{milestone:{label:5.123,id:UT23703-093-001-17151}}}“You cannot apprehend a measure of form”{{note:{index1143,id:UT23703-093-001-17152}}}—
ultimate form is “immeasurable” because you cannot delineate it as “just this much.” It is 
“infinite”
because it cannot be given a size by counting. It is 
“limitless”
because there is no termination of instants. The “prior limit” is production, the “later limit” is cessation, and the “middle” is lasting for an instant. 
{{milestone:{label:5.124,id:UT23703-093-001-17158}}} Having thus at first taught that the perfections are unlimited, it then teaches the unlimited in four parts:{{note:{index1144,id:UT23703-093-001-17159}}} the unlimited knowledge of all aspects, the unlimited body of dharmas, unlimited suchness, and unlimited beings.
{{milestone:{label:5.125,id:UT23703-093-001-17160}}} Among these, what are “unlimited beings”? Their “limits” are the two extremes: the permanent extreme and the annihilation extreme. The nonexistence of those extremes is the state where the extremes are absent, so beings are “unlimited.” Suppose beings existed. In that case they would have limits. But since beings are in their intrinsic nature just nonexistent, unlimited beings with an intrinsic nature do not exist. Suppose a certain being is taught in this explanation of the doctrine. In that case unlimited beings would also be taught. But since it does not teach a being, there are no unlimited beings here either. Therefore, it says,
“Kauśika, where there has been no explanation of anything as a being there will also be no limitlessness of a being.”{{note:{index1145,id:UT23703-093-001-17162}}}{{page:{number:362,id:UT23703-093-001-22029,folio:F.182.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.126,id:UT23703-093-001-17163}}}This means that because it does not teach a being it therefore also does not teach that beings are unlimited. 
{{milestone:{label:5.127,id:UT23703-093-001-17164}}} Then, 
“Kauśika, if a tathāgata, worthy one, perfectly complete buddha remaining for as many eons as there are sand particles in the Gaṅgā River were to say the word being again and again,”
and so on, teaches that a statement from the mouth does not make beings unlimited. They are unlimited in their intrinsic nature because they are nonexistent. Suppose beings were made unlimited as a statement in the mouth, that from what the Tathāgata says beings might be born or cease. It means because that is not the case, beings are not unlimited because it has been said they are. 
{{milestone:{label:5.128,id:UT23703-093-001-17167}}}“Kauśika, from this one of many explanations you should know this perfection of wisdom is unlimited because beings are unlimited.”
This means suppose a being is taught in this explanation, so it exists in reality. Then the two extremes would also exist. But those two are not taught so this perfection is limitless. Because a being is not taught, therefore a being does not exist. Because it does not exist the two extremes do not exist either. Therefore, because it does not teach a being this perfection is unlimited. 
{{milestone:{label:5.129,id:UT23703-093-001-17169}}}“Without apprehending any dharma… still they make known the presentation of the three vehicles”{{note:{index1146,id:UT23703-093-001-17170}}}— 
ultimately and conventionally. 
{{milestone:{label:5.130,id:UT23703-093-001-17172}}}“But without apprehending the tathāgata as other than the perfection of giving”{{note:{index1147,id:UT23703-093-001-17173}}}—
this means the dharma body’s tathāgata is the intrinsic nature of the buddhadharmas. When bodhisattvas train in that, because it is ultimately the intrinsic nature of the buddhadharmas there is also no difference between bodhisattvas and tathāgatas so 
“you… should therefore call them… just tathāgatas.” {{page:{number:363,id:UT23703-093-001-22030,folio:F.182.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.131,id:UT23703-093-001-17176}}}Since bodhisattvas newly practicing the buddhadharmas are the intrinsic nature of the buddhadharmas, because he{{note:{index1148,id:UT23703-093-001-17177}}} would teach, 
“the tathāgata… Dīpaṅkara,”
having seen that he was inseparable from the buddhadharmas, prophesied he would be a tathāgata. Thus it gives the example of Dīpaṅkara. 
{{milestone:{label:5.132,id:UT23703-093-001-17180}}}“Then those gods said to the Lord”{{note:{index1149,id:UT23703-093-001-17181}}}—
because the Lord had obtained the prophesy from Dīpaṅkara—
“It is amazing, Lord, this perfection of wisdom of the bodhisattva great beings, through not appropriating and rejecting form,”
up to
“is favorable to getting hold of{{note:{index1150,id:UT23703-093-001-17186}}} the knowledge of all aspects.”
{{milestone:{label:5.133,id:UT23703-093-001-17187}}}This means it is amazing that it assists a “knowledge of all aspects” not there before, even though the two, “getting hold of and rejecting,” do not exist, because a real superior or inferior thing in the dharmas, form and so on, does not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-2}}}Explanation of Chapters 24 to 33
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-2-1}}}Beneficial qualities
{{milestone:{label:5.134,id:UT23703-093-001-17188}}}Then the Lord, knowing the four retinues of monks, nuns,
and so on, takes as its point of departure the Perfection of Wisdom that is being explained.{{note:{index1151,id:UT23703-093-001-17190}}} It teaches the beneficial qualities that come about in this life and in later lives from this explanation of the Dharma that up to here has constituted the meaning, and that serves as the cause for an increase of much merit. 
{{milestone:{label:5.135,id:UT23703-093-001-17191}}}“Emptiness becomes a good sustainable position”{{note:{index1152,id:UT23703-093-001-17192}}}
teaches just a concordant cause with emptiness as the sustainable position, which is to say, to them{{note:{index1153,id:UT23703-093-001-17194}}} all ordinary things appear as empty, and the self, too, appears as empty. 
{{milestone:{label:5.136,id:UT23703-093-001-17195}}} Here it teaches why 
“emptiness finds no way to infiltrate emptiness.”
{{milestone:{label:5.137,id:UT23703-093-001-17197}}}That
“with which they might infiltrate”
is wicked action. A level or a place of the gods is
“where infiltration might take place.”
{{milestone:{label:5.138,id:UT23703-093-001-17201}}}That
“into which infiltration might take place”
is a bodhisattva. It is because they are all nonexistent. I will not spell it out {{page:{number:364,id:UT23703-093-001-22031,folio:F.183.a}}} here because the scripture is easy to interpret. 
{{milestone:{label:5.139,id:UT23703-093-001-17204}}}“Guarding, protection, and safekeeping”{{note:{index1154,id:UT23703-093-001-17205}}}—
“guarding” is establishing all physical well-being; “protection” is defending against all external dangers; and “safekeeping” is stopping internal sickness and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.140,id:UT23703-093-001-17207}}} Here, furthermore, it teaches four benefits: not being infiltrated, not dying an untimely death, not getting scared and so on, and being protected by the gods. 
{{milestone:{label:5.141,id:UT23703-093-001-17208}}} Teaching by analogy, with
“to illustrate, … if this… were filled with śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas like a thicket of sugarcane,”
and so on, it teaches the greater value.{{note:{index1155,id:UT23703-093-001-17211}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.142,id:UT23703-093-001-17212}}} This teaches the benefits in this life and the many benefits in future lives. There are the ten, 
“a perfect family”
and so on;{{note:{index1156,id:UT23703-093-001-17215}}} they
“magically produce themselves”
and teach the doctrine; they 
“have taken possession of… all the buddhadharmas”; 
calm those who fight and contradict them and so on; the causes of those; perfectly gaining the six perfections; the absence of being disturbed{{note:{index1157,id:UT23703-093-001-17220}}} and so on; the analogy of medicine;{{note:{index1158,id:UT23703-093-001-17221}}} stopping all nonbright dharmas;{{note:{index1159,id:UT23703-093-001-17222}}} protecting and increasing
“wholesome dharmas”;{{note:{index1160,id:UT23703-093-001-17224}}}
“polite speech”
and so on; promotion of the ten wholesome actions; promotion of all the buddhadharmas; and 
“training perfectly”
in each of the six perfections.{{note:{index1161,id:UT23703-093-001-17230}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.143,id:UT23703-093-001-17231}}}“Has been made available in order to tame… and in order to lessen their conceit”{{note:{index1162,id:UT23703-093-001-17232}}}— 
it is “made available” to 
“bodhisattvas… practicing the ordinary”
practices to fully guide them in the pursuit of the career, and it is also “made available” in order to lessen their conceit when
“without skillful means”
they are conceited. When they pursue the career
“without apprehending”
anything and this perfection of wisdom is completely guiding them, it has been made available in order to fully guide them, and been made available in order to lessen their conceit because they do not become conceited. {{page:{number:365,id:UT23703-093-001-22032,folio:F.183.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-2-2}}}Merits
{{milestone:{label:5.144,id:UT23703-093-001-17240}}}Then{{note:{index1163,id:UT23703-093-001-17241}}} it teaches that it protects from weapons in a battle and the reasons for that; that it protects from external harms and the reasons for that; and that it does not present an opportunity for infiltration.{{note:{index1164,id:UT23703-093-001-17242}}} It teaches with the example of the site of awakening; and with{{note:{index1165,id:UT23703-093-001-17243}}}
“having borne respectfully in mind this perfection of wisdom written out in book form”
it teaches the qualities of the perfection of wisdom as a collection of statements and collection of letters. It teaches that places come to serve as caityas because of the perfection of wisdom, and it teaches that the worship there of the perfection of wisdom is superior to worship of a caitya filled with the physical remains of a tathāgata and the reasons for that; that there are more beings who are lacking and many fewer who are good and the reasons for that; that in the ten directions there are more beings in the deficient vehicle and the reasons for that; that it is necessary to engage constantly in listening to this explanation and so on; that worshiping it{{note:{index1166,id:UT23703-093-001-17246}}} is superior to worshiping 
{{milestone:{label:5.145,id:UT23703-093-001-17247}}}“a stūpa be made of the seven precious things”;
that there is more merit from that than from worshiping just a
“Jambudvīpa,”
just a
“millionfold world system,”
or just a
“billionfold world system”
full of stūpas; and that there is more merit from worshiping the perfection of wisdom than all beings in all world systems worshiping that many stūpas. Similarly, it teaches there is more merit from worshiping it than if{{note:{index1167,id:UT23703-093-001-17255}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.146,id:UT23703-093-001-17256}}}“each single being of the beings in as many world systems as there are sand particles in the Gaṅgā River in each of the ten directions”
were to have made a stūpa of the seven precious things and worshiped it, and the reasons for that. It teaches that when the perfection of wisdom is present in the world the cause of the special ordinary and extraordinary good qualities comes about; the entrusting to Śatakratu;{{note:{index1168,id:UT23703-093-001-17258}}} and the benefits conveyed using the analogy of the gods and asuras when they
{{milestone:{label:5.147,id:UT23703-093-001-17259}}}“engage… in battle”
and so on. It gives it the names{{note:{index1169,id:UT23703-093-001-17261}}}
“a great knowledge-mantra… an unsurpassable knowledge-mantra… a knowledge-mantra equal to the unequaled,”
and teaches the reasons for those. It is “a great knowledge-mantra” because it has all ordinary and extraordinary attributes and hence is exceedingly great; it is “an unsurpassable knowledge-mantra” {{page:{number:366,id:UT23703-093-001-22033,folio:F.184.a}}} because there is no other above it; and it is “a knowledge-mantra equal to the unequaled” because there is none equal to it. By giving the illustration of 
{{milestone:{label:5.148,id:UT23703-093-001-17264}}}“the disk of the moon”
it teaches that it serves as the cause of all bright dharmas issuing forth, and it serves as the cause of skillful means. It also teaches{{note:{index1170,id:UT23703-093-001-17266}}}
“these good qualities in this very life… poisoning will not cause the time of their death… or fire, weapons, or water… up to sickness”;
and they are not persecuted by retainers of 
“a royal family.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.149,id:UT23703-093-001-17270}}}It teaches the benefits of these good qualities:{{note:{index1171,id:UT23703-093-001-17271}}} they will not be separated from all the bright dharmas; they will not be
“born in the hells, the animal world,”
or as ghosts; they will not 
“have incomplete faculties… missing limbs… [or] be born in”
a low caste; they will have
“a body adorned with the marks”
and signs; and they will take birth in a buddhafield, 
“pass on… to buddhafields… [and] bring beings to maturity and purify a buddhafield,”
and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.150,id:UT23703-093-001-17280}}} Then it teaches{{note:{index1172,id:UT23703-093-001-17281}}}
“religious mendicants… a hundred of them… went back,”
and the reasons for that, and that
“Māra… turned back”;{{note:{index1173,id:UT23703-093-001-17285}}}
that all the gods offer worship and praise, and make the commitment to
“guard and protect”;{{note:{index1174,id:UT23703-093-001-17288}}}
and that those who take it up will become endowed with the finest wholesome roots. In this context,{{note:{index1175,id:UT23703-093-001-17290}}} what emerges from the perfection of wisdom is the knowledge of all aspects.
{{milestone:{label:5.151,id:UT23703-093-001-17291}}}“Issues forth from… the knowledge of all aspects”
and
“the perfection of wisdom”
teaches that they are different conventionally, and
“the knowledge of all aspects is not one thing and the perfection of wisdom another”
teaches that they are not different ultimately. 
{{milestone:{label:5.152,id:UT23703-093-001-17297}}}“The knowledge of all aspects issues forth from the perfection of wisdom”
is the practice level;
“the perfection of wisdom issues forth from the knowledge of all aspects” {{page:{number:367,id:UT23703-093-001-22034,folio:F.184.b}}}
is the result level. 
{{milestone:{label:5.153,id:UT23703-093-001-17301}}}“The knowledge of all aspects is not one thing and the perfection of wisdom another”
 because both constitute the dharma body.
{{milestone:{label:5.154,id:UT23703-093-001-17303}}} After that Ānanda speaks,{{note:{index1176,id:UT23703-093-001-17304}}} and then, from{{note:{index1177,id:UT23703-093-001-17305}}}
“all the buddhadharmas are preceded by the perfection of wisdom,”
up to
“Ānanda, … have been dedicated to the knowledge of all aspects in a nondual way,”
it says that when giving has been dedicated to the knowledge of all aspects, at that time, having understood analytically that the perfection of giving and the knowledge of all aspects are not different and not two at the result level, when engaging in giving it 
“gets the name ‘perfection of giving.’ ” 
{{milestone:{label:5.155,id:UT23703-093-001-17311}}}“Ānanda, by way of the nonduality of form, in a nonappropriating way, in a nonapprehending way”{{note:{index1178,id:UT23703-093-001-17312}}}— 
the true dharmic nature of form is “by way of the nonduality of form”; falsely imagined form is “by way of nonapprehending”; and conceptualized form is “by way of nonappropriating.” In 
“that which is nondual cannot be apprehended,”
the nondual is the thoroughly established phenomenon. It is not settled down on as something apprehended and falsely imagined. 
{{milestone:{label:5.156,id:UT23703-093-001-17316}}}“That which cannot be apprehended is not appropriated”
means that the absence of settling down by way of apprehending is not appropriated by the conceptualization that pays attention to it. 
{{milestone:{label:5.157,id:UT23703-093-001-17318}}} Then again it teaches{{note:{index1179,id:UT23703-093-001-17319}}} infinite good qualities of the perfection of wisdom: that it serves as the cause of 
“an immeasurable… morality”
and so on, and surpasses the 
“morality… of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas”
and so on. It teaches Śatakratu’s commitment to
{{milestone:{label:5.158,id:UT23703-093-001-17324}}}“guard, protect, and keep safe”;
the gods connecting with confidence giving a readiness to speak;{{note:{index1180,id:UT23703-093-001-17326}}} not being cowed in front of retinues; {{page:{number:368,id:UT23703-093-001-22035,folio:F.185.a}}} not fault-finding; not feeling cowed and so on; being liked by the whole world; the seamless{{note:{index1181,id:UT23703-093-001-17327}}} true nature of dharmas; all the gods taking up the perfection of wisdom; the offering of a gift of Dharma to them; the gods guarding; the sign 
{{milestone:{label:5.159,id:UT23703-093-001-17328}}}“the gods have come”;{{note:{index1182,id:UT23703-093-001-17329}}}
the inferior gods withdrawing; belief in the vast;{{note:{index1183,id:UT23703-093-001-17331}}} worship of the place; feeling a sense of physical pleasure and so on; having no weariness and so on; having good dreams; 
{{milestone:{label:5.160,id:UT23703-093-001-17332}}}bodies being infused with energy;{{note:{index1184,id:UT23703-093-001-17333}}}
not being greedy for the four requirements;{{note:{index1185,id:UT23703-093-001-17335}}} worshiping all the buddhas in world systems all around in the ten directions with the four requirements; there being more merit merely from having respected this perfection of wisdom, even if it has not been taken up and so on, than from having stūpas made of the seven various precious stones and worshiping them; and there being more merit from taking up the perfection of wisdom than were 
“Śatakratu, head of the gods”
to have
“filled this Jambudvīpa right to the top with the physical remains of the tathāgatas,”
and the reasons for that.
{{milestone:{label:5.161,id:UT23703-093-001-17340}}} In this context,{{note:{index1186,id:UT23703-093-001-17341}}}
“Kauśika, the perfection of wisdom cannot be apprehended”
because it “cannot be apprehended” with thinking-mind consciousness. It 
“cannot be pointed out”
because it “cannot be pointed out” with words. It 
“does not obstruct”
because, since it is not an object of sense consciousness, it “does not obstruct” as an object does. It 
“has only one mark—that is, no mark”
because it is separated from all imaginary marks. 
{{milestone:{label:5.162,id:UT23703-093-001-17350}}}“It is not a place to be seized or not seized”
because it is not suitable to be conceptualized as something that can be seized or something that cannot be seized; 
“to be increased or reduced”
because it is not a place for the elimination of things on the dark side or {{page:{number:369,id:UT23703-093-001-22036,folio:F.185.b}}} the increase of things on the bright side; or
“to be taken away from or added to”
because it is not a place for the removal of saṃsāric dharmas or the accomplishment of nirvāṇic dharmas. And why? Because it is without all attachments to such conceptualizations. You should connect it in the same way with them all.{{note:{index1187,id:UT23703-093-001-17356}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.163,id:UT23703-093-001-17357}}}“A dual perfection of wisdom is not available”
means were the perfection of wisdom to be a mode of seizing and not seizing and so on, it would be in a dual state and would be available with a diverse nature, but it is ultimately one, not broken apart, so ultimately such a proliferation of activity is absent from it.
{{milestone:{label:5.164,id:UT23703-093-001-17359}}}“Similarly, a perfection of giving, a perfection of morality,”
and so on, in the ultimate state are essentially one, and hence 
“are not two,”
because they are not broken apart. Therefore, it says,
“Kauśika… is simply to accept suchness as two,”
and so on. All those perfections of wisdom and so on are one in the form of suchness; they are not there as a duality. 
{{milestone:{label:5.165,id:UT23703-093-001-17365}}} It gives the illustration of [the throne]{{note:{index1188,id:UT23703-093-001-17366}}}
“in the Sudharmā assembly of gods”
and teaches that the physical remains of all the tathāgatas have come about from this perfection of wisdom.
{{milestone:{label:5.166,id:UT23703-093-001-17369}}}“The perfection of wisdom has no causal sign” 
because it 
“has no token, is inexpressible,”
and so on, and is therefore separated from all thought constructions. It “has no token” because it is separated from its own defining mark. It “is inexpressible” because it is not within the range of words. It
“cannot be talked about” 
because it is not in the form of language. It 
“is inconceivable”
because it is self-reflexive analytic knowledge.
{{milestone:{label:5.167,id:UT23703-093-001-17377}}} After that it teaches that there will be none of the bad forms of life or lesser vehicle aspirations and so on; that there is more merit from taking up this perfection of wisdom than from 
“this billionfold world system filled right to the top with the physical remains {{page:{number:370,id:UT23703-093-001-22037,folio:F.186.a}}} of tathāgatas,”
and the reasons for that; that
“the tathāgata and the perfection of wisdom are not two”;
that for all the buddhas in the ten directions to teach the twelvefold doctrine{{note:{index1189,id:UT23703-093-001-17382}}} and to read the perfection of wisdom out loud 
“is equivalent”;
and that worshiping all the tathāgatas of the ten directions and worshiping the perfection of wisdom 
“is equivalent.”
{{milestone:{label:5.168,id:UT23703-093-001-17386}}}It teaches that those who have taken up the perfection of wisdom and so on stand on the irreversible level;{{note:{index1190,id:UT23703-093-001-17387}}} the analogy of 
“a person fearful of rich creditors”; 
that they reach the true nature of dharmas—
“complete nirvāṇa”;{{note:{index1191,id:UT23703-093-001-17391}}}
the analogy of 
“the large jewel”;
again,{{note:{index1192,id:UT23703-093-001-17395}}} that there is more merit from taking up this perfection of wisdom than from 
“as many… world systems as there are sand particles in the Gaṅgā River filled right to the top with the physical remains of tathāgatas,”
and the reason for that; and seeing
“the dharma body, the form body, and the knowledge body.”{{note:{index1193,id:UT23703-093-001-17399}}}
The “knowledge body” is the knowledge accumulation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.169,id:UT23703-093-001-17401}}}“What the dharmas actually are when compounded”{{note:{index1194,id:UT23703-093-001-17402}}}—
they have transcendental knowledge with conceptualization as their intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.170,id:UT23703-093-001-17404}}}“What dharmas actually are when they are uncompounded”—
the intrinsic nature that is the inexpressible, the ultimate is what dharmas actually are when they are uncompounded.
{{milestone:{label:5.171,id:UT23703-093-001-17406}}}“Gives detailed instruction for the three vehicles, and instruction by way of no causal sign, by way of no production, by way of no stopping,”{{note:{index1195,id:UT23703-093-001-17407}}}
and so on—it says this intending the nirvāṇa of śrāvakas at the result stage. 
{{milestone:{label:5.172,id:UT23703-093-001-17409}}} Ultimately, the perfection of wisdom 
“is not over there or over here, or has stayed up or sunk down,”
and so on. It explains it like this because, again, at the thoroughly established stage such conceptualizations and causal signs do not exist. 
{{milestone:{label:5.173,id:UT23703-093-001-17412}}}“Replied Śatakratu, “This—that is, the perfection of wisdom—is a great perfection.” 
He says this having thought about {{page:{number:371,id:UT23703-093-001-22038,folio:F.186.b}}} the intrinsic nature of the wisdom that is perfect. The attention that does not apprehend any dharma does not see it, so it is like space because it is a greater object. 
{{milestone:{label:5.174,id:UT23703-093-001-17414}}} As for the analogy of the trees,{{note:{index1196,id:UT23703-093-001-17415}}} the perfection of wisdom is like the trees; those other than it are like the shadows.
 It teaches that giving to others has a greater result than personal worship.
{{milestone:{label:5.175,id:UT23703-093-001-17417}}}“Shatters the vajra-like body and imbues the physical remains of the tathāgata with a special power”{{note:{index1197,id:UT23703-093-001-17418}}}—
this teaches that what has been shared has a greater result. 
{{milestone:{label:5.176,id:UT23703-093-001-17420}}}“Who goes to others and explicates”
is teaching the activity of teaching. 
{{milestone:{label:5.177,id:UT23703-093-001-17422}}}“ ‘What should I rely on and stay by, whom should I respect, revere, honor, and worship?’ ”{{note:{index1198,id:UT23703-093-001-17423}}}
is teaching that if even the Tathāgata worshiped this perfection of wisdom, it goes without saying those others than him should. The section of the passage that says,
“Kauśika, those sons of a good family or daughters of a good family who have entered into the Śrāvaka Vehicle or who have entered into the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle,” 
is teaching that the perfection of wisdom is the principal cause and therefore should be worshiped.
{{milestone:{label:5.178,id:UT23703-093-001-17427}}} Then there is a section{{note:{index1199,id:UT23703-093-001-17428}}} teaching that the result of merit is greater
“from establishing one being in the result of stream enterer, but not so much from establishing the beings in Jambudvīpa in the ten wholesome actions.”
{{milestone:{label:5.179,id:UT23703-093-001-17430}}}Then, having taught the increase in merit in a further section, teaching that there is more merit from having{{note:{index1200,id:UT23703-093-001-17431}}}
“written out this perfection of wisdom in book form and bestowed it”
than from, up to
“establishing all the beings in Jambudvīpa in the state of a worthy one and a pratyekabuddha’s awakening,”
and taught that the reason for that is that 
“in this perfection of wisdom are taught the dharmas without outflows,”
it teaches that it serves as the cause for the appearance of all ordinary special beings and serves as the cause for the appearance of noble beings. Then there is the section{{note:{index1201,id:UT23703-093-001-17438}}} about greater merit from having
“written out this perfection of wisdom in book form and bestowed it”
than from having established all the beings in this four continent world system… thousandfold… millionfold… {{page:{number:372,id:UT23703-093-001-22039,folio:F.187.a}}} a great billionfold world system… or in world systems in the ten directions in the state of a worthy one and a pratyekabuddha’s awakening; the section on the reason for that—that in it are taught dharmas without outflows; the section teaching that it serves as the cause for the appearance of all ordinary special beings and serves as the cause for the appearance of noble beings; and then the teaching on the greater merit, and the teaching that properly paying attention is the main thing. 
{{milestone:{label:5.180,id:UT23703-093-001-17441}}}“There, properly paying attention is this: taking up… this perfection of wisdom with an understanding that operates without duality.”{{note:{index1202,id:UT23703-093-001-17442}}}
This means that engaging “with an understanding” that habitually “operates without duality” is “properly paying attention.”
{{milestone:{label:5.181,id:UT23703-093-001-17444}}} Then there is the section{{note:{index1203,id:UT23703-093-001-17445}}} on the great increase in merit and the teaching that meaning is principal.
{{milestone:{label:5.182,id:UT23703-093-001-17446}}}“There the meaning of the perfection of wisdom is this:”
first,
“not viewing the perfection of wisdom as two and not viewing it as not two.”
{{milestone:{label:5.183,id:UT23703-093-001-17449}}}This means never mind a dualistic nature, there is not even the idea that because it is separated from the conceptualization of all dharmas the nature of the nonconceptual perfection of wisdom is nondual, so the perfection of wisdom is not viewed in a dual way and it is not viewed in a nondual way either. There,{{note:{index1204,id:UT23703-093-001-17450}}}
“not viewing the perfection of wisdom as a causal sign or as not a causal sign,”
and so on, teaches the nonexistence of fourteen conceptualizations of fourteen states: being an objective support, the maturation of karma, being a differentiated object of knowledge, transformation of the basis, apprehension of the meaning of true reality, ascending from one level to another level, different levels, practice, paying attention, {{page:{number:373,id:UT23703-093-001-22040,folio:F.187.b}}} elimination, realization, witnessing the true nature of dharmas, meditating on suchness, and nirvāṇa.
{{milestone:{label:5.184,id:UT23703-093-001-17453}}} There, it says “not as a causal sign and not as not a causal sign” because, when apprehending an objective support, it does not grasp the falsely imagined causal sign of form and so on, and the idea “there is no causal sign” does not occur. Similarly, it says not
{{milestone:{label:5.185,id:UT23703-093-001-17454}}}“as brought in or as sent out,”
because it does not conceive of bringing something into existence at the time of the karmic action, and it does not conceive of being sent out in forms of life at the time of the maturation. Similarly, it says not
{{milestone:{label:5.186,id:UT23703-093-001-17456}}}“as taken away or as added on,”
because, when differentiating dharmas as objects of knowledge, it does not take anything away by over-negating something that exists, and it does not add anything on by over-reifying something that does not exist. Similarly, it says not
{{milestone:{label:5.187,id:UT23703-093-001-17458}}}“as defilement or as purification,”
because, when in the state of an ordinary person, the tathāgata­garbha is naturally pure, so there is no defilement, and even when there is a transformation of the basis there is no purification not already there before, like space. Similarly, it says not
{{milestone:{label:5.188,id:UT23703-093-001-17460}}}“as a production or as a cessation,”
because no production or stopping is seen in the true nature of dharmas because all dharmas are not produced and do not stop. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.189,id:UT23703-093-001-17462}}}“as grasped or as rejected,”
because, even when ascending from a lower level to a higher level, ultimately it does not grasp a special realization dharma at a higher level and does not reject an inferior realization dharma at a lower level. Similarly, it says not
{{milestone:{label:5.190,id:UT23703-093-001-17464}}}“as stationed or as not stationed,”
because it does not conceive of having to be stationed on a higher level and it does not conceive of having to be not stationed on a lower level, {{page:{number:374,id:UT23703-093-001-22041,folio:F.188.a}}} because both being stationed and not being stationed are simply just imaginary. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.191,id:UT23703-093-001-17466}}}“as true or as mistaken,”
because when engaging in the practice of calm abiding and special insight the ideas “this is correct practice” and “this is not correct practice” do not occur. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.192,id:UT23703-093-001-17468}}}“as right or as wrong,”
because, even when zealously paying attention to true reality correctly, the ideas “this attention is produced in the right way,” and “this is produced in the wrong way” do not occur. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.193,id:UT23703-093-001-17470}}}“as tiny or as not tiny,”
because, even though, when eliminating the afflictive obscurations and the knowledge obscurations that are the final basis of suffering, the tiny conceptualization of afflictions is eliminated in stages, such an idea does not occur. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.194,id:UT23703-093-001-17472}}}“as a part or as not a part,”
because, even when realizing the ultimate in the form of suchness in stages through parts—“in the omnipresent sense, the tip sense, the outflow sense, the neither defilement nor purification sense, the nothing is lacking and nothing added sense” and so on{{note:{index1205,id:UT23703-093-001-17474}}}—such an idea does not occur. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.195,id:UT23703-093-001-17475}}}“as a dharma or as not a dharma,”
because, even when making the true nature of dharmas manifest and bringing the true nature of dharmas to completion, if there is any idea of something in the form of a dharma or not a dharma the actual stable suchness is not appearing. Similarly, it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.196,id:UT23703-093-001-17477}}}“as suchness or as not suchness,”
because even when meditating on suchness the ideas “this is suchness” and “this is something else” do not occur. And similarly, {{page:{number:375,id:UT23703-093-001-22042,folio:F.188.b}}} it says not 
{{milestone:{label:5.197,id:UT23703-093-001-17479}}}“as the very limit of reality or as not the very limit of reality,”
because even when in nirvāṇa “this is the very limit of reality and this is its opposite” is not grasped. 
{{milestone:{label:5.198,id:UT23703-093-001-17481}}} In regard to 
“this is the meaning of nondual,”
it is explained that this “meaning” is counted in one way as what is to be explained and counted in another way as apprehending; and in regard to this “nondual,” that apprehending the meaning to be explained—the perfection of wisdom that has been explained—and the nonconceptual perfection of wisdom is apprehending the meaning of the perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.199,id:UT23703-093-001-17484}}} Then the section on 
“in both the meaning and the letter”
teaches that the merit from explaining this is greater than the merit from personally taking it up.
{{milestone:{label:5.200,id:UT23703-093-001-17487}}} Then there is the section about the greater merit from explaining this than from having worshiped
“with all the requirements for happiness, all the buddhas in the ten directions”;
then the section on the merit from explaining this 
“without apprehending anything”
being greater than the merit from practicing the six perfections 
“for infinite, incalculable eons by way of apprehending something”;
and the section on the perfections while apprehending something. 
{{milestone:{label:5.201,id:UT23703-093-001-17494}}} There are four sections{{note:{index1206,id:UT23703-093-001-17495}}} on the
“counterfeit perfection of wisdom.”
{{milestone:{label:5.202,id:UT23703-093-001-17497}}}The first is the section teaching cultivation while apprehending something; the second is the section teaching the perfections with results; the third is the section about gaining 
“immeasurable merit”;
and the fourth is the section teaching rejoicing and dedication.
{{milestone:{label:5.203,id:UT23703-093-001-17500}}} The sections teaching the perfectly pure perfection of wisdom are also two.{{note:{index1207,id:UT23703-093-001-17501}}} The first is the section on the instruction that they should not apprehend anything;{{note:{index1208,id:UT23703-093-001-17502}}} the second is the section on not having a view of any dharma and not resting on grasping a view as absolute. {{page:{number:376,id:UT23703-093-001-22043,folio:F.189.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.204,id:UT23703-093-001-17503}}} Then there are six sections{{note:{index1209,id:UT23703-093-001-17504}}} teaching that there is more merit from explaining it to others than the merit from establishing the beings in Jambudvīpa… in the four continents… in a thousandfold… a millionfold… a billionfold world system… or in world systems in the ten directions in the result of stream enterer; similarly, the six sections teach that there is more merit from explaining it to others than the merit from establishing beings 
“in the result of once-returner,”
up to
“a pratyekabuddha’s awakening,”
based on the beings in Jambudvīpa, the four continents and so on; similarly, the six sections teach that there is more merit from explaining it to others than the merit from causing beings to take up
“unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening”
based on the beings in Jambudvīpa, the four continents and so on; similarly, there are also the six sections about those established 
“in the irreversible state”;
and then also the six sections teaching that there is more merit from explaining 
“to one”
for the purpose of speedy clairvoyance than the merit from explaining to those who have been established in the irreversible state.{{note:{index1210,id:UT23703-093-001-17515}}} There is then the section where Śatakratu teaches and the section where the elder Subhūti rejoices.{{note:{index1211,id:UT23703-093-001-17516}}}
 Those are the subsections of the exposition here. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-2-3}}}Rejoicing and dedication
{{milestone:{label:5.205,id:UT23703-093-001-17518}}} Then also in this context of teaching that it{{note:{index1212,id:UT23703-093-001-17519}}} is greater merit, having taught that merit from rejoicing is highest, to set the scene for the explanation it says, 
“Then the bodhisattva Maitreya said to the… venerable monk Subhūti,”{{note:{index1213,id:UT23703-093-001-17521}}}
and so on. The meaning is this:
“in comparison to the bases of meritorious action arisen from”
rejoicing in the giving, morality, and meditation of all beings, śrāvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, the single merit from rejoicing in and dedicating when it is a bodhisattva who has set out to pay attention to not apprehending anything is 
“the highest.” {{page:{number:377,id:UT23703-093-001-22044,folio:F.189.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.206,id:UT23703-093-001-17526}}}Then Maitreya gives the reason for that, saying,
“Because all the bases of meritorious action arisen from giving,”
and so on, 
“of those… in the Śrāvaka Vehicle and those… in the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle are made”
available just
“for personal disciplining… a bodhisattva’s… is for disciplining all beings.”
{{milestone:{label:5.207,id:UT23703-093-001-17532}}}After he says that, the elder Subhūti takes it in his hands and says:{{note:{index1214,id:UT23703-093-001-17533}}} If all the wholesome roots of all the buddhas in the ten directions, gathering a retinue of beings, bringing them to maturity, freeing them, and so on; the five aggregates;{{note:{index1215,id:UT23703-093-001-17534}}} all the buddhadharmas; the collection{{note:{index1216,id:UT23703-093-001-17535}}} of Dharma teachings; the dharma body that is reached; the wholesome roots of bodhisattvas; and perfect, complete awakening were apprehended and were to come into being, since the wholesome roots from the rejoicing of bodhisattvas has to do with an absence of
“entities and objective supports,”
they would be like the four errors.{{note:{index1217,id:UT23703-093-001-17538}}} If anything like those “objective supports” and “entities” existed, in that case, all dharmas—form, feeling, and so on; the thought of awakening, the six perfections, the aggregates, the constituents, the sense bases, and so on; up to
“the eighteen distinct attributes of a buddha”—
would also exist like them. But if they, like those objective supports and like those entities, were to be nonexistent, in that case they would all be nonexistent. He is asking how, if that is the case, since the objective supports, entities, wholesome roots, rejoicing, and bases of meritorious action would be nonexistent, would dedication be achieved. He is saying that has to be explained. 
{{milestone:{label:5.208,id:UT23703-093-001-17541}}}“And if, just like it is with the entities and how it is with the objective supports too, awakening is like that; if thought is like that,” 
means in that case, just as the entities and objective supports are nonexistent, the thought of awakening and so on would be nonexistent too. {{page:{number:378,id:UT23703-093-001-22045,folio:F.190.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.209,id:UT23703-093-001-17544}}} After he says that, the bodhisattva Maitreya says that there is no objection that they fashion causal signs and make the dedication if they are bodhisattvas who are characterized by having a mature knowledge of emptiness, but the objection is properly directed to those bodhisattvas who are immature, not well trained, and new. Those who have a knowledge of emptiness do not fashion causal signs and make the dedication.
{{milestone:{label:5.210,id:UT23703-093-001-17545}}}“Venerable monk Subhūti, if those bodhisattva great beings again and again practice the six perfections,”{{note:{index1218,id:UT23703-093-001-17546}}}
and so on, teaches that because they are new they do not have faults like the four errors.
{{milestone:{label:5.211,id:UT23703-093-001-17548}}} Then,
“Venerable monk Subhūti, you should not give an exposition of this doctrine… like this in the presence of bodhisattvas who have newly set out in the vehicle,”
and so on, teaches that new bodhisattvas are not receptacles for the explanation of this emptiness. If it is explained to them, because they have a
“smidgeon of faith,”
and so on, it teaches that there is the fault that what they have gotten will be spoiled and what they have not gotten will be spoiled too. 
{{milestone:{label:5.212,id:UT23703-093-001-17553}}}“The explanation… has to be given in the presence of bodhisattvas irreversible…”—
it is not wrong when it is explained to those who are mature.
{{milestone:{label:5.213,id:UT23703-093-001-17555}}} Then,{{note:{index1219,id:UT23703-093-001-17556}}}
“they will be, venerable monk Subhūti, those whose bases of meritorious action arisen from rejoicing will be dedicated in that way to unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening,”
and so on, teaches the ultimate dedication.
{{milestone:{label:5.214,id:UT23703-093-001-17559}}} Fashioning causal signs and making the dedication is illogical in four ways: 
there is no connection between the two—the rejoicing thought and the dedicating thought; there is no connection between apprehending the basis, the wholesome root, and the basis of the meritorious action; there is no connection between the two—{{page:{number:379,id:UT23703-093-001-22046,folio:F.190.b}}} the dedication and to what the dedication is being made; and there is no dedication. 
“The thought that does the rejoicing and dedication”
of the wholesome roots to unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening
“is a thought that is extinguished, stopped, nonexistent, and has run out”
teaches that there is no connection between the two thoughts. 
{{milestone:{label:5.215,id:UT23703-093-001-17565}}}“And those entities and those objective supports, those wholesome roots, and those bases of meritorious action arisen from rejoicing are extinguished, stopped, nonexistent, and have run out,” 
and so on, teaches that there are no “entities” and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.216,id:UT23703-093-001-17567}}}“Does thought dedicate thought? If thought were to dedicate thought, there would be no coming together of two thoughts” 
teaches that there is no connection between the two—the dedication and to what the dedication is being made.
{{milestone:{label:5.217,id:UT23703-093-001-17569}}}“The intrinsic nature of thought cannot be dedicated”
teaches that there is no thought making the dedication. It teaches that thought is a construction because of the nonexistence of its intrinsic nature, and nonexistence cannot make a dedication. 
{{milestone:{label:5.218,id:UT23703-093-001-17571}}}“When bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom thus know the perfection of wisdom is a nonexistent thing,”
and so on, teaches that it is characterized as a nonexistent thing.
{{milestone:{label:5.219,id:UT23703-093-001-17573}}}“The bodhisattva Maitreya then asked the elder Subhūti, “Venerable monk Subhūti, when bodhisattva great beings who have newly set out in the vehicle,”
and so on. He is asking what the rejoicing and dedication of those who have newly set out are. And with
“when bodhisattvas… who have newly set out in the vehicle,”
and so on, Subhūti teaches Maitreya that they have to do it based on training 
“by way of not apprehending anything.”{{note:{index1220,id:UT23703-093-001-17578}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.220,id:UT23703-093-001-17579}}}“And, having heard about those works of Māra from them, no decrease happens and no increase happens,”{{note:{index1221,id:UT23703-093-001-17580}}}{{page:{number:380,id:UT23703-093-001-22047,folio:F.191.a}}}
because of the absence of constructing those in thought. 
{{milestone:{label:5.221,id:UT23703-093-001-17582}}}“Grasp the bodhisattva lineage”—
pay attention to suchness. 
{{milestone:{label:5.222,id:UT23703-093-001-17584}}} Then, having taught one of the many explanations of rejoicing in general, it sets the scene for the ultimate explanation with,{{note:{index1222,id:UT23703-093-001-17585}}}
“Furthermore, Maitreya, bodhisattva great beings who have newly set out in the vehicle should compress together the merit accumulations and the wholesome roots planted by the lord buddhas whose path has come to an end, whose thought constructions and cravings for existence have been cut off,”
and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.223,id:UT23703-093-001-17588}}} Then Maitreya asks{{note:{index1223,id:UT23703-093-001-17589}}} him how do they not go wrong and then the elder Subhūti teaches a section on dedication free of basic immorality, ninefold. 
{{milestone:{label:5.224,id:UT23703-093-001-17590}}} There, the first section is that dedication is not wrong based on the absence of the six perceptions,{{note:{index1224,id:UT23703-093-001-17591}}} but otherwise it will be wrong.
{{milestone:{label:5.225,id:UT23703-093-001-17592}}} The second section is where it says 
“it is a conforming dedication,”
if they contemplate like this: ultimately there is no dedication because thinking about the thought of buddhas and so on, as well as the thought of the dedication, 
“are extinguished”—
even awakening is nonexistent, dharmas are empty of an intrinsic nature, and dedication is nonexistent as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.226,id:UT23703-093-001-17597}}} Then the third is where it says{{note:{index1225,id:UT23703-093-001-17598}}} if, having rejoiced in the merits, whatever they may be, of all 
“past, future, and present”
śrāvakas, bodhisattvas, buddhas, and ordinary beings, 
“they rejoice in them and dedicate them, paying attention to their being”
extinguished,
“paying attention to there being no dedication, and paying attention to the”
emptiness of an intrinsic nature, 
“by that dedication they”
dedicate to unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.
{{milestone:{label:5.227,id:UT23703-093-001-17607}}} Then the fourth is where it says when they 
“are aware that the piling up of”
the merit from dedication is isolated from all dharmas, and all dharmas are isolated from an intrinsic nature, they dedicate with 
“the best, up to the equal to the unequaled dedication.”{{note:{index1226,id:UT23703-093-001-17611}}}{{page:{number:381,id:UT23703-093-001-22048,folio:F.191.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.228,id:UT23703-093-001-17612}}} Then the fifth, as before, is where it says that when they rejoice in the wholesome roots and dedicate them, they dedicate while aware that the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, wholesome roots, dedication, awakening, and the thought doing the dedication are the same in their intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.229,id:UT23703-093-001-17613}}} Then the sixth{{note:{index1227,id:UT23703-093-001-17614}}} is where it says that when they fashion a causal sign for the wholesome roots and dedicate them, and, by paying attention to past buddhas as past, fashion a causal sign for them and pay attention to them as an object, it becomes wrong, but when
“they do not form a knowledge of and do not give validity to those wholesome roots, those accumulations, or those productions of the thought,”
 they dedicate perfectly. 
{{milestone:{label:5.230,id:UT23703-093-001-17617}}} Then the seventh is the section of the dedication that has not been poisoned.{{note:{index1228,id:UT23703-093-001-17618}}} This is where the bodhisattva Maitreya, thinking how is it possible that the two—not fashioning a causal sign and dedication—are not a contradiction, asks the elder Subhūti, who then teaches that it is when the dedication is made by 
“bodhisattvas who are skilled.”
{{milestone:{label:5.231,id:UT23703-093-001-17620}}}Then the bodhisattva Maitreya teaches that bodhisattvas who want to make a perfect dedication 
“should reflect deeply as follows: … those buddhas, those wholesome roots, those accumulations, and those… thoughts”
do not exist; nevertheless, look how having fashioned causal signs I construct them all in my mind. Tathāgatas do not permit such a dedication where, having fashioned such causal signs, they conceptualize them. It is similar to a delicacy that has been poisoned. So such a dedication should not be made, and training should not be done in that. Therefore, having taken the Buddha alone as authority, they make a dedication, thinking, “I shall dedicate those wholesome roots just as the lord buddhas {{page:{number:382,id:UT23703-093-001-22049,folio:F.192.a}}} understand them.”
{{milestone:{label:5.232,id:UT23703-093-001-17623}}} Then the eighth is where it says{{note:{index1229,id:UT23703-093-001-17624}}} dedication while paying attention to all dharmas that do not belong to the three realms and three time periods 
“has not been poisoned.”
Dedication other than that 
“has been poisoned.”
{{milestone:{label:5.233,id:UT23703-093-001-17628}}} And then the ninth is where it says
“I too must dedicate… in this truly dharmic way,”
which is the domain of the transcendental knowledge of the buddhas.
{{milestone:{label:5.234,id:UT23703-093-001-17631}}} Then the Lord, having rejoiced in many ways in those statements,{{note:{index1230,id:UT23703-093-001-17632}}} gives a threefold teaching about greatly increasing merit.
{{milestone:{label:5.235,id:UT23703-093-001-17633}}} The first is
“this dedication… without attachment{{note:{index1231,id:UT23703-093-001-17635}}} creates even more merit than”
the merit 
“if all the beings that are in the billionfold world system were to obtain the ten wholesome actions… the concentrations, … the immeasurables, … the absorptions, and… the clairvoyances.”
{{milestone:{label:5.236,id:UT23703-093-001-17638}}} The second{{note:{index1232,id:UT23703-093-001-17639}}} is that one has even more than the merit created from having served those beings if they
“were to become stream enterers,”
and so on, up to
“worthy ones and pratyekabuddhas,” 
with the four necessities for as long as they live.
{{milestone:{label:5.237,id:UT23703-093-001-17645}}}And the third{{note:{index1233,id:UT23703-093-001-17646}}} is, were all those beings to have become bodhisattvas, just that same one has even more than the masses of merit such as those created by all the beings in the ten directions were they to have served each of them with the four necessities and
“with all the requirements for happiness… for as many eons as there are sand particles in the Gaṅgā River.”
{{milestone:{label:5.238,id:UT23703-093-001-17648}}}“Lord, if that basis of meritorious action had a physical form it would not fit in even as many world systems as there are sand particles in the Gaṅgā River”
means all of it would not fit there.
{{milestone:{label:5.239,id:UT23703-093-001-17650}}} Then there is a section{{note:{index1234,id:UT23703-093-001-17651}}} on earlier merits being inferior {{page:{number:383,id:UT23703-093-001-22050,folio:F.192.b}}} because they have the perception of a causal sign and
“a perception that apprehends something,”
and masses of dedication merits being greater than them because they do not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5.240,id:UT23703-093-001-17654}}} Then there are two sections{{note:{index1235,id:UT23703-093-001-17655}}} where all the chiefs of the gods and gods living in the desire realm, and all the Brahmās in the higher realms, have worshiped and raised their voices in praise, and then the section teaching that the merit of a single bodhisattva who dedicates while not apprehending anything is much greater than the merit from the dedication by way of apprehending something by 
“all the beings in a billionfold world system”
who have become bodhisattvas.
{{milestone:{label:5.241,id:UT23703-093-001-17658}}} The first rejoicing is
“without grasping, without rejecting, without falsely projecting, without acquiring, and without apprehending,”{{note:{index1236,id:UT23703-093-001-17660}}}
which teaches the sameness of those buddhas and those wholesome roots based on the fact that there is no worse or better in suchness. Similarly, because 
“there is no production, cessation, defilement, purification,”
and so on,
“I{{note:{index1237,id:UT23703-093-001-17665}}} also rejoice,”
just like those buddhas, śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and ordinary beings, and the wholesome roots, and the dedicating thought that all abide in suchness.
{{milestone:{label:5.242,id:UT23703-093-001-17667}}} Then the second is also rejoicing{{note:{index1238,id:UT23703-093-001-17668}}} while understanding analytically that all dharmas are comparable to
“liberation,”
which is to say, all dharmas are the same because they are comparable to that; because all dharmas are isolated from an intrinsic nature, so earlier at the stage of ordinary beings they
“are not bound, are not freed”;
{{milestone:{label:5.243,id:UT23703-093-001-17672}}}because all dharmas that are pure in their basic nature 
“are not defiled”
earlier and 
“are not purified”
later;
{{milestone:{label:5.244,id:UT23703-093-001-17677}}}because all dharmas that are primordially calm 
“are not produced”
through the power of earlier causes and conditions; because they have no intrinsic nature, 
“do not appear,”
and later 
“do not stop… have not changed places, {{page:{number:384,id:UT23703-093-001-22051,folio:F.193.a}}} and have not been destroyed”{{note:{index1239,id:UT23703-093-001-17683}}}—
{{milestone:{label:5.245,id:UT23703-093-001-17684}}}thus all dharmas are the same because 
“they are not bound, are not freed, are not defiled, and are not purified, … are not produced, do not appear, and do not stop, have not changed places, and have not been destroyed.”
