{{milestone:{label:5.246,id:UT23703-093-001-17686}}} Then there is the section{{note:{index1240,id:UT23703-093-001-17687}}} teaching that the merit from dedicating the aggregates of morality from 
“practicing the perfections… by way of not apprehending anything”
is greater than merit accumulated from having served all the buddhas in the ten directions with all the requirements for happiness and by practicing the six perfections together with apprehending something.
 These are the sections of the text on rejoicing.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-3}}}Explanation of Chapters 34 to 36 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-3-1}}}Wheel of the Dharma and the perfection of wisdom
{{milestone:{label:5.247,id:UT23703-093-001-17997}}} Then Śāriputra, feeling faith after having heard about the vast merit from rejoicing in, and dedication of, such worship and reciting of the perfection of wisdom, and from giving and so on, begins with seventeen statements{{note:{index1241,id:UT23703-093-001-17998}}} in praise of this perfection of wisdom, to generate faith in others in the retinue. 
{{milestone:{label:5.248,id:UT23703-093-001-17999}}}“Turning the wheel of the Dharma that has twelve aspects three times”—
the Lord turned “the wheel of the Dharma” of the four truths “that has twelve aspects three times.” There he turns it three times: One is: “These are the four truths.” It is the part of the speech stating the intrinsic nature of the four truths. The second turning is the part of the speech stating that just those four truths have to be comprehended, eliminated, realized, and cultivated. The third turning is the part of the speech stating that “I have comprehended, eliminated, realized, and cultivated” just those four truths. Those are the turning three times.
{{milestone:{label:5.249,id:UT23703-093-001-18001}}} For the truth of suffering {{page:{number:385,id:UT23703-093-001-22052,folio:F.193.b}}} there are three aspects: the intrinsic nature of suffering, that it has to be comprehended, and that “I have comprehended.” For the truth of origination there are three aspects: the intrinsic nature of origination, that it has to be eliminated, and that “I have eliminated it.” For the truth of cessation there are three aspects: the intrinsic nature of cessation, that it has to be realized, and that “I have realized it.” And for the truth of the path there are three aspects: the intrinsic nature of the path, that it has to be cultivated, and that “I have cultivated it.” Thus, there are twelve aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.250,id:UT23703-093-001-18002}}}“Lord, how does one stand in the perfection of wisdom?”{{note:{index1242,id:UT23703-093-001-18003}}}
Śatakratu has already asked earlier{{note:{index1243,id:UT23703-093-001-18005}}} about the way to stand in the perfection of wisdom, and it has already been explained, so this is not a question about the way to stand in the perfection of wisdom. Here “how does one stand” means this: how, by respecting and serving it, does one stand?{{note:{index1244,id:UT23703-093-001-18006}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.251,id:UT23703-093-001-18007}}}“The perfection of wisdom is itself the Teacher and the Teacher is himself the perfection of wisdom.”
Because it does the work of the Buddha it is envisioned and taught to be not different. 
{{milestone:{label:5.252,id:UT23703-093-001-18009}}} Śatakratu wonders,
“What occasioned this inquiry by the venerable monk Śāriputra? What was the catalyst?”
because he is not satisfied with just those reasons Śāriputra has given. So then Śāriputra says 
“assisted by the perfection of wisdom”
and so on. It teaches that this perfection of wisdom is principal. It teaches that even though all the perfections other than that are causes of unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening, they are governed by it, so it should be greatly respected. 
{{milestone:{label:5.253,id:UT23703-093-001-18014}}}“Dedicate”
them all{{note:{index1245,id:UT23703-093-001-18016}}}
“to the knowledge of all aspects”
by rejoicing in them. 
{{milestone:{label:5.254,id:UT23703-093-001-18019}}}“When the five perfections are assisted by the perfection of giving, they do not get the name perfection.”{{note:{index1246,id:UT23703-093-001-18020}}}{{page:{number:386,id:UT23703-093-001-22053,folio:F.194.a}}}
It says this because it taught earlier that all six are lodged one in the other and work as a single cause. 
{{milestone:{label:5.255,id:UT23703-093-001-18022}}}“It is not so, Kauśika, it is not so”
is teaching that when you complete one of the six perfections, all six are completed, so they are reciprocally one and just simply one cause, but, unlike the perfection of wisdom that is the nature of them all, they are not therefore the cause in all respects.
{{milestone:{label:5.256,id:UT23703-093-001-18024}}}“Lord, how should [they]… find and produce within themselves the perfection of wisdom?”{{note:{index1247,id:UT23703-093-001-18025}}}
Here too it is not asking how they find and produce the perfection of wisdom within themselves, it is asking what the result of finding and producing the perfection of wisdom within themselves is.
{{milestone:{label:5.257,id:UT23703-093-001-18027}}}“So they do not find and produce within themselves form”
means: so form is a nonexistent thing.
{{milestone:{label:5.258,id:UT23703-093-001-18029}}}“Lord, how do they find and produce within themselves the perfection of wisdom so that they do not find and produce within themselves form?”{{note:{index1248,id:UT23703-093-001-18030}}}
This is the second question Śāriputra asks the Lord. It means: in what form within themselves should the perfection of wisdom be found and produced so that the nonexistence of form and so on is feasible?
{{milestone:{label:5.259,id:UT23703-093-001-18032}}}“Śāriputra, they should find and produce within themselves the perfection of wisdom as the nonenactment, the nonproduction, the noncessation, the nonappearance, the nondestruction, and the nonapprehension of form.”
{{milestone:{label:5.260,id:UT23703-093-001-18033}}}In the context of a thoroughly established phenomenon there is no “enactment” of falsely imagined form. There is neither “production nor cessation” from the perspective of a continuum. In each instant there is neither “appearance nor nondestruction.” And there is no “apprehension” because in all respects there is no production. It
“does not cause any dharma to be gained.”
At that time there are not any dharmas at all. {{page:{number:387,id:UT23703-093-001-22054,folio:F.194.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.261,id:UT23703-093-001-18036}}}“It is counted as the perfection of wisdom.”
The nonconceptual effortless wisdom that has gone to the other side of the nonexistence of all dharmas is the “perfection of wisdom.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.262,id:UT23703-093-001-18038}}}“The perfection of wisdom… does not cause even the knowledge of all aspects to be gained. It does not apprehend it.”{{note:{index1249,id:UT23703-093-001-18039}}}
In the context of the dharma body, just that is the perfection of wisdom, just that is the knowledge of all aspects. It does not apprehend that “the knowledge of all aspects is one thing and the perfection of wisdom another.”{{note:{index1250,id:UT23703-093-001-18041}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.263,id:UT23703-093-001-18042}}}“Kauśika… it is because the perfection of wisdom does not cause it to be gained as a name, as a causal sign, or as something to be enacted.”
The true nature of dharmas is nonconceptual. The perfection of wisdom does not grasp any dharma at all through a name, causal sign, or enactment, so the knowledge of all aspects cannot be apprehended through that name, that causal sign, or that enactment.
{{milestone:{label:5.264,id:UT23703-093-001-18044}}}“Well then, Lord, how does this perfection of wisdom cause it to be gained?”
Insofar as the perfection of wisdom does cause the knowledge of all aspects to be gained conventionally, how does it cause it to be gained?
{{milestone:{label:5.265,id:UT23703-093-001-18046}}}“The perfection of wisdom causes it to be gained without apprehending, without asserting, without being stationed on, without forsaking, without settling down on, without grasping, and without rejecting anything at all, but it does not cause any dharma to be gained.”
{{milestone:{label:5.266,id:UT23703-093-001-18047}}}When apprehended and apprehender have become the same thing in the same form, this wisdom does not “apprehend” that this is a dharma I have to grasp; does not “assert” that I myself am the grasper; does not see, as does the eye and so on, as something “stationed”; does not see any defiling conceptualization that has to be “forsaken”; {{page:{number:388,id:UT23703-093-001-22055,folio:F.195.a}}} does not “settle down” even slightly on “this is true” as being in the nature of truth; and does not “grasp or reject” because it does not see what is grasped and has to be joined with in the form of bright and dark sides. At that time, because it itself is the entity of the knowledge of all aspects, it is also said that “it causes the knowledge of all aspects to be gained.”
{{milestone:{label:5.267,id:UT23703-093-001-18048}}}“It is amazing, Lord, … this perfection of wisdom…”{{note:{index1251,id:UT23703-093-001-18049}}}
Because all dharmas do not exist, they are not produced, do not cease, do not occasion anything, are not apprehended, and are not destroyed in that context, it is explained with the names 
“nonproduction”
and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.268,id:UT23703-093-001-18053}}} It says if they
“have such ideas as ‘the perfection of wisdom causes all dharmas to be gained’ or ‘the perfection of wisdom does not cause all dharmas to be gained,’… the perfection of wisdom is forsaken,”
because both an existent thing and a nonexistent thing are thought constructions. 
{{milestone:{label:5.269,id:UT23703-093-001-18056}}}“I do not have confidence in form.”{{note:{index1252,id:UT23703-093-001-18057}}}
This means the Lord has confidence in and comprehends form that is marked as a nonexistent thing. Construe the others similarly.
{{milestone:{label:5.270,id:UT23703-093-001-18059}}}“Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom gives me confidence because form cannot be apprehended,”{{note:{index1253,id:UT23703-093-001-18060}}}
and so on, means that having comprehended all dharmas, form and so on, as the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature, the Lord has “confidence in”—that is, has a directly realization of—the perfection of wisdom.
{{milestone:{label:5.271,id:UT23703-093-001-18062}}}“Does not make form bigger nor does not make it smaller”{{note:{index1254,id:UT23703-093-001-18063}}}—
it{{note:{index1255,id:UT23703-093-001-18065}}} does not make the form of the true nature of dharmas that is thoroughly established bigger and it does not make falsely imagined form smaller. Construe them all similarly.
{{milestone:{label:5.272,id:UT23703-093-001-18066}}}“Those bodhisattva great beings with such notions, Lord, are not practicing the {{page:{number:389,id:UT23703-093-001-22056,folio:F.195.b}}} the perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1256,id:UT23703-093-001-18067}}}
Were this perfection of wisdom to do anything, in that case it might be right to say ‘this perfection of wisdom does not do anything,’ but because this perfection of wisdom is beyond every false imagination it does not do anything at all. Therefore it is not right to say that “the perfection of wisdom does not make form bigger and does not make form smaller” and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.273,id:UT23703-093-001-18069}}}“Lord… because… they are not in harmony with the perfection of wisdom as cause”{{note:{index1257,id:UT23703-093-001-18070}}}
means that because all dharmas remain in their intrinsic nature, in their own basic nature as it really is, there is nothing there in harmony with the perfection of wisdom as cause. 
{{milestone:{label:5.274,id:UT23703-093-001-18072}}} Now it again teaches that even the perfection of wisdom is like form and so on, in twelve rounds of teaching beginning with
“because beings are not produced.”
You should view the perfection of wisdom as marked by nonproduction because a being is marked by not arising. 
{{milestone:{label:5.275,id:UT23703-093-001-18075}}} There, “because beings are not produced,” up to
“because one who sees is not produced,”{{note:{index1258,id:UT23703-093-001-18077}}}
intends the selflessness of persons. From
“because form is not produced, up to… because a buddha is not produced,”
intends the selflessness of dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.276,id:UT23703-093-001-18081}}}“There is no full awakening”{{note:{index1259,id:UT23703-093-001-18082}}}
of form and so on. There is no realization of them.
{{milestone:{label:5.277,id:UT23703-093-001-18084}}}“Because beings are not endowed with the powers,”
they are weak or do not have the power of wisdom.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-3-2}}}Not bound and not freed
{{milestone:{label:5.278,id:UT23703-093-001-18086}}}“Because dharmas are in an inanimate material state”{{note:{index1260,id:UT23703-093-001-18087}}}
means because all dharmas are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.279,id:UT23703-093-001-18089}}} The elder Śāriputra,{{note:{index1261,id:UT23703-093-001-18090}}} having heard that this perfection is thus in its nature big and vast, feels faith, and for the bodhisattvas poses four questions about the death and birth of bodhisattvas, the amount of time since they have set out, {{page:{number:390,id:UT23703-093-001-22057,folio:F.196.a}}} the number of tathāgatas they have attended on, and the amount of time they have been practitioners of the perfections. That same part of the text sets the scene for an account of what happens to those forsaking the good Dharma, and that same part of the text also sets the scene for it being 
“hard… to believe in this perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1262,id:UT23703-093-001-18092}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.280,id:UT23703-093-001-18093}}}Then, because it has taught it is hard to believe in, Subhūti asks the question, 
“Just how deep, Lord, is this perfection of wisdom in which it is so hard for them to believe?”
{{milestone:{label:5.281,id:UT23703-093-001-18095}}}The Lord explains that it
“is not bound and it is not freed,”
explains about 
“purity,”
explains about
“the unlimited,”
and explains about
“those who are attached and not attached.”
Thus, it sets the scene for a fourfold explanation.
{{milestone:{label:5.282,id:UT23703-093-001-18104}}} Among these, 
“Subhūti… form is not bound and it is not freed.”{{note:{index1263,id:UT23703-093-001-18106}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.283,id:UT23703-093-001-18107}}}During the period of the cycle of existences, that which is the appearance of the thoroughly established true dharmic nature of form “is not bound,” because, for the entire duration it is not bound by all the bonds of affliction, karma, and maturation, and later during the period of the thoroughly established phenomenon it “is not freed” because freedom does not exist, so being “bound and freed” is said of just a falsely imagined state, not of the true dharmic nature of form that, like space, is not tainted by anything at all. Therefore, it says 
“because the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature in form is form.”
This means falsely imagined form, the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature, is the true dharmic nature of form. You should construe all dharmas, up to the knowledge of all aspects, like this as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.284,id:UT23703-093-001-18110}}} Again, to elucidate just that, that it is not bound and is not freed, there is an explanation in tandem with the three time periods:
{{milestone:{label:5.285,id:UT23703-093-001-18111}}}“Subhūti, the prior limit of form is not bound and is not freed.”{{note:{index1264,id:UT23703-093-001-18112}}}
The “prior limit” is the true dharmic nature of form in the cycle of existences during the period when there are stains and impurity. {{page:{number:391,id:UT23703-093-001-22058,folio:F.196.b}}} The 
“present”
describes the present period during which there is purity and impurity. 
“The later limit”
describes the future period when there is purity. 
{{milestone:{label:5.286,id:UT23703-093-001-18118}}}“Because the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature in the prior limit is form”
teaches that what is marked as abiding without change in all three time periods is suchness, indicating that the true nature of dharmas does not have the mark of being freed over time. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-3-3}}}Purity
{{milestone:{label:5.287,id:UT23703-093-001-18120}}} Having thus taught, through the explanation of not being bound and not being freed, that saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are nonexistent things, again, to teach that defilement and purification do not exist it begins the explanation of purity with
“that purity of form is the purity of the result.”{{note:{index1265,id:UT23703-093-001-18122}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.288,id:UT23703-093-001-18123}}}There the dharmas from form, up to, finally, the knowledge of all aspects, have no bonds so there is no defilement. Because there is no defilement they are pure in their intrinsic nature, and because they are pure in their intrinsic nature there are no purification dharmas either. Ultimately purification dharmas do not do anything at all to natural purity. So, even though defilement and purification are impossible, foolish beings construct them. They are not thoroughly established. 
{{milestone:{label:5.289,id:UT23703-093-001-18124}}} Thus, having taught in one way that it is hard to believe,{{note:{index1266,id:UT23703-093-001-18125}}} it again teaches it is hard to believe because of purity. There, “just that purity of form is the purity of the result” means there is nothing other than purity that results from the purification dharmas—the perfections, the dharmas on the side of awakening, and so on. The true dharmic nature of form, the constantly abiding purity in the form of the thoroughly established nature, just that is purity in the form of the result. 
 You should construe all the dharmas like this as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.290,id:UT23703-093-001-18127}}} Having thus {{page:{number:392,id:UT23703-093-001-22059,folio:F.197.a}}} taught the intrinsic nature of purity, then it teaches that the purity of all dharmas is also one, not broken apart:
“That purity of form is the purity of the result. That purity of the result is the purity of the perfection of wisdom. That purity of the perfection of wisdom is the purity of form.”
{{milestone:{label:5.291,id:UT23703-093-001-18129}}}There, the true dharmic nature of the form state is called “the purity of form.” The very limit of reality called the “nirvāṇa” state is called “the purity of the result.” The dharma body state is called “the purity of the perfection of wisdom.” The meaning there is that the suchness that is the purity of form is the purity of the result, that is, is freed; just that freedom is the purity of the perfection of wisdom, that is, is the dharma body; and just that dharma body is the purity of form, that is, is suchness. Hence suchness, freedom, and the dharma body are ultimately not broken apart.
{{milestone:{label:5.292,id:UT23703-093-001-18130}}} You should construe up to the purity of the knowledge of all aspects like this as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.293,id:UT23703-093-001-18131}}} Summing up in conclusion it teaches that the purity of all dharmas is one. Therefore, those purities from the purity of form, the purity of the result, and the purity of the perfection of wisdom, up to the knowledge of all aspects, are
“not two, not divided, not separate, and not broken apart.”{{note:{index1267,id:UT23703-093-001-18133}}}
They are “not two” because they are the same; they are “not divided” because you cannot divide them into different things; they are “not separate” because a particular one does not exist; they are “not broken apart” because nothing obstructs them, or, because they are constant. 
{{milestone:{label:5.294,id:UT23703-093-001-18135}}} Thus, it has taught the purity of the result {{page:{number:393,id:UT23703-093-001-22060,folio:F.197.b}}} shared in common with śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas. Now, to teach the uncommon purity of bodhisattvas it leaves out the result, and it teaches having taken up only the purity of the perfection of wisdom.{{note:{index1268,id:UT23703-093-001-18136}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.295,id:UT23703-093-001-18137}}} Thus, these two passages{{note:{index1269,id:UT23703-093-001-18138}}} teach that the purity of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and the purity of the tathāgata, are “one.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.296,id:UT23703-093-001-18139}}} Now it teaches the purity in a sequence of three connected sections: the purity that is the nonexistence of a self of persons,{{note:{index1270,id:UT23703-093-001-18140}}} the purity that is the nonexistence of secondary afflictions,{{note:{index1271,id:UT23703-093-001-18141}}} and the purity that is the nonexistence of a self in dharmas.
{{milestone:{label:5.297,id:UT23703-093-001-18142}}}“Because of the purity of self, there is the purity of form.”
The knowledge that a self is a nonexistent thing is the purity of self. There it should be taught in the order of the sections of the text. It teaches that
“because of the purity of self, there is the purity of form.”
Because of the purity of form there is the purity of self. Thus, this purity of self and purity of form are not two, are not divided, are not separate, and are not broken apart. 
{{milestone:{label:5.298,id:UT23703-093-001-18146}}}Similarly, 
“because of the purity of self, there is the purity of feeling… perception… volitional factors… and consciousness. Because of the purity of consciousness, there is the purity of self,”
and so on, and that
“the purity of self and purity of”
all dharmas, up to, finally, 
“the purity of the knowledge of all aspects”
is not two.
{{milestone:{label:5.299,id:UT23703-093-001-18153}}} Then, in the section on the purity that is the nonexistence of secondary afflictions, 
“because of the purity of greed there is the purity of form; because of the purity of form there is the purity of greed. Thus, this purity of greed and the purity of form is not two,”
and so on, again explains that the purity of dharmas, up to, finally, the knowledge of all aspects, {{page:{number:394,id:UT23703-093-001-22061,folio:F.198.a}}} and the purity of greed 
“is not two.”
{{milestone:{label:5.300,id:UT23703-093-001-18157}}}Similarly connect this with 
“hatred, and confusion.”
{{milestone:{label:5.301,id:UT23703-093-001-18159}}} Then, in the section on the purity that is the nonexistence of a self of dharmas, having taken up the purity of dharmas, the dependent originations, and so on, up to, finally, the knowledge of all aspects, there is the section explaining that the purity of two dharmas is not two:
{{milestone:{label:5.302,id:UT23703-093-001-18160}}}“Because of the purity of ignorance there is the purity of volitional factors; because of the purity of volitional factors there is the purity of ignorance. Thus, this purity of ignorance and the purity of volitional factors is not two,”{{note:{index1272,id:UT23703-093-001-18161}}}
and so on. So too with the perfections as well, it says,
{{milestone:{label:5.303,id:UT23703-093-001-18163}}}“Because of the purity of the perfection of giving there is the purity of the perfection of morality; because of the purity of the perfection of morality there is the purity of the perfection of giving. Thus, this purity of the perfection of giving and the purity of the perfection of morality is not two,”{{note:{index1273,id:UT23703-093-001-18164}}}
and so on. All have to be construed in the same way as well. Thus, you should construe
“because of the purity of the knowledge of the path aspects there is the purity of the knowledge of all aspects, because of the purity of the knowledge of all aspects there is the purity of the knowledge of all path aspects. Thus, this purity of the knowledge of the path aspects and the purity of the knowledge of all aspects is not two,”{{note:{index1274,id:UT23703-093-001-18167}}}
and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.304,id:UT23703-093-001-18169}}} Then, also in the section gathering the purity of all dharmas together, first, having taken up among the six perfections the purity of the perfection of wisdom, and the purity of the aggregates and so on, up to, finally, the six collections of feelings,{{note:{index1275,id:UT23703-093-001-18170}}} and the purity of the knowledge of all aspects, there is the section teaching that it is not two: 
{{milestone:{label:5.305,id:UT23703-093-001-18171}}}“Furthermore, Subhūti, that purity {{page:{number:395,id:UT23703-093-001-22062,folio:F.198.b}}} of the perfection of wisdom is the purity of form. That purity of form is the purity of the knowledge of all aspects. Thus, this purity of the perfection of wisdom, purity of form, and purity of the knowledge of all aspects is not two, not divided, not separate, and not broken apart.”{{note:{index1276,id:UT23703-093-001-18172}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.306,id:UT23703-093-001-18173}}}Similarly connect this with
“feeling, perception, volitional factors, and consciousness,”
up to
“that purity of the perfection of wisdom is the purity of the feeling that arises from the condition of contact with the thinking mind. The purity of the feeling that arises from the condition of contact with the thinking mind is the purity of the knowledge of all aspects. Thus, this purity of the perfection of wisdom, purity of the feeling that arises from the condition of contact with the thinking mind, and purity of the knowledge of all aspects is not two,”{{note:{index1277,id:UT23703-093-001-18177}}}
and so on. Then also,{{note:{index1278,id:UT23703-093-001-18179}}} having taken up the purity of the dharmas—from the perfection of concentration up to the aggregates and so on, and finally the feelings—and 
“the purity of the knowledge of all aspects,”
it teaches that it is not two; and similarly it teaches that the purity of the dharmas—all the perfections, all the emptinesses, up to, finally, the feelings—and 
“the purity of the knowledge of all aspects is not two”;
and, similarly, it explains that (1) the purity of the dharmas, the applications of mindfulness, and so on, up to, finally, all-knowledge; and (2) the purity of the dharmas form and so on, up to, finally, the six collections of feelings; and (3) the purity of the knowledge of all aspects is one.
{{milestone:{label:5.307,id:UT23703-093-001-18184}}}Then it teaches the section on 
“the purity of the compounded”
and 
“the uncompounded,” {{page:{number:396,id:UT23703-093-001-22063,folio:F.199.a}}}
and the section on the purity of the three time periods.{{note:{index1279,id:UT23703-093-001-18189}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.308,id:UT23703-093-001-18190}}} The elder Śāriputra, having listened to the exposition of purity up to here, because a retinue is gathered together, musters the confidence to speak and says,{{note:{index1280,id:UT23703-093-001-18191}}}
“Lord, this purity is deep,”
and so on. With this begins a sequence of thirteen statements about purity.
{{milestone:{label:5.309,id:UT23703-093-001-18194}}}“Śāriputra, it is deep because it is extremely pure”
says that the true nature of dharmas that is not broken apart from those saṃsāric dharmas, composed of the stains of the many afflictions, secondary afflictions, and conceptualizations, does not become stained by those stains. It is extremely pure at all times, so it is hard for fools to feel confidence in it. Hence it is called “deep because it is extremely pure.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.310,id:UT23703-093-001-18196}}}“Śāriputra, purity is light because it is extremely pure,”
To illustrate, the sun and moon and so on are extremely pure, that is, they shine brightly where there are no clouds, fog, haze and so on. Similarly, the true dharmic nature of form and so on is called “light because it is extremely pure,” so it says “purity is light because form is extremely pure.”
{{milestone:{label:5.311,id:UT23703-093-001-18199}}}“Lord, purity does not link up.”
Because the stains of the proliferation of afflictions and conceptualizations have stopped there is no further linking up, so, because it is stainless and pure, it is said that it “does not link up.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.312,id:UT23703-093-001-18201}}}“Śāriputra, form does not link up because it does not change places, so it is pure”{{note:{index1281,id:UT23703-093-001-18202}}}
means because falsely imagined form and so on that have been abandoned do not change places again, they have stopped. 
{{milestone:{label:5.313,id:UT23703-093-001-18204}}}“Lord, purity is without defilement”
is saying that even though there have been clouds, fog, haze and so on, like space, in its basic nature it is thoroughly clean. {{page:{number:397,id:UT23703-093-001-22064,folio:F.199.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.314,id:UT23703-093-001-18206}}}“Lord, there is no obtaining and no clear realization of purity.”
Were the two dharmas—something obtained and a cause of obtaining—to exist, there would be an “obtaining”; were the two dharmas—something clearly realized and a cause of clear realization—to exist, there would be a “clear realization.” But because the mere nonexistence of false imagining and conceptualizing is posited as the “purity” that is the thoroughly established true nature of dharmas, “obtaining” and “clear realization” do not exist in that purity at all. 
{{milestone:{label:5.315,id:UT23703-093-001-18208}}}“Lord, purity does not come into being.”
“Purity” is posited as the dharmas, falsely imagined and conceptualized form and so on, not coming into being, so it is “marked by not coming into being.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.316,id:UT23703-093-001-18210}}}“Lord, purity does not arise in the desire realm… the form realm… [or] the formless realm.”
The desire, form, and formless realms are falsely imagined. When not arising and appearing in them it is called “purity,” so it says
“because you cannot apprehend the desire realm’s intrinsic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.317,id:UT23703-093-001-18213}}}“Lord, purity does not know”
means the self is not the intrinsic nature self-awareness. 
{{milestone:{label:5.318,id:UT23703-093-001-18215}}}“Because dharmas are inanimate material”—
it is saying “dharmas are inanimate material” because they are free from conceptual consciousness. 
{{milestone:{label:5.319,id:UT23703-093-001-18217}}}“Lord, purity does not know form.”
This means it also does not see all dharmas, form and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.320,id:UT23703-093-001-18219}}}“Because it is empty of its own mark” 
means things like form and so on are without defining marks. This “does not know” teaches that purity is the mark of the absence of conceptualization. This “purity {{page:{number:398,id:UT23703-093-001-22065,folio:F.200.a}}} does not know form” teaches that dharmas are the mark of nonexistence. The two teach the mark of the nonexistence of apprehended object and apprehending subject. 
{{milestone:{label:5.321,id:UT23703-093-001-18221}}}“Lord, the perfection of wisdom does not help nor does it hinder the knowledge of all aspects,”
because both, marked by suchness, are 
“extremely pure.”
{{milestone:{label:5.322,id:UT23703-093-001-18224}}}Suchness does not help and does not hinder suchness, just like space does not help and does not hinder space. Therefore, it says
“because of the establishment of the dharma-constituent.”{{note:{index1282,id:UT23703-093-001-18226}}}
This is teaching that nobody helps or hinders the dharma body, given that at all times it is marked by staying in the same state.
{{milestone:{label:5.323,id:UT23703-093-001-18228}}}“Lord, the purity that is the perfection of wisdom does not assist any dharma,”
because the extremely pure perfection of wisdom is the mark of not taking hold of anything. Were it to take hold of any dharma it would not be pure.{{note:{index1283,id:UT23703-093-001-18230}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.324,id:UT23703-093-001-18231}}}Then the statements by the elder Subhūti,{{note:{index1284,id:UT23703-093-001-18232}}}
“Lord, form is pure because self is pure”
and so on, mean that because the self is something that is nonexistent, form and so on are things that do not exist either, because here you have to take “purity” as something that does not exist. Hence, it says 
“because it is extremely pure, Subhūti.”
{{milestone:{label:5.325,id:UT23703-093-001-18236}}}Earlier it was teaching the pure perfection of wisdom, now it is teaching the purity of selflessness. 
{{milestone:{label:5.326,id:UT23703-093-001-18237}}}“Because knowledge is not found and is not discarded, Subhūti.”{{note:{index1285,id:UT23703-093-001-18238}}}
They do not obtain or find a transcendent knowledge that was not there before, and a transcendent knowledge that is found is also not lost, so, because there are neither, there is not even awakening. Even “awakening” is falsely imagined. 
{{milestone:{label:5.327,id:UT23703-093-001-18240}}}“Nonduality {{page:{number:399,id:UT23703-093-001-22066,folio:F.200.b}}} and purity”{{note:{index1286,id:UT23703-093-001-18241}}}—
because the two—defilement and purification—do not exist, it is pure in its intrinsic nature even before, so like space it has no defilement. And even at the period of the final outcome, it is like space that has no purity that was not there before. 
{{milestone:{label:5.328,id:UT23703-093-001-18244}}}Having thus completed the explanation of purity, it begins the explanation of the unlimited to inculcate belief in the deep, with
“because form is unlimited.”
It is “unlimited” because it is not permanent and not annihilated, and is not at the prior limit, later limit, or in the middle. Therefore, it says 
“because of the emptiness of what transcends limits and the emptiness of no beginning and no end, Subhūti.”
{{milestone:{label:5.329,id:UT23703-093-001-18248}}}Why does the elder Subhūti ask,
“Lord, why is such a realization as that the perfection of wisdom of bodhisattva great beings?” 
{{milestone:{label:5.330,id:UT23703-093-001-18250}}}He is asking why, if the perfection of wisdom is so deep a topic as that, is it just an object of bodhisattvas, not of buddhas. It says,
“Because it is the knowledge of path aspects, Subhūti.”
{{milestone:{label:5.331,id:UT23703-093-001-18252}}}Thus, this perfection of wisdom is not the final one, is not when the work is done. It is an aspect of the path of the knowledge of all aspects, hence it is “just of bodhisattvas.”
{{milestone:{label:5.332,id:UT23703-093-001-18253}}}“Lord, you cannot apprehend the perfection of wisdom of bodhisattva great beings on this side, on the farther side, or on neither.”{{note:{index1287,id:UT23703-093-001-18254}}}
What does this intend? You can suppose “perfection” (pāramitā) is on the way to the other side (para), has arrived at the other side, or is the essential nature of the other side. It says this because, even when taken to be the perfection of wisdom of bodhisattvas, {{page:{number:400,id:UT23703-093-001-22067,folio:F.201.a}}} it is not positioned on this side, it is not positioned on the farther side, and cannot be apprehended on some other that is not included in those sides. “This side” incorporates the compounded; “the farther side” incorporates the uncompounded.
{{milestone:{label:5.333,id:UT23703-093-001-18256}}} After saying that,
“Because it is extremely pure,” said the Lord.
Were any side to be apprehended, then, in that case, it would not be purity. This means it is extremely pure because there are none, and, because it is extremely pure, it is not positioned on either side or anywhere else either. 
{{milestone:{label:5.334,id:UT23703-093-001-18259}}}“Because of the sameness of the three time periods, Subhūti”—
this means that with the comprehension of the sameness of the three time periods, because of the emptiness of no beginning and no end, there is no notion of this side and no notion of a farther side, and hence “it does not stand on this side and it also does not stand on the farther side.”
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-3-4}}}Attachment and nonattachment
{{milestone:{label:5.335,id:UT23703-093-001-18261}}}In order to build trust that the perfection of wisdom is deep, it then again sets the scene for the explanation of attachment and nonattachment from the perspective of practices that apprehend and do not apprehend, with
“they are attached to a name and attached to a causal sign,”{{note:{index1288,id:UT23703-093-001-18263}}}
and so on. Seizing on a dharma, form and so on, as a word is falsely imagining. Seizing on a causal sign as a conventional term is conceptualizing. Both are obscurations, so they are “attachment.”
{{milestone:{label:5.336,id:UT23703-093-001-18265}}}“Subhūti, even though all dharmas are without causal signs and without names”
is teaching that they are within the range of the perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.337,id:UT23703-093-001-18267}}}“Lord, such an excellent exposition and excellent definitive teaching of this perfection of wisdom… to bodhisattva great beings is amazing”—
this is teaching of the knowledge of path aspects.
{{milestone:{label:5.338,id:UT23703-093-001-18269}}}“When… they perceive that form is ‘empty,’ they are attached”{{note:{index1289,id:UT23703-093-001-18270}}}{{page:{number:401,id:UT23703-093-001-22068,folio:F.201.b}}}
 is thinking like that by way of apprehending something. 
{{milestone:{label:5.339,id:UT23703-093-001-18272}}}“Not perceive form as ‘form’ ”{{note:{index1290,id:UT23703-093-001-18273}}}—
this is the bodhisattva’s knowledge of path aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.340,id:UT23703-093-001-18275}}}“Not perceive… dharmas as… ‘dharmas’ ”—
they do not appear.
{{milestone:{label:5.341,id:UT23703-093-001-18277}}}“Kauśika, it is because the basic nature of form cannot be dedicated”{{note:{index1291,id:UT23703-093-001-18278}}}
means dharmas should not be dedicated to awakening by way of apprehending something, because they stay in the same state and do not undergo transformation.
{{milestone:{label:5.342,id:UT23703-093-001-18280}}}“Subhūti, I will teach you other sorts of attachment even more subtle than those”{{note:{index1292,id:UT23703-093-001-18281}}}
that obscure the knowledge of path aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.343,id:UT23703-093-001-18283}}}“Lord, the perfection of wisdom is deep.”{{note:{index1293,id:UT23703-093-001-18284}}}
Earlier,{{note:{index1294,id:UT23703-093-001-18286}}} to build trust, the elder Śāriputra set the scene for the explanation of the perfection of wisdom being deep, and for it being hard to believe in. Now, to demonstrate that he himself has comprehended that it is deep, the elder Subhūti says, “Lord, … [it] is deep.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.344,id:UT23703-093-001-18287}}}“Subhūti, it is because all dharmas are isolated in their basic nature.”
Thus all phenomena are always deserted by all attachments, are deserted by a basic nature, are isolated in their basic nature. But falsely imagined attachment is still apprehending, and even though falsely imagined attachment is apprehending, still all dharmas are untainted, that is, are isolated in their intrinsic nature so they are deep. 
{{milestone:{label:5.345,id:UT23703-093-001-18289}}}“The perfection of wisdom… is unmade and does not cause anything to come into being.”
In it there is nothing to be established and nothing is caused to come into being because it is the intrinsic nature of the dharma body. 
{{milestone:{label:5.346,id:UT23703-093-001-18291}}}“The basic nature of a dharma is not two; it is simply one.”
As the intrinsic nature that is suchness, all dharmas are a single entity, but still they appear with different identities. This is difficult to clearly realize. Because suchness is the intrinsic nature of all dharmas {{page:{number:402,id:UT23703-093-001-22069,folio:F.202.a}}} it is called their “basic nature.” That suchness, moreover, is not the cause of any other true nature of dharmas, so it
“is not a basic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.347,id:UT23703-093-001-18294}}}This suchness is uncompounded; it is not made by anybody, so it
“is unmade.”
{{milestone:{label:5.348,id:UT23703-093-001-18296}}}Just that 
“has not caused anything to come into being”
because no enactment of merit or demerit whatsoever has occasioned it.
{{milestone:{label:5.349,id:UT23703-093-001-18299}}}“Nobody has seen, heard, thought about, been conscious of, or fully awakened to the perfection of wisdom,”
because the perfection of wisdom is not the object of seeing consciousness and so on, nor of thought constructions such as those, because an apprehender and an apprehended object are the same in their intrinsic nature.
{{milestone:{label:5.350,id:UT23703-093-001-18301}}}“The perfection of wisdom is inconceivable”
means you cannot conceive of it through another dharma, like fire indicated by smoke. Therefore, it says
“it is not known through form”
and so on. It
“is the nonapprehender of all dharmas.”
{{milestone:{label:5.351,id:UT23703-093-001-18306}}}It makes all dharmas known as the mark of what cannot be apprehended. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-4}}}Explanation of Chapters 37 and 38
{{milestone:{label:5.352,id:UT23703-093-001-18307}}}“How do [they]… practice the perfection of wisdom?”
that is, the knowledge of path aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.353,id:UT23703-093-001-18309}}} The section of the text to teach that if those conscious of a basic nature practice all dharmas they do not practice the perfection of wisdom is{{note:{index1295,id:UT23703-093-001-18310}}}
“if they do not practice form,”
and so on. The second section is to teach that when those conscious of special insight practice the marks of dharmas, they do not practice the perfection of wisdom.
{{milestone:{label:5.354,id:UT23703-093-001-18313}}} It says,
“ ‘form is completed’ or ‘not completed,’ ”
intending when meditation is completed.
{{milestone:{label:5.355,id:UT23703-093-001-18316}}}“ ‘Form is not attached’ ”{{note:{index1296,id:UT23703-093-001-18317}}}
is the unobstructed true dharmic nature of form. When they practice like that
“they do not perceive ‘form is not attached.’ ”
This means that if, when practicing, they have set out like that, then when they awaken to the knowledge of all aspects they will have a realization like that. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-4-1}}}Benefits of purity
{{milestone:{label:5.356,id:UT23703-093-001-18321}}} Subhūti’s {{page:{number:403,id:UT23703-093-001-22070,folio:F.202.b}}} statement that he is amazed, the statement of some monk or other, the statement by Śatakratu, and the statement that guarding, protecting, and keeping safe are not possible are all alike.{{note:{index1297,id:UT23703-093-001-18322}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.357,id:UT23703-093-001-18323}}}“They do not falsely project form”{{note:{index1298,id:UT23703-093-001-18324}}}
as a functioning thing that is real and a defining mark and so on; 
“do not falsely project form as ‘mine’ ”
as a real thing, like a master’s servant;
“do not falsely project anything onto form”
as a real thing on a foundation or basis; and
“do not falsely project a causal sign of form”
as a basis of a designation that is a conventional term.
{{milestone:{label:5.358,id:UT23703-093-001-18332}}} The description of 
“the thousand buddhas”{{note:{index1299,id:UT23703-093-001-18334}}}
is because those thousand buddhas cause faith to arise in that perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.359,id:UT23703-093-001-18336}}}The question about 
“Maitreya”
teaching the Dharma{{note:{index1300,id:UT23703-093-001-18339}}} is to make it known that during the three periods of time the explanations are of just this perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.360,id:UT23703-093-001-18340}}}Then,{{note:{index1301,id:UT23703-093-001-18341}}}
“Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom is pure because form is pure.”
The dharmas, form and so on, that have been apprehended are stainless, so the knowledge of path aspects is also pure. 
{{milestone:{label:5.361,id:UT23703-093-001-18344}}}“Subhūti, form… is unproduced and unceasing, without defilement and without purification.”
When form abides in its intrinsic nature—the true nature of dharmas—and does not appear as produced, ceasing, defiled, or purified, that
“form is pure,”
not otherwise.
{{milestone:{label:5.362,id:UT23703-093-001-18348}}}“Because space is pure”—
this is teaching that just as space does not become impure even if there are clouds and haze because it is pure in its nature, so too with the perfection of wisdom. The six{{note:{index1302,id:UT23703-093-001-18350}}}—
“pure… untainted… cannot be grasped… does not say anything… does not converse about anything… cannot be apprehended”—
teach that it is comparable to space.
{{milestone:{label:5.363,id:UT23703-093-001-18353}}}“Because space does not say anything”— {{page:{number:404,id:UT23703-093-001-22071,folio:F.203.a}}}
even though in space something other than that space says something, in space nothing is said and there is no conversation,
“just like the two sounds of an echo, as an analogy,”{{note:{index1303,id:UT23703-093-001-18357}}}
reverberate in space, but it is not suitable to say that space says something.
{{milestone:{label:5.364,id:UT23703-093-001-18359}}}“Because space does not converse about anything”
means that because of its intrinsic nature there is no conversation in space. Alternatively, “saying something” is mere sound; “conversing” is naming. 
{{milestone:{label:5.365,id:UT23703-093-001-18361}}}“Subhūti, … because form is extremely pure, cannot be apprehended, is unproduced and unceasing, and without defilement and without purification”{{note:{index1304,id:UT23703-093-001-18362}}}—
when this perfection of wisdom sees all dharmas, it sees the “pure” aspect of form and so on because the stains of falsely imagined afflictions and conceptualizations constructed in thought do not exist; the aspect that “cannot be apprehended” because it is separated from all apprehending; the “unproduced and unceasing” aspects because it is a thoroughly established phenomenon; and the aspects “without defilement and without purification” because it is isolated from an intrinsic nature. At that point it is called 
“pure”
in its nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.366,id:UT23703-093-001-18366}}} Having thus taught that the perfection of wisdom is extremely pure, then, to engender faith in it, they
“will not contract diseases of the eye,”
and so on, teaches its benefits in the here and now and in future lives.{{note:{index1305,id:UT23703-093-001-18369}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.367,id:UT23703-093-001-18370}}}“In the perfection of wisdom there is no dharma that is produced or ceases, is defiled or purified, or is appropriated or rejected at all” 
teaches that production, cessation, and so on do not appear in the perfection of wisdom.
{{milestone:{label:5.368,id:UT23703-093-001-18372}}}“Thus, do not form a notion, and thus do not conceive”—
they do not even conceive of the perfection of wisdom as such
“a great jewel” {{page:{number:405,id:UT23703-093-001-22072,folio:F.203.b}}}
endowed with those good qualities. 
{{milestone:{label:5.369,id:UT23703-093-001-18376}}}“Subhūti, this perfection of wisdom does not establish any dharma, or teach it.”{{note:{index1306,id:UT23703-093-001-18377}}}
All dharmas are thoroughly established phenomena that do not alter, so at the time they are thoroughly established phenomena this perfection of wisdom appears like that, which is to say, there is no false projection of having to establish any special dharma; there is no false projection of taking hold of or bestowing any special dharma; there is no false projection of producing dharmas without outflows or stopping bad dharmas; there is no false projection of annihilating the dharmas of cyclic existence or of making purification permanent;{{note:{index1307,id:UT23703-093-001-18379}}} there is no false projection of being one or being different things; there is no false projection of coming about through the power of bodhisattva activities not there before or being separated from all obscurations; there is no false projection of having earlier become defiled by afflictions, secondary afflictions, and so on, and later being purified; there is no false projection of making dark dharmas decline and making bright dharmas increase; there is no false projection of being included in the three periods of time; there is no false projection of being established in the three realms or of having to transcend them; and there is no false projection of bestowing the perfection of giving and so on, or of removing their opposing sides of miserliness and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.370,id:UT23703-093-001-18380}}}“Subhūti, whether the tathāgatas arise or whether the tathāgatas do not arise”{{note:{index1308,id:UT23703-093-001-18381}}}
is teaching the mark of all dharmas that remain in the same state, nothing doing anything at all. Those “tathāgatas,” so called because they know just this state in which dharmas remain, appear in the world. It means just this is their {{page:{number:406,id:UT23703-093-001-22073,folio:F.204.a}}} clear realization, just this is
“the wheel of Dharma.”
{{milestone:{label:5.371,id:UT23703-093-001-18384}}}“Subhūti… it is not a second turning of the wheel of Dharma and it is not a first turning either.”{{note:{index1309,id:UT23703-093-001-18385}}}
It says this because ultimately all dharmas are beyond counting. It
“has not been made available in order to turn or not turn any Dharma”{{note:{index1310,id:UT23703-093-001-18388}}}
removes the notion or idea that it is turning or not turning the wheel of Dharma.
{{milestone:{label:5.372,id:UT23703-093-001-18390}}}“Given the emptiness that is the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature”
means the perfection of wisdom grasps all dharmas as the mark of the emptiness that is the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.373,id:UT23703-093-001-18392}}}“The perfection of wisdom is a great perfection,”
and so on. With the ninety-five statements the elder Subhūti explains at length that this perfection of wisdom engages with all dharmas.{{note:{index1311,id:UT23703-093-001-18394}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.374,id:UT23703-093-001-18395}}} There “the perfection of wisdom is a great perfection” teaches that it is a great object, and a great secret in the form of an object. It says about such a secret that it is three: a secret engagement with dharmas, a secret awakening, and a secret turning of the wheel of Dharma.
{{milestone:{label:5.375,id:UT23703-093-001-18396}}} There, for dharmas, governed by the conventional and ultimate, it engages with perceiving dharmas as dharmas and also engages with perceiving them as not dharmas as well, so it says
“all dharmas are empty of the intrinsic nature of all dharmas.”
{{milestone:{label:5.376,id:UT23703-093-001-18398}}}It teaches awakening but also sees the nonexistence of awakening, so it says{{note:{index1312,id:UT23703-093-001-18399}}}
“but still, bodhisattva great beings abiding in this perfection of wisdom fully awaken to unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening without fully awakening to any dharma at all.”
{{milestone:{label:5.377,id:UT23703-093-001-18401}}}Teaching the secret turning of the wheel of Dharma, it says{{note:{index1313,id:UT23703-093-001-18402}}}
“will turn the wheel of the Dharma but will not turn or not turn {{page:{number:407,id:UT23703-093-001-22074,folio:F.204.b}}} any Dharma.”
{{milestone:{label:5.378,id:UT23703-093-001-18404}}} Then there is the section with the eightfold turning of the wheel of Dharma:{{note:{index1314,id:UT23703-093-001-18405}}} the nonexistence of the Dharma, the nonexistence of the wheel, the nonexistence of the turning, the nonexistence of the intrinsic nature of an explanation, the nonexistence of one who explains, the nonexistence of one who listens, the nonexistence of realization, and the nonexistence of a noble person.
{{milestone:{label:5.379,id:UT23703-093-001-18406}}} There, about the nonexistence of the Dharma, it says
“will not see any Dharma at all, and will not not see any Dharma at all either.”
{{milestone:{label:5.380,id:UT23703-093-001-18408}}} About the nonexistence of the wheel, it says
“because a Dharma that will be turned or will not be turned cannot be apprehended.”{{note:{index1315,id:UT23703-093-001-18410}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.381,id:UT23703-093-001-18411}}} About the nonexistence of turning, it says
“emptiness does not turn it, nor does it not turn it. The signless and the wishless also do not turn it, nor do they not turn it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.382,id:UT23703-093-001-18413}}} About the nonexistence of an explanation, it says
“therefore, this teaching of the perfection of wisdom, this illumination,”
up to
“is the teaching of the perfection of wisdom that is perfectly pure.”
{{milestone:{label:5.383,id:UT23703-093-001-18417}}} About the nonexistence of one who explains, it says
“nobody teaches that teaching of the perfection of wisdom.”
{{milestone:{label:5.384,id:UT23703-093-001-18419}}} About the nonexistence of one who listens, it says
“and nobody receives it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.385,id:UT23703-093-001-18421}}} About the nonexistence of realization, it says
“nobody has directly realized it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.386,id:UT23703-093-001-18423}}} And about the absence of a noble person, it says
“nobody has entered into nirvāṇa either. And in this Dharma teaching there is also nobody who becomes worthy of offerings.”
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-4-2}}}Glosses
{{milestone:{label:5.387,id:UT23703-093-001-18425}}}“Because space is a nonexistent thing, Subhūti”{{note:{index1316,id:UT23703-093-001-18426}}}—
like space, it is not truly real in a form you can apprehend, and not not truly real in a form that cannot be apprehended. 
{{milestone:{label:5.388,id:UT23703-093-001-18428}}}“Because all dharmas are equally nonapprehendable, Subhūti”—
all dharmas are equally imaginary {{page:{number:408,id:UT23703-093-001-22075,folio:F.205.a}}} with a nature that cannot be apprehended. 
{{milestone:{label:5.389,id:UT23703-093-001-18430}}}“Because of not having a name and body”—
this means formless dharmas and form dharmas are not in the form of names.
{{milestone:{label:5.390,id:UT23703-093-001-18432}}}“Because the movement of breath in and out is unfindable”—
this is because upon analysis there is no movement of breath in and out because the body is empty like space.
{{milestone:{label:5.391,id:UT23703-093-001-18434}}}“Because applied and sustained thought is unfindable”—
it says this because the two, applied and sustained thought, occasion words, because it is said, “Having applied their mind and thought in a sustained way earlier, later on they deliver a speech.”{{note:{index1317,id:UT23703-093-001-18436}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.392,id:UT23703-093-001-18437}}}“Because the feeling, perception, volitional factors, and consciousness aggregates are unfindable.”
Because they have no form they are in their nature just a collection of names.{{note:{index1318,id:UT23703-093-001-18439}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.393,id:UT23703-093-001-18440}}}“Because all phenomena do not go away.”
Because all phenomena are separated from going.
{{milestone:{label:5.394,id:UT23703-093-001-18442}}}“Because all dharmas cannot be seized.”
Dharmas do not seize dharmas, so it 
“is not stolen.”{{note:{index1319,id:UT23703-093-001-18445}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.395,id:UT23703-093-001-18446}}}“Because all dharmas have come to an end in extreme purity.”
Because all dharmas appear as an extreme purity they do not arise and are not stopped, and hence appear to have come to an end. 
{{milestone:{label:5.396,id:UT23703-093-001-18448}}}“Because all dharmas do not arise and do not stop.”
All dharmas are empty. They appear as not arising and as not stopping.
{{milestone:{label:5.397,id:UT23703-093-001-18450}}}“Because death and rebirth are unfindable.”
It{{note:{index1320,id:UT23703-093-001-18452}}} knows that the time of deaths and rebirths appear based on false imagination, not ultimately. 
{{milestone:{label:5.398,id:UT23703-093-001-18453}}}“Because all dharmas are indestructible in their nature.”
It is indestructible because the nature of all dharmas is suchness, so it does not change. 
{{milestone:{label:5.399,id:UT23703-093-001-18455}}}“Because a dream that has been seen cannot be apprehended.”{{note:{index1321,id:UT23703-093-001-18456}}}
Just as that thing existent in a dream which has been seen in a dream {{page:{number:409,id:UT23703-093-001-22076,folio:F.205.b}}} cannot be apprehended and does not exist, so too all phenomena are there as nonexistent things.{{note:{index1322,id:UT23703-093-001-18458}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.400,id:UT23703-093-001-18459}}}“This is a perfection without purification… because the presence of defilement cannot be apprehended.”{{note:{index1323,id:UT23703-093-001-18460}}}
There can be purification if there is defilement, but all phenomena are pure in their nature so there is no defilement and there is no purification either. 
{{milestone:{label:5.401,id:UT23703-093-001-18462}}}“This is a perfection that does not stand… because all phenomena cannot be apprehended.”
Because all phenomena cannot be apprehended they therefore are not apprehended as standing anywhere. 
{{milestone:{label:5.402,id:UT23703-093-001-18464}}}“Because it is a full awakening to all dharmas as unmistaken suchness.”
All phenomena are the intrinsic nature of unmistaken suchness, which is to say, they make manifest that unmistaken intrinsic nature so they make available the wisdom that knows “all phenomena are calm.”{{note:{index1324,id:UT23703-093-001-18466}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.403,id:UT23703-093-001-18467}}}“Because the causal sign of greed cannot be apprehended.”
There is no causal sign that is a basis to become attached to. 
{{milestone:{label:5.404,id:UT23703-093-001-18469}}}“Because hate is not real.”
Because the causal sign that serves as a cause of hate does not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5.405,id:UT23703-093-001-18471}}}“This perfection of wisdom is a perfection that is not a means of measurement… because all phenomena do not fully arise.”
It might be supposed that all phenomena are caused to fully arise on account of a means of measurement.{{note:{index1325,id:UT23703-093-001-18473}}} But this perfection of wisdom does not see the emergence of a basis for the measurement of any phenomenon, therefore it is “not a means of measurement.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.406,id:UT23703-093-001-18474}}}“Because all phenomena are distinct.” 
Because all dharmas are isolated.
{{milestone:{label:5.407,id:UT23703-093-001-18476}}}“Because the measure of all phenomena cannot be apprehended.”
There might be a means of measurement were there something to be measured.{{note:{index1326,id:UT23703-093-001-18478}}} But because a means of measurement of all phenomena, were there to be something measured, cannot be apprehended and does not exist, therefore something to be measured does not exist either.
{{milestone:{label:5.408,id:UT23703-093-001-18479}}}“Because all phenomena are without attachment like space.” {{page:{number:410,id:UT23703-093-001-22077,folio:F.206.a}}}
All phenomena, similar to space, are without attachment. 
{{milestone:{label:5.409,id:UT23703-093-001-18481}}}“This… is an impermanent perfection
Because all dharmas are unproduced, like horns on a rabbit and so on, they are not destroyed. Therefore, they do not exist. They are impermanent because they are not existent things, because scripture says that “the meaning of a nonexistent thing is the meaning of impermanence.”{{note:{index1327,id:UT23703-093-001-18483}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.410,id:UT23703-093-001-18484}}}“Because all phenomena are not suitable to be clung to.”
All phenomena are not suitable to be clung to, or to be stayed with, or to be made use of, so it is suffering.{{note:{index1328,id:UT23703-093-001-18486}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.411,id:UT23703-093-001-18487}}}“This… is a perfection of the empty{{note:{index1329,id:UT23703-093-001-18488}}}… because an intrinsic nature of all phenomena cannot be apprehended.”
Those intrinsic natures—easily breakable, experience,{{note:{index1330,id:UT23703-093-001-18490}}} and so on—do not ultimately exist. Therefore, those phenomena are empty of those intrinsic natures. 
{{milestone:{label:5.412,id:UT23703-093-001-18491}}}“This… is a selfless perfection… because all phenomena are not settled down on.”
The “phenomena,” form and so on, do not exist. They are therefore not suitable to be “settled down on.” Since that is the case, the nonexistence of all the phenomena is selflessness. Even though there is no difference in the meaning of emptiness and selflessness, based on being designated they are differentiated. “The empty” is being without something else. To illustrate, you say “an empty pot” when it has no water. Similarly, because they are without an intrinsic nature, their “defining mark” and so on, those phenomena are thought of as “empty.” As for “selfless,” it is the nonexistence of the phenomena, like, to illustrate, the magically produced illusion of elephants and so on. You say “empty” when you want to say those phenomena are separated from their defining marks and so on. You say “selfless” when you want to say that “they are not existent”—they are not existent things.
{{milestone:{label:5.413,id:UT23703-093-001-18493}}}“Because all phenomena {{page:{number:411,id:UT23703-093-001-22078,folio:F.206.b}}} have no causal sign.”
Given that a causal sign is a defining mark and there is no such defining mark they are 
“without a defining mark.”
{{milestone:{label:5.414,id:UT23703-093-001-18496}}}“Because the emptiness of emptiness cannot be apprehended.”
This means there is just no second emptiness in emptiness. The empty is said to be “emptiness.” An “empty” that is a different attribute called “emptiness” does not exist at all. 
{{milestone:{label:5.415,id:UT23703-093-001-18498}}}“The great emptiness cannot be apprehended.”
“Great emptiness” is said of the immensity of just the nonexistence of forms for all the directions. A different attribute called “the great emptiness” does not exist at all. 
 You should construe them all like this as well.{{note:{index1331,id:UT23703-093-001-18501}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.416,id:UT23703-093-001-18502}}}“This… is a perfection that is the emptiness of a basic nature… because compounded and uncompounded dharmas cannot be apprehended.”
This means if compounded and uncompounded dharmas were findable, their basic nature would be not empty, but all dharmas are empty, hence their “emptiness of a basic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.417,id:UT23703-093-001-18504}}}“This… is a perfection that is giving… because miserliness cannot be apprehended.”
The miserliness that cannot be apprehended in the perfection of wisdom is the mark of giving. 
 You should construe the others like this as well.{{note:{index1332,id:UT23703-093-001-18507}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.418,id:UT23703-093-001-18508}}}“This… is a perfection that is the ten powers… because all the aspects of all dharmas cannot be apprehended.”{{note:{index1333,id:UT23703-093-001-18509}}}
All the aspects of all dharmas would fall within the range of the ten knowledges—the power that is knowledge of the possible and impossible and so on. But they are not within their range, they are unreal aspects. So, because those aspects do not ultimately exist, therefore the aspects that serve as the objects of the ten powers are seen not to exist, hence it is “a perfection that is the ten powers.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.419,id:UT23703-093-001-18511}}}“Because the knowledge of path aspects is not cowed.”{{note:{index1334,id:UT23703-093-001-18512}}}
The knowledge of path aspects of bodhisattvas {{page:{number:412,id:UT23703-093-001-22079,folio:F.207.a}}} is not cowed by any phenomenon. Therefore, the knowledge of path aspects, which in its nature is uncowed by anything, is
“a perfection that is fearlessness.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.420,id:UT23703-093-001-18515}}}“Because knowledge is totally unattached and unimpeded.”
Because the knowledge of bodhisattvas is totally unattached and unimpeded, therefore it is
“a perfection that is detailed and thorough knowledge.”
{{milestone:{label:5.421,id:UT23703-093-001-18518}}}“Because it has gone beyond all śrāvaka and pratyekabuddha attributes.”
Because śrāvakas and so on do not have this perfection of wisdom it is therefore counted as
“a perfection that is the… attributes of a buddha.”
{{milestone:{label:5.422,id:UT23703-093-001-18521}}}“This… is a perfection that is the realized one… because what has been spoken by all the buddhas is reality.”{{note:{index1335,id:UT23703-093-001-18522}}}
By a creative explanation, the realized one is so called because of having spoken thus, which is to say, the perfection of wisdom that observes thus—what has been spoken by all the buddhas—is called the “perfection that is the realized one.”
{{milestone:{label:5.423,id:UT23703-093-001-18524}}}“This… is a perfection that is self-originated… because it is in control of all dharmas.”
Because all dharmas are under its control, therefore it predominates among all dharmas so it is a “self-originated perfection.”{{note:{index1336,id:UT23703-093-001-18526}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-5}}}Explanation of Chapters 39 to 42
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-5-1}}}Absence of a practice and signs of completion
{{milestone:{label:5.424,id:UT23703-093-001-18527}}} It is easy to explain Śatakratu’s praise passage, the elder Śāriputra passage, and the Lord’s rejoicing passage so they are just as they are in the Sūtra.{{note:{index1337,id:UT23703-093-001-18528}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.425,id:UT23703-093-001-18529}}}“When practicing the perfection of wisdom [they] do not stand in form, and when they do not stand in form they practice the yoga of form.”{{note:{index1338,id:UT23703-093-001-18530}}}
The bodhisattvas’ transcendental knowledge of a knower of path aspects does not stand in any phenomenon, therefore just that not standing is their “practice of the yoga.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.426,id:UT23703-093-001-18532}}}“Furthermore, Kauśika, they do not practice the yoga of a bodhisattva’s form, and {{page:{number:413,id:UT23703-093-001-22080,folio:F.207.b}}} thus not practicing the yoga of form like that, they practice the yoga of form.”{{note:{index1339,id:UT23703-093-001-18533}}}
The earlier subsection of the passage refutes standing; here it refutes what is established by not standing.{{note:{index1340,id:UT23703-093-001-18535}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.427,id:UT23703-093-001-18536}}}“Do not apprehend form as past,”
and so on, teaches that they do not apprehend it in any of the three time periods. 
{{milestone:{label:5.428,id:UT23703-093-001-18538}}}“Śāriputra, it is because the depth of form is not form.”{{note:{index1341,id:UT23703-093-001-18539}}}
It says this because “the depth” is falsely imagined, so form itself ultimately does not exist. 
{{milestone:{label:5.429,id:UT23703-093-001-18541}}} The interpretation of the depth subsection, hard to fathom subsection, and immeasurable subsection; the Śatakratu passage and obtaining a prediction; the wilderness analogy, the spring analogy, and the pregnant woman analogy; and the passage on taking care of and teaching others is easy.{{note:{index1342,id:UT23703-093-001-18542}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.430,id:UT23703-093-001-18543}}} There are two signs that 
“the meditation on the perfection of wisdom… is completed”—
when they 
“do not see… an increase… or a decline in”
all dharmas, and when they see the marks of dharmas.{{note:{index1343,id:UT23703-093-001-18548}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.431,id:UT23703-093-001-18549}}}That the inconceivable has been taught and that they do not conceptualize the inconceivable are also signs that 
“the meditation on the perfection of wisdom… is completed.”{{note:{index1344,id:UT23703-093-001-18551}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.432,id:UT23703-093-001-18552}}} The sign that they are practicing the six perfections is that they{{note:{index1345,id:UT23703-093-001-18553}}}
“do not mentally construct and do not conceive of form, do not mentally construct and do not conceive of a causal sign of form, and do not mentally construct and do not conceive of an intrinsic nature of form.”
With the meditative stabilization on emptiness they do not mentally construct dharmas; with the meditative stabilization on signlessness they do not mentally construct causal signs; and with the meditative stabilization on wishlessness they do not mentally construct an intrinsic nature. They do not conceptualize falsely imagined phenomena; they do not conceptualize dependent phenomena.
{{milestone:{label:5.433,id:UT23703-093-001-18556}}} Earlier{{note:{index1346,id:UT23703-093-001-18557}}} it said that it is deep because of the depth of suchness; here, having superimposed the mark of suchness onto form and so on, and saying that it is deep, is because of the various dispositions of trainees.
{{milestone:{label:5.434,id:UT23703-093-001-18558}}}“Lord, the perfection of wisdom is an aggregate of the purity {{page:{number:414,id:UT23703-093-001-22081,folio:F.208.a}}} of all dharmas”
means it is pure and it is the aggregate of all dharmas.{{note:{index1347,id:UT23703-093-001-18560}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.435,id:UT23703-093-001-18561}}}“Lord, that… would not give rise to many hindrances would be amazing.”{{note:{index1348,id:UT23703-093-001-18562}}}
It says this having in mind that there are many obstacles to something excellent.
{{milestone:{label:5.436,id:UT23703-093-001-18564}}}Next, the explanation of the teaching about the merit from reciting the good Dharma is easy.{{note:{index1349,id:UT23703-093-001-18565}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-5-2}}}Last of the five hundreds
{{milestone:{label:5.437,id:UT23703-093-001-18566}}} “During the last of the ‘five hundreds’ ”{{note:{index1350,id:UT23703-093-001-18567}}}—
a “five hundred” incorporates five one hundreds. It is said that the time the doctrine of the Tathāgata lasts is five thousand years. If you break up and subdivide the five thousand years into five-hundred-year periods, there are ten five hundreds. For these there are ten chapters:{{note:{index1351,id:UT23703-093-001-18569}}} first, three chapters (the Understanding chapter, Practice chapter, and Scripture chapter). There the Understanding chapter is again subdivided into three chapters (the Worthy One chapter, Non-returner chapter, and stream enterer chapter); the Practice chapter too is subdivided into three chapters (the Insight chapter, Meditative Stabilization chapter, and Morality chapter); and the Scripture chapter is also subdivided into three (the Abhidharma chapter, Sūtra chapter, and Vinaya chapter). These nine chapters and the Mere Signs chapter{{note:{index1352,id:UT23703-093-001-18570}}} are the ten chapters.
{{milestone:{label:5.438,id:UT23703-093-001-18571}}} There, each of the ten chapters lasts five hundred years, so, the ten chapters comprise ten five hundreds that become the five thousand years. 
{{milestone:{label:5.439,id:UT23703-093-001-18572}}} There, in the first of all the five hundreds are the worthy ones; in the second five hundred, the non-returners; in the third, the stream enterers; in the fourth five hundred, insight; in the fifth, meditative stabilization; in the sixth, morality; in the seventh, the abhidharma; in the eighth, the sūtras; in the ninth, the vinaya; and in the tenth five hundred, a mere sign. It is just this that is called “the last of the five hundreds.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.440,id:UT23703-093-001-18573}}} Some say{{note:{index1353,id:UT23703-093-001-18574}}} “the measure of a human lifespan can be one hundred years. There in the earlier fifty years the color, shape, strength, {{page:{number:415,id:UT23703-093-001-22082,folio:F.208.b}}} intellect and so on increase, and in the later fifty years they wane. Similarly, the end of the time period, the time of the waning of the teaching, is like the later fifty years and hence is labeled ‘the last of the five hundreds.’ ” 
{{milestone:{label:5.441,id:UT23703-093-001-18575}}} *When formulated like that,{{note:{index1354,id:UT23703-093-001-18576}}} the duration of the lasting of the Tathāgata’s teaching is two thousand five hundred years. The two commentaries appear to be contradictory. Śāntarakṣita’s intention is that the good Dharma lasts from the Worthy One chapter up to the Meditative Stabilization chapter. There is the explanation in the explanatory tradition and there is this other expanation. In general there is agreement on five thousand years.*{{note:{index1355,id:UT23703-093-001-18577}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.442,id:UT23703-093-001-18578}}} The explanation of the teaching of all the benefits of the good qualities is easy.{{note:{index1356,id:UT23703-093-001-18579}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-5-3}}}Explanation of the work of Māra
{{milestone:{label:5.443,id:UT23703-093-001-18580}}} The work of Māra: 
“When it takes a really long time to have the confidence to speak”{{note:{index1357,id:UT23703-093-001-18582}}}
it becomes an impediment; and, 
“when the confidence to speak happens too fast,”
bodhisattvas become arrogant and act with disrespect. There is
“yawning”
and being arrogant;
“laughing”—
laughing or joking with each other when the Dharma is being explained; and
“fooling{{note:{index1358,id:UT23703-093-001-18591}}} with each other”
when they make the other want to laugh. 
{{milestone:{label:5.444,id:UT23703-093-001-18593}}}“Attached to each other as friends”{{note:{index1359,id:UT23703-093-001-18594}}}—
they do it to protect each other’s minds; they do not do it out of faith. There is also the reading “attached to other readings while not knowing what the meaning is.”
{{milestone:{label:5.445,id:UT23703-093-001-18596}}}“While if they yawn while… taking it up”—
in regard to these five, yawning and so on,{{note:{index1360,id:UT23703-093-001-18598}}} the earlier five are when they are writing it out; here it is when they are taking it up in their minds. 
{{milestone:{label:5.446,id:UT23703-093-001-18599}}}“As many thoughts as they have to leave, they appropriate that many eons of practice.”{{note:{index1361,id:UT23703-093-001-18600}}}
They have to practice the yoga of the perfection of wisdom again for as many eons as the thoughts they have to leave, because they do not reach maturity for that many eons, since their thought is confused. 
{{milestone:{label:5.447,id:UT23703-093-001-18602}}}“Those… would reject the root of the tree of the knowledge of all aspects.”{{note:{index1362,id:UT23703-093-001-18603}}}
To illustrate, if you get rid of the root of a tree you will not get 
“the branches, petals, and leaves”
as the outcome you aim for. Similarly, without the tree of the knowledge of all aspects you will not get śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas that are like the branches and leaves and so on. That is the meaning. 
{{milestone:{label:5.448,id:UT23703-093-001-18607}}} Connect this here in the same way: it is just as
“a dog might spurn”
its master’s tasty 
“food”
that is easy to get, and go looking for
“food from a servant”
that it either does not get, or only gets a bit of. 
{{milestone:{label:5.449,id:UT23703-093-001-18614}}} Similarly, connect this in the same way: it is just as when
“somebody finds an elephant,”
rejects it, and makes the absurd statement, “I am interested in 
‘the track’
of the elephant, I am not interested in the elephant.” {{page:{number:416,id:UT23703-093-001-22083,folio:F.209.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.450,id:UT23703-093-001-18619}}} The illustration of
“the hoofprint left by a bull,”
and the analogy of the 
“contractor who wants to build a Vaijayanta palace”
who looks for a
“celestial mansion circle,”
thinking a Vaijayanta palace is also just that measure, are similar.
{{milestone:{label:5.451,id:UT23703-093-001-18626}}}“Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom does not give confidence to speak”{{note:{index1363,id:UT23703-093-001-18627}}}
because it does not conceptualize; 
{{milestone:{label:5.452,id:UT23703-093-001-18629}}}“is inconceivable”
because it is beyond the range of speculative thought;
{{milestone:{label:5.453,id:UT23703-093-001-18631}}}“is without production and without cessation”
because it is thoroughly established as a final outcome that does not alter;
{{milestone:{label:5.454,id:UT23703-093-001-18633}}}“is without defilement and without purification”
because it is pure in its basic nature;
{{milestone:{label:5.455,id:UT23703-093-001-18635}}}“is without distraction”
because it is always in meditative equipoise;
{{milestone:{label:5.456,id:UT23703-093-001-18637}}}“is not something that can be spoken out loud”
because it is self-reflexive analytic knowledge;
{{milestone:{label:5.457,id:UT23703-093-001-18639}}}“is not part of a conversation”
because it is beyond language; 
{{milestone:{label:5.458,id:UT23703-093-001-18641}}}“is not something that can be talked about”
because it is beyond applied thought and sustained thought; and
{{milestone:{label:5.459,id:UT23703-093-001-18643}}}“cannot be apprehended”
because it is separated from apprehending anything as an existent thing. If they
{{milestone:{label:5.460,id:UT23703-093-001-18645}}}“form the notion ‘this deep perfection of wisdom is not an existent thing,’ Subhūti, they should know that this too is the work of Māra.”{{note:{index1364,id:UT23703-093-001-18646}}}
If they explain the perfection of wisdom with the notion that it does not exist, there is the fault of not honoring it.
{{milestone:{label:5.461,id:UT23703-093-001-18648}}}“The perfection of wisdom is without letters,”{{note:{index1365,id:UT23703-093-001-18649}}}
because it is not something that can be spoken out loud and is not something that can be heard.{{note:{index1366,id:UT23703-093-001-18651}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.462,id:UT23703-093-001-18652}}} The rest of the works of Māra are easy to understand.{{note:{index1367,id:UT23703-093-001-18653}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-1-5-4}}}Revealing this world
{{milestone:{label:5.463,id:UT23703-093-001-18654}}}“Subhūti… this deep perfection of wisdom gives birth to a tathāgata’s ten powers,”
and so on,{{note:{index1368,id:UT23703-093-001-18656}}} teaches that it gives birth to the ultimate tathāgata because it gives birth to the buddhadharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.464,id:UT23703-093-001-18657}}}“Reveals this world”—
it says it “reveals this world” in eleven forms:{{note:{index1369,id:UT23703-093-001-18659}}} it reveals the world of the aggregates; it reveals that the basic nature of all dharmas cannot be designated or apprehended; {{page:{number:417,id:UT23703-093-001-22084,folio:F.209.b}}} it reveals the thought activities of all beings and the divisions and so on;{{note:{index1370,id:UT23703-093-001-18660}}} it reveals the suchness of all phenomena; it reveals that the mark of all phenomena is no mark; it reveals the power of being cognizant of what has been done, and acknowledging what has been done,{{note:{index1371,id:UT23703-093-001-18661}}} and the nonexistence of one who knows and the nonexistence of one who sees; it reveals all unseen dharmas; and{{note:{index1372,id:UT23703-093-001-18662}}} it reveals the power of one who knows, one who understands, one who is aware of, and one who reveals a description of the world as empty, and who reveals this world as inconceivable and isolated, without an interior and so on, and at peace on account of the nonexistence of a perception of this world or the world beyond.
{{milestone:{label:5.465,id:UT23703-093-001-18663}}} Among those,
