{{milestone:{label:5.1109,id:UT23703-093-001-20475}}}Take this with the period when there is effort and thought construction. Subhūti asks,
“Will they without having meditated?”
and the Lord is silent, and then negates that with
“no.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1110,id:UT23703-093-001-20479}}}Subhūti asks,
“Will they, having meditated when they meditated, and without having meditated when they did not meditate?”
Because the two faults have already been explained, the answer is no. The response to,
“Will they without having meditated and without having not meditated?”
eliminates that because the passages propounding the two main options could have raised a doubt,{{note:{index1672,id:UT23703-093-001-20484}}} so it teaches that it is a totally inexpressible and inconceivable state. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1111,id:UT23703-093-001-20485}}}“Just as suchness will, Subhūti”{{note:{index1673,id:UT23703-093-001-20486}}}—
teaching all dharmas later in a state that cannot be apprehended—
“just as the self element,”
and so on, will.
{{milestone:{label:5.1112,id:UT23703-093-001-20490}}}“Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom cannot be labeled”
means it is inexpressible.
{{milestone:{label:5.1113,id:UT23703-093-001-20492}}}“Subhūti, what do you think, can a being that is a label be apprehended?”
and so on is teaching that hell and so on do not exist because they are falsely imagined phenomena, but they are labeled conventionally for the benefit of ordinary fools. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1114,id:UT23703-093-001-20494}}}“Without taking anything away and without adding anything”—
over-negation of what exists is “taking away”; over-reification of what does not exist is “adding something.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1115,id:UT23703-093-001-20496}}}“Subhūti, they should train in those as {{page:{number:503,id:UT23703-093-001-22170,folio:F.252.b}}} not produced and not stopping.”
Training “as not produced” is without over-reification; training “as not stopping” is without over-negation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1116,id:UT23703-093-001-20498}}}“Without meditating on and without investigating”{{note:{index1674,id:UT23703-093-001-20499}}}
is training in not occasioning anything. It is training that is not produced, because of not occasioning anything by thinking, “I should meditate, I should produce something”; and it is training that does not stop because of not occasioning anything by thinking, “I should destroy,”{{note:{index1675,id:UT23703-093-001-20501}}} should make something nonexistent.
{{milestone:{label:5.1117,id:UT23703-093-001-20502}}}“Form as empty of form”—
falsely imagined form does not exist in form itself because it is empty of the defining mark of form. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1118,id:UT23703-093-001-20504}}}“Not practicing is the bodhisattvas’ practice of the perfection of wisdom”{{note:{index1676,id:UT23703-093-001-20505}}}—
not practicing anything is the practice, because nothing can be apprehended.
{{milestone:{label:5.1119,id:UT23703-093-001-20507}}}“If not practicing is the practice of the perfection of wisdom, how then will bodhisattva great beings who are beginning the work practice the perfection of wisdom?”
This is the question,{{note:{index1677,id:UT23703-093-001-20509}}} and 
“bodhisattva great beings beginning the work,”
and so on,
“starting from the first production of the thought… train in all phenomena as providing no basis for apprehension” 
teaches that those beginning the work do not have a practice of the ultimate, but still they should train for it, so just that training is the practice.{{note:{index1678,id:UT23703-093-001-20514}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1120,id:UT23703-093-001-20515}}}“Lord… does the findable provide a basis for not apprehending?”{{note:{index1679,id:UT23703-093-001-20516}}}
This is asking, “Is a basis for not apprehending findable?” An unfindable intrinsic nature is unfindable so it cannot be said that “it provides a basis for apprehending,” therefore it says that it does not, with
“neither does the findable provide a basis for not apprehending.”{{note:{index1680,id:UT23703-093-001-20519}}}
This means there is a sameness to all dharmas that are marked as being unfindable, so the absence of a basis for apprehending is not unfindable.
{{milestone:{label:5.1121,id:UT23703-093-001-20521}}}“The sameness {{page:{number:504,id:UT23703-093-001-22171,folio:F.253.a}}} of the findable and the unfindable is the unfindable.”{{note:{index1681,id:UT23703-093-001-20522}}}
The existent thing when all dharmas are findable and the nonexistent thing when all dharmas are unfindable are both comparable. Why? Because they are without an intrinsic nature. The findable is falsely imagined and hence without an intrinsic nature, and the unfindable is in the form of a nonexistent thing and hence without an intrinsic nature too, so both are comparable as being without an intrinsic nature. This means the sameness of both the findable and unfindable, that absence of an intrinsic nature, is the unfindable.{{note:{index1682,id:UT23703-093-001-20524}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1122,id:UT23703-093-001-20525}}}“How… will… [they] complete level after level, and how… will they reach the knowledge of all aspects?”
This intends to say that if they are not attached to what provides a basis for apprehending, how will they work hard at level after level and the knowledge of all aspects? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1123,id:UT23703-093-001-20527}}}“Subhūti… a perfection of wisdom cannot be apprehended,”{{note:{index1683,id:UT23703-093-001-20528}}}
and so on, teaches that with a findable intrinsic nature a higher level or the knowledge of all aspects would not be reached, but because the perfection of wisdom, awakening, and a bodhisattva are in their nature unfindable, as the absence of apprehending gets stronger and stronger there is an ascent from one level to the other and they reach the knowledge of all aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1124,id:UT23703-093-001-20530}}}“How will [they]… make an investigation into… all these dharmas that are without an intrinsic nature?”
If all dharmas are without an intrinsic nature, how will they make an investigation into
“ ‘this is form, this is feeling,’ ”
and so on?
{{milestone:{label:5.1125,id:UT23703-093-001-20534}}}“Subhūti… bodhisattvas… who do it in such a way that they apprehend form… do not make an investigation into dharmas,” {{page:{number:505,id:UT23703-093-001-22172,folio:F.253.b}}}
and so on, teaches that bodhisattvas do not apprehend any dharmas, form and so on. As they progress more and more, they apprehend less and less and thereby enter into an unfindable reality. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1126,id:UT23703-093-001-20536}}}“Lord, if [they]… do not apprehend form,”
and so on, is asking: how, if they have entered into an unfindable reality, will they accomplish practices that apprehend a basis—the completion of the perfections, entry into the secure state of a bodhisattva, purification of a buddhafield, bringing beings to maturity, awakening, turning the wheel of the Dharma, the work of a buddha, and freeing all beings?
{{milestone:{label:5.1127,id:UT23703-093-001-20538}}}“Subhūti, bodhisattva great beings do not practice the perfection of wisdom for the sake of form,”
and so on, teaches that bodhisattvas do not practice the dharmas, form and so on, but rather practice for the state in which all dharmas are unfindable.{{note:{index1684,id:UT23703-093-001-20540}}} The earlier explanation was teaching that they were findable conventionally as designations, not ultimately. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1128,id:UT23703-093-001-20541}}} I have explained the meaning of 
“unmade, unchanging”
before.{{note:{index1685,id:UT23703-093-001-20544}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1129,id:UT23703-093-001-20545}}}“How is there an arrangement of three vehicles?”
means that if all dharmas are unmade and unchanging there will be no division into three vehicles.
{{milestone:{label:5.1130,id:UT23703-093-001-20547}}}“Subhūti, no arrangement at all can be apprehended in dharmas that are unmade and unchanging” 
intends that the falsely imagined arrangement of vehicles does not ultimately exist. Here the questions and answers are easy to understand so they have not been explained in detail.
{{milestone:{label:5.1131,id:UT23703-093-001-20549}}}“As an ordinary convention, but not ultimately, I keep these beings… away {{page:{number:506,id:UT23703-093-001-22173,folio:F.254.a}}} from seizing on the unreal.”{{note:{index1686,id:UT23703-093-001-20550}}}
It is saying that ultimately any beings included in the three groups are unfindable. They are simply designated conventionally with those names, simply as an ordinary convention, not ultimately, to stop them seizing on unreal dharmas as real. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1132,id:UT23703-093-001-20552}}}“But Lord, the tathāgatas stood in the ultimate and fully awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.”
He responds in the negative to this question with 
“no, Subhūti,”
because ultimately there is no standing and there is no full awakening. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1133,id:UT23703-093-001-20556}}}“Well then, the tathāgatas stood in a succession of miraculous powers and fully awakened”{{note:{index1687,id:UT23703-093-001-20557}}}
means if not ultimately, well then, as magical creations? Again, the answer he gives is because they absolutely do not exist. A realization inexpressible in its nature and in the form of self-reflexive analytic knowledge of all dharmas is complete awakening. He intends this: “And so why do you still inquire if they stand in the ultimate, or if they stand in a succession of miraculous powers?” With
“but do not stand in the compounded element or the uncompounded element,”
and so on, it teaches that even
“awakening”
is not anywhere at all. It explains that with the analogy of a tathāgata’s magical creation.
{{milestone:{label:5.1134,id:UT23703-093-001-20563}}} As for,{{note:{index1688,id:UT23703-093-001-20564}}}
“Subhūti, there is no distinction… between a tathāgata and a tathāgata’s magical creation,”
and 
“the magical creation does the work,”
the Lord Buddha was passing into complete nirvāṇa and at that time he did not see a bodhisattva like our lord Maitreya suitable for a prophecy, to whom he could say, “After I have passed away, do the work of a buddha and work for the welfare of beings.” He therefore emanated a magically created {{page:{number:507,id:UT23703-093-001-22174,folio:F.254.b}}} perfect form comparable to his own body and said to it, “You must do the work of a buddha.” He then passed into nirvāṇa. When he had done so the Tathāgata’s magical creation did the work of the Buddha in all world systems and benefited beings. When that magical creation saw a bodhisattva suitable for a prophesy, he entrusted beings into that bodhisattva’s hands and demonstrated complete nirvāṇa. Between that magical creation and a tathāgata there is no difference at all. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1135,id:UT23703-093-001-20569}}} It says
“the true nature of dharmas on account of which the magical creation…”{{note:{index1689,id:UT23703-093-001-20571}}}
because they are both the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature. Both come about just in order to benefit beings, and both do their{{note:{index1690,id:UT23703-093-001-20573}}} work. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1136,id:UT23703-093-001-20574}}}“But has the Lord not complicated the true dharmic nature of all dharmas”{{note:{index1691,id:UT23703-093-001-20575}}}
by explaining nonexistent dharmas as being existent?
{{milestone:{label:5.1137,id:UT23703-093-001-20577}}}“Subhūti, I have taught… dharmas with words and signs.”
He accepts the ideas of simple folk as ordinary convention. He has explained like that; otherwise, it would not be easy.
{{milestone:{label:5.1138,id:UT23703-093-001-20579}}}“There is no settling down to do with names and signs.”{{note:{index1692,id:UT23703-093-001-20580}}}
He uses conventional designations that are in accord with ordinary people because they are incapable of understanding in other ways. It is difficult for them. There is no settling down on them, however, so there is no fault. This is teaching that were they to settle down, thinking “this is true,” then there would be a fault.
{{milestone:{label:5.1139,id:UT23703-093-001-20582}}}“Subhūti, were a name to settle down on a name, or were a sign to settle down on a sign”—
if names settled down on names or if causal signs settled down on causal signs, then 
“emptiness would settle down on emptiness,”
and similarly,
“signlessness”
and so on would settle down. Thus, it is saying that emptiness and so on {{page:{number:508,id:UT23703-093-001-22175,folio:F.255.a}}} do not settle down because they are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature. Similarly, buddhas and śrāvakas do not settle down.
{{milestone:{label:5.1140,id:UT23703-093-001-20588}}}“Subhūti, all dharmas are thus simply mere names.”
Thus, while all dharmas are simply mere names and signs, those in the world do not know them as such. Therefore, bodhisattvas practice so that they will come to that realization. Thus, all dharmas are simply mere names and signs and they reach the knowledge of all aspects by realizing them. This is teaching that were any dharma to be an existent thing then there would be no complete awakening.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-3-4}}}The three knowledges
{{milestone:{label:5.1141,id:UT23703-093-001-20590}}}“Subhūti, all-knowledge belongs to śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, the knowledge of path aspects… to bodhisattva great beings, and the knowledge of all aspects… to tathāgatas, worthy ones, perfectly complete buddhas.”{{note:{index1693,id:UT23703-093-001-20591}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1142,id:UT23703-093-001-20592}}}Among these, “all-knowledge”: Beginning as the three forms of the knowledge of all those who know that “all compounded phenomena are impermanent; all contaminated phenomena are suffering; all phenomena are without a self,” all-knowledge is the definitive knowledge of all dharmas based on dharma and subsequent realization knowledge.{{note:{index1694,id:UT23703-093-001-20593}}} That knowledge, furthermore, is not knowledge of all dharmas in all aspects. The knowledge of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas is called all-knowledge because by way of the three marks{{note:{index1695,id:UT23703-093-001-20594}}} and four truths they are not perplexed about all dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1143,id:UT23703-093-001-20595}}} “The knowledge of path aspects”: Here, from the first production of the thought of awakening on the devoted course of conduct level up to the Dharmameghā level, {{page:{number:509,id:UT23703-093-001-22176,folio:F.255.b}}} the knowledge operating as insight by penetrating into suchness in the omnipresent sense, the tip sense, and so on,{{note:{index1696,id:UT23703-093-001-20596}}} which acts to cause the transformation of the basis, operates for the happiness and benefit of beings, and causes bodhisattvas to reach the great city of the knowledge of all aspects is called the knowledge of path aspects.
{{milestone:{label:5.1144,id:UT23703-093-001-20597}}} “The knowledge of all aspects” is the knowledge of buddhas as far-reaching as the space element, for the welfare of beings without interruption, that realizes the body of dharmas—a resultant knowledge of the abandonment of residual impression connections called the knowledge of all aspects because it is the result of having comprehended all dharmas in all aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1145,id:UT23703-093-001-20598}}}“Subhūti, that one aspect on account of which… [it] is called ‘knowledge of all aspects’ is thus the calm aspect.”{{note:{index1697,id:UT23703-093-001-20599}}}
That aspect the tathāgatas comprehend, the subsiding of all the aspects of the conceptualizations separated entirely from the world as beings and from the container world, when the morality encompassing the three realms has stopped the net of conceptual thought—that which is the extremely calm aspect that constitutes the spontaneous body of dharmas that is the absolutely pure dharma-constituent accessed as a sameness—is the aspect of all dharmas, hence “all aspects.” The knowledge entity of the sort that has accessed such an aspect is called the knowledge of all aspects.
{{milestone:{label:5.1146,id:UT23703-093-001-20601}}}“An abandonment of all residual impression connections”{{note:{index1698,id:UT23703-093-001-20602}}}—
from among the residual impressions left by action and conceptual affliction, here cutting the continuum of the uninterrupted arising, one to the next, of cause and effect is called the abandonment of all residual impression connections.
{{milestone:{label:5.1147,id:UT23703-093-001-20604}}}“Before reaching the knowledge of all aspects {{page:{number:510,id:UT23703-093-001-22177,folio:F.256.a}}} is there an uncompounded abandonment of afflictions?”
[The Lord] says [there is] because it is in the form of a cessation. He says, nevertheless, the cessation is simply just an abandonment, so 
“they still do odd things with their bodies and voices.{{note:{index1699,id:UT23703-093-001-20607}}} These are not even bad in ordinary persons,”
like gazing in a mirror, hopping while walking, and Pilindavatsa’s use of a word for a low caste woman.{{note:{index1700,id:UT23703-093-001-20609}}} These are not bad, whether for an ordinary person or a noble person. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1148,id:UT23703-093-001-20610}}}“Do bodhisattvas actualize the very limit of reality having stood on a path… or having stood on what is not a bad path?”{{note:{index1701,id:UT23703-093-001-20611}}}
and so on. The Lord again says about the possibilities that “they cannot stand on the path because it is the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1149,id:UT23703-093-001-20613}}}“Lord, if the path is not an existent thing and nirvāṇa is not an existent thing, why is it taught that ‘this is a stream enterer; this is a once-returner,’ ”{{note:{index1702,id:UT23703-093-001-20614}}}
and so on, intends that you can suppose about the explanations of noble persons and of buddhas that they are explanations based on the path, or explanations because of having reached nirvāṇa, but if there are neither, how is there going to be a presentation of noble persons? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1150,id:UT23703-093-001-20616}}}“Subhūti… all of these are categories of the uncompounded.”{{note:{index1703,id:UT23703-093-001-20617}}}
He again says that even though both a path and nirvāṇa are nonexistent they are categories of the suchness that is the basic nature of the uncompounded.
{{milestone:{label:5.1151,id:UT23703-093-001-20619}}}“Lord, does something uncompounded make the categories ‘this is a stream enterer’,”
and so on, is asking—intending the “categories of the uncompounded”—whether the uncompounded makes, or produces, those categories of persons. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1152,id:UT23703-093-001-20621}}}“Subhūti, the uncompounded does not make categories,”{{note:{index1704,id:UT23703-093-001-20622}}}
and so on, teaches that even though the uncompounded is not the producer, still, {{page:{number:511,id:UT23703-093-001-22178,folio:F.256.b}}} because of the special feature of entering into suchness through the power of the transformation of the basis, and the special feature of the abandonment of latent affliction, this or that sort of person comes about. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1153,id:UT23703-093-001-20624}}}“Lord, how will there be a later limit of saṃsāra?”
Earlier,{{note:{index1705,id:UT23703-093-001-20626}}} in the explanation of the emptiness of no beginning and no end, it said “there is no saṃsāra,” about the unfindable beginning, middle, and end of saṃsāra. Now it asks this, intending that if the worthy ones are categories of the uncompounded there will be an end to saṃsāra.
{{milestone:{label:5.1154,id:UT23703-093-001-20627}}}“Having taken ordinary convention as the authority, they are simply spoken about, even though ultimately there cannot be categories.”
This is teaching that the suchness of ordinary persons and worthy ones is there at all times so there is no later limit, but still, having taken the cutting of the continuum of those falsely imagined dharmas called “the five aggregates” as its point of departure, it explains like that according to ordinary convention. Therefore, it says
“those for whom an end is demarcated.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1155,id:UT23703-093-001-20630}}}“Lord, if in all dharmas empty of their own marks a prior limit is not apprehended, what need is there to say more about a later limit?”
This is saying the falsely imagined phenomena, the five aggregate “dharmas, are empty of their own marks” because they are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature and hence are like an illusion. So, given that there is no “prior limit” of them perceived as being produced, “what need is there to say more about a later limit” when they are perceived as stopping?
{{milestone:{label:5.1156,id:UT23703-093-001-20632}}}“Exactly so, Subhūti, exactly so!”
He rejoices in his statement because all dharmas are not produced and do not stop.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-3-5}}}The meaning of pāramitā
{{milestone:{label:5.1157,id:UT23703-093-001-20634}}}“Subhūti… this perfection of wisdom is, of all dharmas, perfect; therefore, it is called perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1706,id:UT23703-093-001-20635}}}
There are four alternative meanings of pāramitā.
{{milestone:{label:5.1158,id:UT23703-093-001-20637}}} Among them, first,{{note:{index1707,id:UT23703-093-001-20638}}}{{page:{number:512,id:UT23703-093-001-22179,folio:F.257.a}}} similar in meaning to the word parama (ultimate), there is the word parami. An abstract noun “superiority” (pārami) is derived from that. It says “superiority” because it is in the form of the limit of all dharmas and all dharmas culminate in it. The received tradition says, “Also when a suffix that makes an abstract noun [like -tā] is at the end it expresses just the thing itself, as, for example, saying of running water, ‘the water element’s fluidity.’ ” {{note:{index1708,id:UT23703-093-001-20641}}} Hence it says, “Subhūti, this is the ultimate (parama) superiority (pārami-tā) of all dharmas.” It means that it is extremely superior, it is the final superiority of all dharmas.
{{milestone:{label:5.1159,id:UT23703-093-001-20642}}} Alternatively, pāram (farther shore) means limit and ita means gone. Hence pāramitā, “gone to the other side.” Therefore, it says
“with this… all śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattva great beings, and tathāgatas, worthy ones, perfectly complete buddhas have reached the other side.”
It is called perfection because it causes them to go to the farther shore. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1160,id:UT23703-093-001-20645}}} Alternatively, construe the word parama (perfect) with paramārtha (the ultimate). Because it arises from the ultimate it is an understanding of the ultimate (pāramitā); it comes about with the ultimate as its objective support. The wisdom that has arisen having taken as its objective support the basic nature marked by nonabiding nirvāṇa, which is the ultimate sameness of all dharmas, is the perfection of wisdom. Therefore, it says,
“Also, Subhūti, with this perfection of wisdom the tathāgata has fully awakened to the fact that all dharmas are not ultimately different; therefore, it is called perfection of wisdom.”
The wisdom has the ultimate as its objective support so the tathāgatas have fully awakened to the ultimate. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1161,id:UT23703-093-001-20648}}} Alternatively, construe the word pāra (farthest limit) with suchness, because it is the farthest limit of everything. The wisdom that has gone into the farthest limit, has reached suchness, is said to be perfection (pāramitā). Therefore, it says, 
“gone into this perfection of wisdom is suchness, and gone into it {{page:{number:513,id:UT23703-093-001-22180,folio:F.257.b}}} also is unmistaken suchness.”{{note:{index1709,id:UT23703-093-001-20650}}}
Because gone into it are suchness and so on, it is said that it has extended over suchness and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1162,id:UT23703-093-001-20652}}}“Neither conjoined with nor disjoined from,”
and so on—up to here, the explanation has been of just the intrinsic nature of the perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1163,id:UT23703-093-001-20654}}}“This perfection of wisdom causes the practice of all dharmas, this perfection of wisdom bestows all confidences”
means the practice of all dharmas causing the production of all knowledges.{{note:{index1710,id:UT23703-093-001-20656}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1164,id:UT23703-093-001-20657}}}“Because all those who do the stopping, those who will stop, and the way the stopping happens cannot be apprehended in the perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1711,id:UT23703-093-001-20658}}}
This means a stopper, something that needs to be stopped, and the stopping to be done cannot be apprehended in this perfection of wisdom, so they{{note:{index1712,id:UT23703-093-001-20660}}} cannot stop bodhisattvas practicing it. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1165,id:UT23703-093-001-20661}}}“Furthermore, Subhūti, bodhisattva great beings should practice the reality of the perfection of wisdom—namely, they should practice the reality of impermanence, the reality of suffering, and the reality of selfless.”{{note:{index1713,id:UT23703-093-001-20662}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1166,id:UT23703-093-001-20663}}}Having taught the condition shared in common by everything with these three, the realities of these eleven{{note:{index1714,id:UT23703-093-001-20664}}} knowledges, from
“the good of the knowledge of suffering, the good of the knowledge of origination,”
up to
“the good of the knowledge of mastery, and the good of the knowledge in accord with sound,”
are the intrinsic nature of the perfection of wisdom, so they teach the good of the perfection of wisdom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1167,id:UT23703-093-001-20669}}}“According to the reality and the mode”—
“the reality” is those realities of impermanence and so on; “the mode” is the intrinsic nature of the perfection of wisdom dealt with below.{{note:{index1715,id:UT23703-093-001-20671}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1168,id:UT23703-093-001-20672}}}“When… practicing this deep perfection of wisdom’s reality… they should not practice with the idea ‘greed is good for me’ or ‘is bad for me,’ ”
and so on, {{page:{number:514,id:UT23703-093-001-22181,folio:F.258.a}}} is teaching that they should eliminate the conceptualization of good or bad as different, because in suchness the concern with such things does not exist. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1169,id:UT23703-093-001-20674}}}“They should not practice with the idea ‘form is good for me’ or ‘form is bad for me.’ ”
Viewing form falsely considered as a fact is “bad”; viewing form as unfindable is “good.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1170,id:UT23703-093-001-20676}}}“Whether the tathāgatas arise or whether the tathāgatas do not arise”{{note:{index1716,id:UT23703-093-001-20677}}}
is teaching that 
“the perfection of wisdom does not do anything good or bad to anything,”
because
“the establishment of dharmas,”
just the intrinsic nature, thus 
“remains”
as it is.
{{milestone:{label:5.1171,id:UT23703-093-001-20685}}}“The perfection of wisdom does not cause any compounded or uncompounded dharma at all”
is teaching that because, having looked, the perfection of wisdom does not see any compounded or uncompounded dharma, it does not cause any dharma. So how will the perfection of wisdom cause anything good or bad?{{note:{index1717,id:UT23703-093-001-20687}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1172,id:UT23703-093-001-20688}}}“But Lord, the uncompounded is good for all noble… is it not?”
It says this intending: does this perfection of wisdom not cause attainment of uncompounded nirvāṇa? It
“is not there to be good or bad for anything” 
means the perfection of wisdom, as a cause, is not in any way good or bad for nirvāṇa. It also teaches that through the simile of 
“the suchness of space.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1173,id:UT23703-093-001-20693}}}“Lord, having trained in the uncompounded perfection of wisdom, do bodhisattva great beings not reach the knowledge of all aspects?”
He asks this intending: does this perfection of wisdom not produce the knowledge of all aspects?
{{milestone:{label:5.1174,id:UT23703-093-001-20695}}} Having said that, the Lord rejoices in his statement because, when practicing, that is conventionally {{page:{number:515,id:UT23703-093-001-22182,folio:F.258.b}}} so. He then negates it, with
“but not in a dualistic way.”
This means the perfection of wisdom and the knowledge of all aspects are one, they are not different and are not two, therefore there is nothing that assists and nothing that is assisted.
{{milestone:{label:5.1175,id:UT23703-093-001-20698}}} What is intended by
“Lord, does a nondual dharma reach a nondual dharma?”
It is well known that bodhisattvas reach the knowledge of all aspects with the perfection of wisdom as the cause. In regard to that, he is asking about two possibilities—whether these bodhisattvas without an intrinsic nature reach a perfection of wisdom with a nondual intrinsic nature,{{note:{index1718,id:UT23703-093-001-20701}}} or whether bodhisattvas with a dual intrinsic nature reach a perfection of wisdom with a nondual intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1176,id:UT23703-093-001-20702}}} The Lord does not assent because it is not suitable to be expressed as either. He says,
“Because neither a dual dharma nor a nondual dharma can be apprehended, the knowledge of all aspects is thus reached by way of not apprehending anything at all.”
Just as all these dharmas cannot be apprehended as being constituted as dual or constituted as being nondual, similarly the knowledge of all aspects is reached by way of dharmas that cannot be apprehended as dual and dharmas that cannot be apprehended as nondual. Other than that, it does not happen at all.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-4}}}Explanation of Chapters 64 to 72
{{milestone:{label:5.1177,id:UT23703-093-001-20706}}} Having heard about such a deep state, he says, 
“Deep, Lord, is the perfection of wisdom,” 
and so on.{{note:{index1719,id:UT23703-093-001-20709}}} Connect this with this simile as well: understand, as an illustration, that just as a person who wants roots, bark, leaves, flowers, and fruit does not, in the beginning, apprehend them, similarly a bodhisattva {{page:{number:516,id:UT23703-093-001-22183,folio:F.259.a}}} does not apprehend all dharmas. And just as the person gets and makes use of the roots, bark, and so on later when the trunk has grown, similarly all beings are given use of the benefits and happiness when the many accumulations of merit and knowledge have increased and they have gained the knowledge of all aspects. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1178,id:UT23703-093-001-20710}}}“Subhūti, it is because that suchness, on account of which tathāgatas are labeled, is just the suchness… on account of which the suchness of all beings and the suchness of the tathāgatas is labeled.”
The “tathāgatas” are so called because of having gone into reality.{{note:{index1720,id:UT23703-093-001-20712}}} Bodhisattvas, too, go into reality, therefore they should indeed be called tathāgatas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1179,id:UT23703-093-001-20713}}} In the second subsection of the passage,
“standing in this suchness, bodhisattva great beings,”
because of comprehending and realizing suchness,
“are called tathāgatas.”{{note:{index1721,id:UT23703-093-001-20717}}}
This reality is also called 
“the perfection of wisdom.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1180,id:UT23703-093-001-20720}}} After this, the increase in benefits and merits from practicing suchness and the perfection of wisdom is easy to understand.{{note:{index1722,id:UT23703-093-001-20721}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1181,id:UT23703-093-001-20722}}}“Candidates for bodhisattva”{{note:{index1723,id:UT23703-093-001-20723}}}
are those standing on the path to perfect, complete awakening. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1182,id:UT23703-093-001-20725}}}“Subhūti… the knowledge of all aspects is a nonexistent thing that is without a defining mark,”{{note:{index1724,id:UT23703-093-001-20726}}}
and so on. It is “a nonexistent thing” because it is beyond existent dharmas; “without a defining mark” because it is separated from specific and general defining marks; 
{{milestone:{label:5.1183,id:UT23703-093-001-20728}}}“without a causal sign”
because it is separated from all words and signifiers;
{{milestone:{label:5.1184,id:UT23703-093-001-20730}}}“without effort”
because it is spontaneous;
{{milestone:{label:5.1185,id:UT23703-093-001-20732}}}“unproduced”
because it is uncompounded;
{{milestone:{label:5.1186,id:UT23703-093-001-20734}}}“and not appearing”
because it is marked as not remaining.
{{milestone:{label:5.1187,id:UT23703-093-001-20736}}}“Subhūti, the objective support of the knowledge of all aspects is a nonexistent thing”
means “it operates having taken a nonexistent thing as the point of departure”; it is not the objective support condition. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1188,id:UT23703-093-001-20738}}}“The dominant factor is mindfulness.”
It says that based on its being its earlier cause. {{page:{number:517,id:UT23703-093-001-22184,folio:F.259.b}}} It is not there at that time. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1189,id:UT23703-093-001-20740}}}“Subhūti, something that has arisen from a union has no intrinsic nature…”{{note:{index1725,id:UT23703-093-001-20741}}}
Form, feeling, and so on, which are imaginary in their intrinsic nature, are said to be “arisen from a union” because they have arisen dependent on conditions. Such an intrinsic nature is a nominal one because it is necessarily dependent. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1190,id:UT23703-093-001-20743}}}“And anything arisen from a union with no intrinsic nature is a nonexistent thing.”
A dharma that is contingent on something else—that is not an “intrinsic nature”—is called a “nonexistent thing.” It is not nonexistent because it is absolutely nonexistent like a rabbit’s horns and so on; it is because it is the nonexistent thing that is the reverse of a phenomenon that is an existent thing. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1191,id:UT23703-093-001-20745}}}“Are the intrinsic nature of a nonexistent thing”{{note:{index1726,id:UT23703-093-001-20746}}}—
falsely imagined dharmas, form and so on, are called “nonexistent things.” The reversed intrinsic nature they have is also called “the intrinsic nature of a nonexistent thing.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1192,id:UT23703-093-001-20748}}} After that it teaches that the perfection of wisdom is the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature and is skillful means. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1193,id:UT23703-093-001-20749}}} There,
“Lord, are phenomena separated from the phenomena themselves?”{{note:{index1727,id:UT23703-093-001-20751}}}
means that if all phenomena are separated from all phenomena, in that case something known and something that knows would not exist, and it would not be suitable to say, “It is known.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1194,id:UT23703-093-001-20753}}}“It is not appropriate that an existent thing knows an existent thing.”
It is not appropriate that a falsely imagined phenomenon knows a falsely imagined phenomenon, like an illusory elephant a footprint of an illusory elephant. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1195,id:UT23703-093-001-20755}}}“It is not appropriate that a nonexistent thing knows a nonexistent thing,”{{note:{index1728,id:UT23703-093-001-20756}}}
like space;
“it is not appropriate that an existent thing knows a nonexistent thing,”
like an illusory person space; and
“it is not appropriate that a nonexistent thing knows an existent thing,”
like space an illusory person. This is the perfection of wisdom of existent things and nonexistent things. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1196,id:UT23703-093-001-20762}}}“Lord, is ordinary convention one thing and the ultimate another?” {{page:{number:518,id:UT23703-093-001-22185,folio:F.260.a}}}
An ordinary convention is marked as a nonexistent thing, so the question is about the ultimate. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1197,id:UT23703-093-001-20764}}}“Just that suchness of ordinary convention is the suchness of the ultimate” 
means that the suchness of “ordinary convention”—of all dharmas, form and so on—is itself just the suchness of the ultimate. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1198,id:UT23703-093-001-20766}}}“Subhūti, true reality is called buddha”{{note:{index1729,id:UT23703-093-001-20767}}}
says what the intrinsic nature marking an awakened being is. It means true reality, suchness, the dharma body, is called buddha.
{{milestone:{label:5.1199,id:UT23703-093-001-20769}}}“Also, they are those who have fully awakened to the true Dharma,{{note:{index1730,id:UT23703-093-001-20770}}} therefore they are called buddha,”
and so on, provides three creative explanations. With the knowledge of a worthy one’s path, the lords awaken to the true Dharma—the state of nirvāṇa; then, with the knowledge of a knower of all aspects they have a penetrating realization of true reality as a reality that is empty, calm, and so on; and with the subsequent attainment of the knowledge of those who know all, they subsequently realize the characteristic marks of all. Thus, it says, because
“there are those who have fully awakened to the true Dharma… have a penetrating realization of true reality, … [and] have fully awakened to all dharmas as they really are, therefore they are called buddha.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1200,id:UT23703-093-001-20773}}}“Lord, what is the word awakening for?”
Awakening is also taught threefold: intrinsic nature, characteristic mark, and creative explanation. The intrinsic nature is twofold: the thoroughly established intrinsic nature and the falsely imagined intrinsic nature. In regard to the thoroughly established intrinsic nature, it says,
“Subhūti, awakening is a word for emptiness.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1201,id:UT23703-093-001-20776}}}In regard to the falsely imagined intrinsic nature, it says,
“Also, Subhūti, awakening is a word for mere designation.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1202,id:UT23703-093-001-20778}}}As for the characteristic mark, {{page:{number:519,id:UT23703-093-001-22186,folio:F.260.b}}} it says
“true reality means awakening.”{{note:{index1731,id:UT23703-093-001-20780}}}
The characteristic mark of the ultimate is true reality, called the reality of the ultimate.
{{milestone:{label:5.1203,id:UT23703-093-001-20782}}} As for the creative explanation, it is threefold:
“that awakening is a realization that all dharmas are a mere designation and causal sign,”
and so on. There, the creative explanation of it as the realization of the marks of falsely imagined phenomena is: “it is a realization that all dharmas are a mere designation and causal sign.” It says about the dharma body’s way of being marked by the transformation of the basis on account of the realization of dependent phenomena, 
“that… is the awakening of the lord buddhas, therefore it is called awakening.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1204,id:UT23703-093-001-20787}}}As for the realization of the mark of the thoroughly established phenomenon, it says
“the lord buddhas have fully awakened to it, therefore it is called awakening.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1205,id:UT23703-093-001-20789}}}In regard to the awakening of those practicing the perfection of wisdom, it says it
“is not to accumulate or to diminish… any dharma.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1206,id:UT23703-093-001-20791}}}Where it says 
“it is not available in the manner of an objective support that has to be accumulated,”
wholesome roots from giving and so on;
{{milestone:{label:5.1207,id:UT23703-093-001-20794}}}“or that has to be diminished,” 
miserliness, immorality and so on; 
{{milestone:{label:5.1208,id:UT23703-093-001-20797}}}“or that has to be decreased,”
the dark side; 
{{milestone:{label:5.1209,id:UT23703-093-001-20799}}}“or that has to be increased,”
the bright side; 
{{milestone:{label:5.1210,id:UT23703-093-001-20801}}}“or that has to be produced,”
the unproduced buddhadharmas;
{{milestone:{label:5.1211,id:UT23703-093-001-20803}}}“or that has to be stopped,”
defilements that have been produced;
{{milestone:{label:5.1212,id:UT23703-093-001-20805}}}“or that has to be defiled,”
during the period with stains;
{{milestone:{label:5.1213,id:UT23703-093-001-20807}}}“or that has to be purified,”
during the period without stains, it says that because awakening is in its basic nature the elimination of all objective supports.
{{milestone:{label:5.1214,id:UT23703-093-001-20809}}}“Practice the perfection of giving in a dualistic way”{{note:{index1732,id:UT23703-093-001-20810}}}
means with apprehended and apprehender as existent things. As it will say immediately after this below, 
“even bodhisattva great beings who have attended on the lord buddhas, have planted wholesome roots, and have been looked after by spiritual friends {{page:{number:520,id:UT23703-093-001-22187,folio:F.261.a}}} will not be able to gain the knowledge of all aspects,”{{note:{index1733,id:UT23703-093-001-20813}}}
because, on account of the power of apprehending things, they do not have skillful means. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1215,id:UT23703-093-001-20815}}}“How will… [they] fully grasp the perfection of giving?”{{note:{index1734,id:UT23703-093-001-20816}}}
He asks this with the thought that “giving gifts, having taken awakening as the object, is labeled the perfection of giving.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1216,id:UT23703-093-001-20818}}}“[They] do not practice the perfection of giving in a dualistic way”
means they do not practice with the idea, “I will do this for awakening,” conceptualizing the two—an apprehended and an apprehender—as existent things.
{{milestone:{label:5.1217,id:UT23703-093-001-20820}}}“Lord, if they do not practice the perfection of giving in a dualistic way”
is asking: if they are not making a dedication to awakening in a dualistic way, how will the wholesome roots grow and flourish?
{{milestone:{label:5.1218,id:UT23703-093-001-20822}}}“Subhūti, those who practice dualistically do not{{note:{index1735,id:UT23703-093-001-20823}}} grow and flourish on wholesome roots”
teaches that just practicing without dualism causes the wholesome roots to grow and flourish, not dualistic practice. This is the practice of the perfection of wisdom without dualism.
{{milestone:{label:5.1219,id:UT23703-093-001-20825}}} Then the practice of the six perfections endowed with skillful means, the practice of the dharmas on the side of awakening, the practice of the buddhadharmas, and the praise of the bodhisattvas who 
“do not move from their intrinsic nature”{{note:{index1736,id:UT23703-093-001-20827}}}
are easy to understand from the scripture itself.{{note:{index1737,id:UT23703-093-001-20829}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1220,id:UT23703-093-001-20830}}} As for the four possibilities in
“can a nonexistent thing fully awaken to a nonexistent thing,”{{note:{index1738,id:UT23703-093-001-20832}}}
and so on, it is not suitable to connect full awakening with those sorts of four possibilities so a scriptural authority for them does not exist. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1221,id:UT23703-093-001-20834}}}“Seeing sameness like this, not like an existent thing and not like a nonexistent thing either, is clear realization.”{{note:{index1739,id:UT23703-093-001-20835}}}
A falsely imagined phenomenon, like something conjured up by magic, is not in the form of an existent thing nor in a totally nonexistent form like a rabbit’s horns. {{page:{number:521,id:UT23703-093-001-22188,folio:F.261.b}}} That sameness that is not an existent thing and not a nonexistent thing is seeing, “is clear realization” of the sameness of an existent thing and nonexistent thing—
“the perfection of wisdom without thought construction.”{{note:{index1740,id:UT23703-093-001-20838}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1222,id:UT23703-093-001-20839}}}“To illustrate, Subhūti, worthy ones… having trained on all the paths”—
having trained on the paths of stream enterer, once-returner, non-returner, and worthy one—
“do indeed enter into the flawlessness that is a perfect state,”
do enter into a worthy one’s state of flawlessness. For the moment, they
“will not reach the result of worthy one in a single instant of the path”
means for as long as they have not finally produced the moment of the path of freedom. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1223,id:UT23703-093-001-20845}}}“Through the wisdom of the unique single instant”—
through the instant of
“the vajropama meditative stabilization.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1224,id:UT23703-093-001-20848}}}“Having beheld all eight levels, pass beyond them with knowledge and seeing,”{{note:{index1741,id:UT23703-093-001-20849}}}
just as explained earlier in the section teaching knowledge of mastery.{{note:{index1742,id:UT23703-093-001-20851}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1225,id:UT23703-093-001-20852}}}“On that bodhisattva great beings should accomplish vocalizations, conventional terms, and sounds,”{{note:{index1743,id:UT23703-093-001-20853}}}
similar to the vocalizations of the various beings. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1226,id:UT23703-093-001-20855}}}“Do not bring about and do not take away any dharma at all”{{note:{index1744,id:UT23703-093-001-20856}}}—
he asks: those dharmas on the side of awakening with no characteristic mark, the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature, do not bring about awakening, do they? And the Lord raises his voice in praise, with
“exactly so, Subhūti, exactly so!”
{{milestone:{label:5.1227,id:UT23703-093-001-20859}}}Nothing at all brings about anything at all, because dharmas are marked by remaining the same. Still, even though that is the case, it formulates this{{note:{index1745,id:UT23703-093-001-20860}}} conventionally, as a method so that simple folk will comprehend, because having understood in this gradual sequence and practiced like that, they become awakened. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1228,id:UT23703-093-001-20861}}}“Noble Dharma and Vinaya”{{note:{index1746,id:UT23703-093-001-20862}}}
teaches that in its intrinsic nature it tames attachment {{page:{number:522,id:UT23703-093-001-22189,folio:F.262.a}}} and so on, and, when it has been achieved, is marked by remaining tamed.{{note:{index1747,id:UT23703-093-001-20864}}} This 
“noble Dharma and Vinaya”
is the
“perfection of wisdom.”{{note:{index1748,id:UT23703-093-001-20868}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1229,id:UT23703-093-001-20869}}}“The disintegration of meditation on all dharmas is meditation”{{note:{index1749,id:UT23703-093-001-20870}}}
means meditating on “all dharmas,” form and so on, as nonexistent things.
{{milestone:{label:5.1230,id:UT23703-093-001-20872}}}“[They] do not meditate on ‘form is an existent thing’ ”{{note:{index1750,id:UT23703-093-001-20873}}}
means they do not meditate on “form is an existent thing in its intrinsic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1231,id:UT23703-093-001-20875}}}“Someone attached to the two extremes, thinking ‘this is me,’ in reference to an existent thing”{{note:{index1751,id:UT23703-093-001-20876}}}—
this means someone attached to the two extremes of permanence and annihilation with the notion of an existent thing: “This is me, which is to say, I exist separately,” “I am form,” “I am feeling,” and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.1232,id:UT23703-093-001-20878}}}“Subhūti, the perception of form is a duality.”{{note:{index1752,id:UT23703-093-001-20879}}}
There is no doubt that where there is the perception “it is form,” the false imagining that it is there or it is not there, or that it is an existent thing or a nonexistent thing, arises. Alternatively, it says “duality” because of a grasped and grasper in the form of existent things.
{{milestone:{label:5.1233,id:UT23703-093-001-20881}}}“To the extent there is an existent thing, to that extent there are volitional factors.”
The conceptualization of an existent thing gives rise to volitional factors that are good, bad, and so on. To “thoroughly reject an existent thing” is not to thoroughly reject the maturation.{{note:{index1753,id:UT23703-093-001-20883}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1234,id:UT23703-093-001-20884}}}“[They] gain control over all dharmas,”{{note:{index1754,id:UT23703-093-001-20885}}}
over perfect, complete awakening;
“[they] gain control over the range of all phenomena,”{{note:{index1755,id:UT23703-093-001-20888}}}
the clairvoyances and the ten controls.{{note:{index1756,id:UT23703-093-001-20890}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1235,id:UT23703-093-001-20891}}}“Here, earlier when I was practicing the bodhisattva’s practice of the six perfections,”
and so on, is teaching the following:
“When I was the one practicing the six perfections and entering into absorption in the clairvoyances and so on, having eliminated perceptions with any objective support, I produced and practiced {{page:{number:523,id:UT23703-093-001-22190,folio:F.262.b}}} a naturally purified perception without relishing the experience of the causal signs. Having fully awakened by just paying attention to space, and, following that, having fully awakened to the four noble truths with subsequent attainment knowledge, I actualized the qualities of a buddha. By paying attention to the conventional I prophesied beings in the three groups.”
This means he was therefore faultless because he practiced in a state where nothing is apprehended and became awakened in a state where nothing is apprehended.
{{milestone:{label:5.1236,id:UT23703-093-001-20895}}} With,
“Lord, how has a tathāgata, worthy one, perfectly complete buddha,”
and so on,{{note:{index1757,id:UT23703-093-001-20898}}} the elder is asking: if concentrations, clairvoyances, and beings are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature, how have you produced them, and prophesied those beings? Then the Lord, with 
“Subhūti, were an intrinsic nature of sense objects or of wrong unwholesome dharmas,”
and so on, teaches that because they are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature everything is established, not otherwise. So, it is because sense objects and wrong unwholesome dharmas are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature that they have been prophesied and the concentrations produced. They
“are not existent things, or nonexistent things, or intrinsically existent things, or dependently existent things”{{note:{index1758,id:UT23703-093-001-20902}}}
is teaching that they are not constituted as falsely imagined existent things, are not totally nonexistent things like a rabbit’s horns, also are not something constituted as its own existent thing, and are also not something constituted as a dependent existent thing. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1237,id:UT23703-093-001-20904}}}“How… will there be serial action, serial training, and serial practice?” {{page:{number:524,id:UT23703-093-001-22191,folio:F.263.a}}}
The intention is that just as apprehending and not apprehending a magically produced illusory elephant and so on happens suddenly, so too the bodhisattvas’ realization that does not apprehend anything happens suddenly; it does not happen gradually. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1238,id:UT23703-093-001-20906}}} With
“Subhūti, here bodhisattva great beings from the very outset have heard from the lord buddhas… that an intrinsic nature… is nonexistent,”
and so on, the Lord explains that bodhisattvas are not vigorously attempting the series of practices for their own benefit; rather, they are gradually making the vigorous attempt so that all beings will come to a gradual understanding, because they are incapable of a sudden understanding. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1239,id:UT23703-093-001-20909}}}“Starting from the first production of the thought,”
 and so on, teaches the order of the unfolding series.
{{milestone:{label:5.1240,id:UT23703-093-001-20911}}}“Having [transcended the śrāvaka level and pratyekabuddha level], they enter,”
after they have produced the thought.{{note:{index1759,id:UT23703-093-001-20913}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1241,id:UT23703-093-001-20914}}}“Do you think you can apprehend a ‘there-is’ or a ‘there-is-not’ in all the phenomena that are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature” {{note:{index1760,id:UT23703-093-001-20915}}}
and that are the intrinsic nature of six perfections?{{note:{index1761,id:UT23703-093-001-20917}}} If taken{{note:{index1762,id:UT23703-093-001-20918}}} as nonexistence, it becomes an annihilation. Those who say they are not existent things, and they are intrinsic natures, say there are not existent things and say there are intrinsic natures, so it is teaching that it is not suitable to take them at the extremes of “there-is” and “there-is-not.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1242,id:UT23703-093-001-20919}}}“Just the absence of an apprehended object is attainment, just the attainment of the absence of an apprehended object is clear realization.”{{note:{index1763,id:UT23703-093-001-20920}}}
If it had said “attainment is without an apprehended object, and clear realization does not apprehend an object,” there would be something to be attained and a clear realization to be had, so there would be the absence of an apprehended object and hence the colossal blunder of apprehending something.{{note:{index1764,id:UT23703-093-001-20922}}} Therefore it teaches that just the absence of an apprehended object is spoken of as “attainment… clear realization,” and 
“unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1243,id:UT23703-093-001-20924}}}“How will there be the clairvoyances arisen from maturation?”{{note:{index1765,id:UT23703-093-001-20925}}}
The clairvoyances arisen from maturation and the perfections arisen from maturation are located from the eighth level on up.
{{milestone:{label:5.1244,id:UT23703-093-001-20927}}} All of the explanation of serial practice is easy to understand.{{note:{index1766,id:UT23703-093-001-20928}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1245,id:UT23703-093-001-20929}}} In regard to the question, {{page:{number:525,id:UT23703-093-001-22192,folio:F.263.b}}}
“Lord, when bodhisattva great beings are practicing the perfection of wisdom, how do they complete the six perfections in a single thought?”{{note:{index1767,id:UT23703-093-001-20931}}}
and so on, it says 
“when they give gifts it is informed by the perfection of wisdom,”
explaining that because they are informed by the perfection of wisdom all beings also become one.
{{milestone:{label:5.1246,id:UT23703-093-001-20935}}}“Nothing other than”{{note:{index1768,id:UT23703-093-001-20936}}}
means simply just the one. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1247,id:UT23703-093-001-20938}}} Then again, in response to the second question,{{note:{index1769,id:UT23703-093-001-20939}}} it explains that it is a single thought because it is not a dualistic thought. The cultivation of all dharmas, the six perfections and so on, while 
“not having a dualistic notion”
is easy to understand. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1248,id:UT23703-093-001-20942}}}“When they give gifts with a thought free from causal signs, without outflows, the perfection of maturation is completed.”{{note:{index1770,id:UT23703-093-001-20943}}}
It teaches that, because from the eighth level on up afflictions do not arise and it is a maturation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1249,id:UT23703-093-001-20945}}}“This gift you have given is worthless”{{note:{index1771,id:UT23703-093-001-20946}}}
is said by the Māra class of gods. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1250,id:UT23703-093-001-20948}}} Then the completion of the six perfections and the maturation of the clairvoyances can be grasped from the text itself. It is also very easy to understand the exposition of the perfections arisen from maturation from the teaching about the knowledge of the mark of all dharmas.{{note:{index1772,id:UT23703-093-001-20949}}}
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-5}}}Explanation of Chapter 73
{{milestone:{label:5.1251,id:UT23703-093-001-20950}}}Then the question,
“Lord, how, when all dharmas are like a dream, have nonexistence for their intrinsic nature, and are empty of their own marks,”
and so on—the response is that the teaching is amazing and marvelous, and the two gifts of Dharma, the ordinary and extraordinary, should be grasped right from the scripture itself.{{note:{index1773,id:UT23703-093-001-20953}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1252,id:UT23703-093-001-20954}}} Among the extraordinary gifts of Dharma, most have already been explained. I will explain the ones I have not explained before. Among them is, 
“What is conflict-free meditative stabilization?”{{note:{index1774,id:UT23703-093-001-20956}}}
Having become absorbed in a meditative stabilization sustained by the power of the thought “may afflictions not arise in others on account of me,” through the force {{page:{number:526,id:UT23703-093-001-22193,folio:F.264.a}}} of the earlier prayer that is a vow that does not provide an opportunity for afflictions to arise in the mindstreams of others, is called “conflict-free absorption.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1253,id:UT23703-093-001-20958}}}“There, what is knowledge from prayer?”
Immediately after a prayer has been made to know some phenomenon included in knowable things—anything at all from the phenomena of the three time periods and three realms included in the ordinary and extraordinary—that knowledge through which it comes to be known is called “knowledge from prayer.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1254,id:UT23703-093-001-20960}}}“There, what are the four total purities?”{{note:{index1775,id:UT23703-093-001-20961}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1255,id:UT23703-093-001-20962}}}The absolute separation from the “basis”—all the final bases of suffering with which all beings are afflicted—and the independence to appropriate, remain in, and die in whatever body one wants is the
“thoroughly purified basis.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1256,id:UT23703-093-001-20964}}}Control gained over what are counted as magical productions and transformations, and over objective supports, is the 
“thoroughly purified objective support.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1257,id:UT23703-093-001-20966}}}The increase of the wholesome in the mind to the fullest extent because of separation from the final basis of mental suffering is the
“thoroughly purified mind.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1258,id:UT23703-093-001-20968}}}Control over the absence of obstructions to the knowledge of all knowable things because of separation from the final basis of suffering that is on the side of ignorance is 
“thoroughly purified knowledge.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1259,id:UT23703-093-001-20970}}} There what are the ten controls? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1260,id:UT23703-093-001-20971}}}“Control over lifespan”
is remaining for as long as they want;
{{milestone:{label:5.1261,id:UT23703-093-001-20973}}}“control over mind”
is the abiding at will in the mental abiding in which they want to abide, in a concentration, an immeasurable, a deliverance, and so on;
{{milestone:{label:5.1262,id:UT23703-093-001-20975}}}“control over necessities”
is being endowed at will with all necessities, food and so on, immediately after just having the idea of them;
{{milestone:{label:5.1263,id:UT23703-093-001-20977}}}“control over action”
is the transformation at will {{page:{number:527,id:UT23703-093-001-22194,folio:F.264.b}}} of all actions that evolve into birth;
{{milestone:{label:5.1264,id:UT23703-093-001-20979}}}“control over birth”
is the birth at will in all birthplaces, in whichever birth they desire;
{{milestone:{label:5.1265,id:UT23703-093-001-20981}}}“control over belief”
is the accomplishing of real things, whatever they are just as they have believed them to be;
{{milestone:{label:5.1266,id:UT23703-093-001-20983}}}“control over prayer”
is this—all their prayers being answered at will;
{{milestone:{label:5.1267,id:UT23703-093-001-20985}}}“control over magical powers”
is the accomplishing of all necessary magical powers at will;
{{milestone:{label:5.1268,id:UT23703-093-001-20987}}}“control over knowledge”
is the speedy knowledge of what they want to know—those very deep things to be known; and
{{milestone:{label:5.1269,id:UT23703-093-001-20989}}}“control over the doctrine”
is the skill at gaining, at will, collections of speech sounds, collections of words, and collections of phrases, and making a perfect presentation of all the doctrine.
{{milestone:{label:5.1270,id:UT23703-093-001-20991}}}“What are the three things the tathāgatas do not have to guard against?”{{note:{index1776,id:UT23703-093-001-20992}}}
The three things they do not have to guard against are easy to understand from the scripture itself.
{{milestone:{label:5.1271,id:UT23703-093-001-20994}}}“[The] three applications of mindfulness”
are easy to understand as the absence of attachment and anger.
{{milestone:{label:5.1272,id:UT23703-093-001-20996}}}“A natural state not robbed of mindfulness”—
in whatever way and at whatever time the tathāgatas work for the welfare of beings, when it is accomplished, at that time it is called the “natural state not robbed of mindfulness.”
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-5-1}}}Major marks and minor signs of a buddha
{{milestone:{label:5.1273,id:UT23703-093-001-20998}}}“What are the thirty-two major marks of a great person?”{{note:{index1777,id:UT23703-093-001-20999}}}
These are presented to engender faith in persons who take the body as the measure of greatness. There, bodhisattva great beings and buddhas are called
“great person”
because of their great humanity on account of great lineage, belief, prayer, vigorous attempt, setting out, practice that accomplishes the final result, wisdom and skillful means, and so on. Because they are great persons, these make that clear so they are the “major marks of a great person.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1274,id:UT23703-093-001-21003}}} Qualm: Well then, {{page:{number:528,id:UT23703-093-001-22195,folio:F.265.a}}} the number “thirty-two” is meaningless because there is no difference between the major or minor parts of their body when appearing as a great person, so it is not appropriate to think “there are this many.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1275,id:UT23703-093-001-21004}}} That is true, but still, the specific number is tailored to the type of experience that follows from studying and being mindful so here too the explanation is with just that number. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1276,id:UT23703-093-001-21005}}} The explanation of these major marks, furthermore, is in four parts: overview, explanation, cause, and result. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1277,id:UT23703-093-001-21006}}} The first is the brief teaching; then, the commentary on the major marks is the explanation, the description of earlier karma the cause, and what they presage is the result. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1278,id:UT23703-093-001-21007}}}“They have wheel marks on the surfaces of their hands and feet.”
Ordinarily a wheel is of two kinds: a wheel that is a weapon and the locomotion wheel, such as a wagon wheel and so on. They occur on both their hands and also their feet. The earlier karma for them is twofold: one, included in the perfection of morality, is listed as having
“welcomed and accompanied gurus.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1279,id:UT23703-093-001-21010}}}This results in the appearance of locomotion wheels on the soles of their feet. The one included in the perfection of giving is having
“listened to the doctrine, strung garlands, visited temples and caityas, and given the gift of servants.”{{note:{index1778,id:UT23703-093-001-21012}}}
This results in their appearance on the palms of both hands.
{{milestone:{label:5.1280,id:UT23703-093-001-21014}}}“Wheels with a thousand spokes, with rims and hubs”—
when these three are not complete it signifies that, having become wheel-turning emperors, they will go forth to homelessness. At that time, they will not become completely awakened, like, for example, King Śaṅka.{{note:{index1779,id:UT23703-093-001-21016}}} When they have become complete in every respect they will become completely awakened, {{page:{number:529,id:UT23703-093-001-22196,folio:F.265.b}}} therefore it says 
“complete in every respect.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1281,id:UT23703-093-001-21018}}} Qualm: Among these, the various other signs taught in other sūtras—the śrīvatsa, svastika, vardhamāna,{{note:{index1780,id:UT23703-093-001-21019}}} full pot, joined fish, victory banner, conch shell, throne, white parasol, fly whisk, and so on—have not been taught, have they? 
 That is true, but still, when it explains the main one—being endowed with the major wheel sign—it indicates those as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1282,id:UT23703-093-001-21022}}}Some say all the major marks that do not appear on the two feet of a tathāgata are not absent because they are included as the necessary insignia of a universal emperor. Hence, it says “complete in every respect.”{{note:{index1781,id:UT23703-093-001-21023}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1283,id:UT23703-093-001-21024}}}“It is a sign presaging an extremely large circle of servants.”
This is shared by wheel-turning emperors and buddhas. Because it has a hub{{note:{index1782,id:UT23703-093-001-21026}}} and spokes, and is held by a rim, it is similar to “an extremely large circle of servants.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1284,id:UT23703-093-001-21027}}}“Feet that are well placed”—
lord buddhas are not like others for whom the ground is uneven, the soles of whose feet are not flat, or who plant the point of the foot or a side of the foot or the heel on the ground when walking, or who bound along taking breaks in the middle.{{note:{index1783,id:UT23703-093-001-21029}}} The whole sole of their foot is flat, lands on the ground when walking, touches the ground evenly, so it is said they have “feet that are well placed.” The entire face of the earth is even and has no change in elevation, no pebbles, boulders, water, mud, thorns, pits and so on, and as rulers over many hundreds and thousands of world systems even the distant is close by. Teaching the earlier karma it says
“their commitment is firm.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1285,id:UT23703-093-001-21031}}}It says this because in regard to all undertakings, on account of the force of the sustaining power of truth, renunciation, peace, and wisdom, {{page:{number:530,id:UT23703-093-001-22197,folio:F.266.a}}} nobody can make them break it. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1286,id:UT23703-093-001-21032}}}“It is a sign presaging that they cannot be swayed.”
They all—Māra, opponents, tīrthikas and so on—cannot sway them.
{{milestone:{label:5.1287,id:UT23703-093-001-21034}}}“Hands and feet with connecting webbing”{{note:{index1784,id:UT23703-093-001-21035}}}—
from the first finger joint there is no gap in between the fingers on hands with totally stunning “connecting webbing,” but still they are suited for slipping on jewelry such as a ring and so on.{{note:{index1785,id:UT23703-093-001-21037}}} And the earlier karma is because of
“their assiduous practice of the four ways of gathering a retinue.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1288,id:UT23703-093-001-21039}}}It is explained that both their hands have “connecting webbing,” because of the force of gathering a retinue 
“by giving”
and so on; and both their feet have “connecting webbing” because of the force of the other three ways—
“consistency between words and deeds,”
and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1289,id:UT23703-093-001-21044}}}Alternatively, they are understood to have come about from two hands gathering a retinue. The beings who have been gathered into the retinue have touched the feet. The appearance of the fingers and toes is with no gaps.
{{milestone:{label:5.1290,id:UT23703-093-001-21045}}}They are like “the four ways of gathering a retinue” because they gather and have become soft. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1291,id:UT23703-093-001-21046}}}“The speedy gathering of a retinue”—
this means the eight retinues{{note:{index1786,id:UT23703-093-001-21048}}} quickly gather for the explanation of the Dharma. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1292,id:UT23703-093-001-21049}}}Someone else explains “hands and feet with connecting webbing” differently. Setting aside the two thumbs on the hands of the lord buddhas, the tips of all the fingers are aligned, that is, the fingers are marked by each being connected with each part, standing aligned like a lattice work window or the tops of columns, so, on all the toes and fingers all the marks of each joint line appear aligned so they appear like a lattice; thus they have “hands and feet with connecting webbing.”{{note:{index1787,id:UT23703-093-001-21050}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1293,id:UT23703-093-001-21051}}}It is said, “When unimportant beings touch the two feet of a tathāgata there is an extremely pleasant feeling, and after death they are born in the ranks of the gods. Such is the power of feet with that major sign—connecting webbing.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1294,id:UT23703-093-001-21052}}}“Delicate and soft feet and hands”— {{page:{number:531,id:UT23703-093-001-22198,folio:F.266.b}}}
because “delicate” means pliable, and “soft”{{note:{index1788,id:UT23703-093-001-21054}}} means having a perfect hue. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1295,id:UT23703-093-001-21055}}}“Stands out prominently in seven ways,”
because they—
“the backs of their hands and upper parts of their feet, shoulders, neck, and head”—
are parts that have filled out. The earlier karma is the
“perfectly prepared hard and soft food and drink.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1296,id:UT23703-093-001-21060}}}From having given what has been perfectly prepared, their hands and feet have become “delicate and soft”; from having given many things to eat, “the parts stand out prominently in seven ways.” Alternatively, they went on their feet and gave with their two hands. Alternatively, their two hands and feet have become like that because, having given with their two hands, beings have served at their feet. “The parts stand out prominently in seven ways” because they are similar to the seven mental constituents{{note:{index1789,id:UT23703-093-001-21061}}} that have been satisfied.
{{milestone:{label:5.1297,id:UT23703-093-001-21062}}} How do you know that one karma gives rise to two major signs? 
The explanation is that even though it is taken as being one karma, it accomplishes two or even three major signs on account of its being done and accumulated to an extreme degree.
{{milestone:{label:5.1298,id:UT23703-093-001-21064}}}“They have long toes and fingers.”
What goes wrong in fingers that are too long, too short, too fat, too thin, and crooked, and so on, has been eliminated. There is nothing wrong with them, and they are in correct proportion relative to the palms of the hands, are of proper length, and are gradually filled out and have slender tips. They are called “long fingers.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1299,id:UT23703-093-001-21066}}}They have 
“stretched-out heels”
because they have heels free from what goes wrong in heels. They are of proper length and in correct proportion {{page:{number:532,id:UT23703-093-001-22199,folio:F.267.a}}} relative to the feet. There, having taken the entire sole of the foot as having four parts, when three parts are the foot and one part is the heel, it is “of proper length.”{{note:{index1790,id:UT23703-093-001-21069}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1300,id:UT23703-093-001-21070}}}They have 
“a big… body”
because they have a perfect build and are tall in height;
“and a straight body,”
because unlike those of other persons they do not bend.
“[It] is not crooked”
anywhere from the shoulders, waist, or knees.{{note:{index1791,id:UT23703-093-001-21077}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1301,id:UT23703-093-001-21078}}}In this “long toes and fingers and stretched-out heels,” the locutions “long” and “stretched-out” are words for proportionate and fitting;{{note:{index1792,id:UT23703-093-001-21079}}} they are not words for very long and very stretched out. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1302,id:UT23703-093-001-21080}}}Also, in regard to the explanation of the earlier karma, 
“because they have freed convicts condemned to death, have sustained life by giving food and drink and so on, and assiduously practiced abstaining from killing”—
having freed those who are going to be killed from having a short life, those humans remain in their ordinary life, they do not suddenly come to live a longer life; and similarly, giving them all that is required for sustaining themselves, they make it so that they do not have a shortened life, but do not suddenly make them have a longer life. Similarly, also, with the toes and fingers and heels here, the “long” is a nontruncated state; it is not additional length. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1303,id:UT23703-093-001-21083}}}“At seven hasta they are elevated in height.”
They are elevated in height relative to an ordinary body. Take this as the measure of an ordinary body. You cannot with certainty take the measure of the body of the Lord because, having looked for the top of the head, it cannot be seen. Because of
“abstaining from killing”
their physical karma is not twisted, similar to “a straight body.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1304,id:UT23703-093-001-21088}}}“Lower legs from the feet up that are not knobby”— 
prominent bones of the knee joints and ankle joints are said to be “knobby.” In others those two bones are big, so the feet and calves are not attractive. Movement is not easy because they are not flexible, so the movement is unattractive. The calves of the Lord are attractive because the joints do not show; they are flexible, so the movement is attractive.
{{milestone:{label:5.1305,id:UT23703-093-001-21090}}} Others say, “The ankle bones of ordinary humans are toward the back of the foot, so their feet look like they have been nailed on. They are not flexible so they cannot be turned freely,{{note:{index1793,id:UT23703-093-001-21091}}} therefore when they move, the soles of the feet do not show.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1306,id:UT23703-093-001-21092}}} The ankle bones of great persons are higher up on the foot.{{note:{index1794,id:UT23703-093-001-21093}}} Also, only the lower parts of their bodies move, the upper parts {{page:{number:533,id:UT23703-093-001-22200,folio:F.267.b}}} do not appear to move. Their feet can be turned easily. When you look from the front, back, right, and left, the soles of the feet appear and the movement is attractive. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1307,id:UT23703-093-001-21094}}}“Body hair that points upward”—
when the hairs on the bodies of great persons grow in the follicles, they grow pointing upward toward the top, like looking upward at a beautiful face. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1308,id:UT23703-093-001-21096}}} Again, just as the earlier karma,
“the wholesome dharmas they have undertaken,”
grow higher and higher, the parts of the legs are higher, and the body hair faces upward. The similarity is in the appearance of height.
{{milestone:{label:5.1309,id:UT23703-093-001-21099}}}“Calves like the aiṇeya antelope”—
those who have calves that are like those of the black antelope are said to have “calves like the aiṇeya antelope.” The calves of ordinary humans have flesh that hangs down{{note:{index1795,id:UT23703-093-001-21101}}} in one part, or they wobble or are too thick or too long or too short. Those of great persons have flesh that is compact, and they taper, are evenly shaped, very spherical, and well built, occupying only the space of eighteen aṅgula.{{note:{index1796,id:UT23703-093-001-21102}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1310,id:UT23703-093-001-21103}}} Again, the earlier karma is
“having shown respect, they have made vocations and branches of knowledge available” 
so those trainees have increased and flourished, and by having made necessary goods available they have become strong. The calves are similar to that because the muscles have developed and have become like the calves of the black antelope.
{{milestone:{label:5.1311,id:UT23703-093-001-21106}}}“It is a sign presaging a speedy grasp of things.”
Those great persons quickly grasp all the buddhas have said, and the tathāgatas also grasp in a single instant the stream of questions of all beings.
{{milestone:{label:5.1312,id:UT23703-093-001-21108}}}“Tubular and long arms”—
“tubular” because they are big, thick arms; “long” because they reach down to their knees. They are long. Again, the earlier karma is similar because they extended their arms out a long way giving gifts to others, and because the doctrine they give is vast. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1313,id:UT23703-093-001-21110}}}“[Their] private parts are hidden in a sheath.”
The “private part” is a secret that is a private part, hence “private part.” About that private part hidden in a sheath, not present before the eyes, it says the “private part {{page:{number:534,id:UT23703-093-001-22201,folio:F.268.a}}} is hidden in a sheath.” It means the private part portion is hidden in the sheath and not present before the eyes, like a golden colored lotus flower hidden in the sheath of the surrounding calyx. Again, the earlier karma is
“[they] reconciled friends and relatives and did not separate”
them and so on. A sheath and a private part are similar in that way. They are similar because on account of something that can be hidden the secret portion was not obvious. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1314,id:UT23703-093-001-21114}}}“A color like gold”—
this teaches that their body is dense, glossy, and has a very clear color. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1315,id:UT23703-093-001-21116}}}“Extremely fine skin”—
this teaches that inner and outer 
“dirt particles”
and stains and so on do not 
“stick to it.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1316,id:UT23703-093-001-21121}}}Here, washing hands and feet and needing to be washed and so on is done by way of conventional designation so those who look after them will get merit, and to fit in at the appropriate times.{{note:{index1797,id:UT23703-093-001-21122}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1317,id:UT23703-093-001-21123}}}“Each strand of body hair grows curling to the right”—
“each strand of body hair” because from their body hair follicle grows just a single strand of body hair; “curling to the right” because they are circular, like an ornamental coiling snake ring, or the circle of a coiling snake, both of which coil to the right. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1318,id:UT23703-093-001-21125}}}“An ūrṇā marks their face.”
When there is a pliable, soft body hair, white in color and glossy, in the spot between the eyebrows, a full hasta or a pair of hasta or three hasta and so on in length when it is stretched out, that, when let go again,{{note:{index1798,id:UT23703-093-001-21127}}} coils to the right with the tip on the upper part, just the measure of an Indian gooseberry fruit,{{note:{index1799,id:UT23703-093-001-21128}}} like an egg-shaped drop of silver, beautifying whatever face it is on, it is said that “an ūrṇā marks their face.” The earlier karma is that
“they have avoided society, and accorded an appropriate status to parents and so on, served them, given them gifts, not displeased them,”{{note:{index1800,id:UT23703-093-001-21130}}}
and so on. That is for both these major marks. On account of that, those strands grow curling to the right and the ūrṇā is long and has an excellent shape. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1319,id:UT23703-093-001-21132}}}“[Their] upper body is like a lion’s.”
Their upper body is like a lion’s upper body so {{page:{number:535,id:UT23703-093-001-22202,folio:F.268.b}}} they have an “upper body like a lion’s.” It says this because their chest is broad and big in size—perfectly broad and big because it is filled out.{{note:{index1801,id:UT23703-093-001-21134}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1320,id:UT23703-093-001-21135}}}“[Their] shoulders are well rounded without an indentation at the throat.”
Put the word “well” together with “rounded.” The “rounded” teaches that the Adam’s apple does not show. This means it is spherical and compact like the neck of a golden pot.{{note:{index1802,id:UT23703-093-001-21137}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1321,id:UT23703-093-001-21138}}} Again, the earlier karma is
“[they] did not speak unkindly,”
similar in style to a lion, the cause of a beautiful throat;
“did not belittle others,”
the cause of the chest being broad like a lion’s; and being
“eloquent and not jarring, and their speech is the same as the roar of a lion,”
