the cause of a beautiful neck.
{{milestone:{label:5.1322,id:UT23703-093-001-21145}}}“The part between the collarbones is filled in”—
the part between the collarbones is expanded and broad. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1323,id:UT23703-093-001-21147}}}“They know tastes as tasty.”
Those who know the tastes of the six tastes{{note:{index1803,id:UT23703-093-001-21149}}} are said to “know tastes as tasty.” In this context, take to “know” as to like, as in “treats like a mother, treats like a father” and so on. Because they enjoy and are satisfied by the tastes, it is said they “know the tastes.” The gullets of great persons have seven thousand receptive tastebuds giving rise to the experience. If they eat even as little as a single tiny sesame seed, it spreads throughout the entire body.{{note:{index1804,id:UT23703-093-001-21150}}} When all tastes are introduced to the mouth they become like the taste of nectar. That is the karma of the major mark. How it is similar to the earlier karma is easy to understand.{{note:{index1805,id:UT23703-093-001-21151}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1324,id:UT23703-093-001-21152}}}“A build like an Indian fig tree”—
some say nya gro means beneath. Take this as the lower part of the body. Take the ro dha as the upper part of the body. Their build is the same. So, when the upper part and the lower part of their body, starting from the waist, are equal in size it is said that they have “a build like an Indian fig tree.”{{note:{index1806,id:UT23703-093-001-21154}}}{{page:{number:536,id:UT23703-093-001-22203,folio:F.269.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1325,id:UT23703-093-001-21155}}} Others say take the nya gro to be from the top of the head down to the feet; take the ro dha as the width; and take the build as the two outstretched arms. So there, when the height and width of their body is the same length of their two outstretched arms, it is said that they have “a build like an Indian fig tree.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1326,id:UT23703-093-001-21156}}} Some say the trunk and branches of an Indian fig tree are equal in height and width. All the bodies of great persons are like that, the same in being the size of two extended arms.
{{milestone:{label:5.1327,id:UT23703-093-001-21157}}}“[They] have an uṣṇīṣa on the top of their head”—
take this as a head like a bound turban.{{note:{index1807,id:UT23703-093-001-21159}}} It is explained that the heads of others are not fully developed, are elongated or squashed and are not symmetrical. The heads of great persons are arranged evenly like a turban, spherical, completed, well shaped, and well developed. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1328,id:UT23703-093-001-21160}}} Others say this major sign is to teach that the forehead is fully developed in size. The flesh in between and above the right ear and the left ear of the foreheads of great persons is well shaped; the size of the forehead is fully completed and beautiful like a royal golden turban that has been bound on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1329,id:UT23703-093-001-21161}}} Again, the earlier karma is that they were 
“first”—
they were chief 
“at doing”
all wholesome actions, making
“parks, assembly halls,”
places to quench thirst and so on—therefore 
“they have a build like a fig tree,” 
and 
“an uṣṇīṣa on the top of their head,”
because, having become chief in the assembly, they raised their head uncowed and fearlessly encouraged others to engage in these actions. Hence,
“these are signs that presage holding the highest office.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1330,id:UT23703-093-001-21173}}}“A long thin tongue”:
“long”—big or lengthy; “thin”—pliable.
{{milestone:{label:5.1331,id:UT23703-093-001-21175}}}“The voice of Brahmā”—
because it is a voice like Brahmā, or the finest voice.
{{milestone:{label:5.1332,id:UT23703-093-001-21177}}}“The call of the kalaviṅka bird”—
like the sound of the Indian cuckoo.
{{milestone:{label:5.1333,id:UT23703-093-001-21180}}}“They have lion-like jaws”
because they are similar in part to the moon on the twelfth day before it is full, and the edges of the jaws are muscled and excellently rounded.{{note:{index1808,id:UT23703-093-001-21182}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1334,id:UT23703-093-001-21183}}}“Very white teeth,”
because they shine; 
“extremely white,”
even more than the planet Venus. {{page:{number:537,id:UT23703-093-001-22204,folio:F.269.b}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1335,id:UT23703-093-001-21187}}}“Even teeth,”
because they 
“are not too long or too short,”
or uneven.
{{milestone:{label:5.1336,id:UT23703-093-001-21191}}}“Teeth without gaps”—
because there are 
“no spaces between their teeth,”
and so on, they are good looking.
{{milestone:{label:5.1337,id:UT23703-093-001-21195}}}“Forty teeth,”
because while other humans have thirty-two or thirty-eight teeth, on the contrary their teeth number forty and are complete.
{{milestone:{label:5.1338,id:UT23703-093-001-21197}}}“Dark blue eyes”—
the globe in the middle of the round of their eyes is moist and black. The two edges of the black globe are white. When the two eyelashes are still, they remain moist and dark blue. The two corners are a little bit redder. In between the eyelashes and eye is like a golden color. Thus, even though they do have the five clarities of sense faculties, still, because the circle of the eye is the foremost, it says “dark blue eyes.”{{note:{index1809,id:UT23703-093-001-21199}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1339,id:UT23703-093-001-21200}}}“[Their] eyelashes are like those of a cow,”
because, like a calf that right from birth has a youth’s eyelashes, the color of 
“the upper and lower eyelashes”
is extremely glossy, and they are
“not entangled, so… [their] eyelashes are like those of a cow.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1340,id:UT23703-093-001-21207}}}“Eighty minor signs”{{note:{index1810,id:UT23703-093-001-21208}}}—
they are called “minor signs”{{note:{index1811,id:UT23703-093-001-21210}}} because they subsequently expand on the major marks or are subsequently divided in conformity with the major marks, that is, they indicate that they are great persons or make them handsome in conformity with the major marks. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1341,id:UT23703-093-001-21211}}}“Lord buddhas have nails with a color like copper”
is an explanation of a minor sign. They
“are isolated from all conditioned things”{{note:{index1812,id:UT23703-093-001-21214}}}
is its corresponding cause. Connect them all like that.
{{milestone:{label:5.1342,id:UT23703-093-001-21216}}}“Bodhisattva great beings gather beings with those six perfections, by kind words.”{{note:{index1813,id:UT23703-093-001-21217}}}
Having brought them into the fold with kind words, they gather them into a retinue with the six perfections, so “kind words” is in the list.{{note:{index1814,id:UT23703-093-001-21219}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1343,id:UT23703-093-001-21220}}}“They have gathered beings… with those same six perfections by… beneficial actions.”{{note:{index1815,id:UT23703-093-001-21221}}}
The aspiration to do something of benefit goes ahead of the six perfections that gather them into a retinue. {{page:{number:538,id:UT23703-093-001-22205,folio:F.270.a}}} Connect the later ones like that as well.{{note:{index1816,id:UT23703-093-001-21223}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1344,id:UT23703-093-001-21224}}}“Become skilled at one syllable accomplishment.”{{note:{index1817,id:UT23703-093-001-21225}}}
Through the sequence of dhāraṇī letters as gateways—“the letter a is the door to all dharmas because they are unproduced from the very beginning,” and so on{{note:{index1818,id:UT23703-093-001-21227}}}—they should, through one letter, become skilled at the accomplishment of the signlessness meditative stabilization.
{{milestone:{label:5.1345,id:UT23703-093-001-21228}}}“Know{{note:{index1819,id:UT23703-093-001-21229}}} through one syllable that all have a decline.”
To have a decline is to decline.{{note:{index1820,id:UT23703-093-001-21231}}} This means compounded phenomena have a complete change. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1346,id:UT23703-093-001-21232}}}“Meditate on forty-five syllables being included in one syllable.”{{note:{index1821,id:UT23703-093-001-21233}}}
Meditate on the meditative stabilizations of all the syllables being included in the a that accomplishes the nonproduction meditative stabilization. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1347,id:UT23703-093-001-21235}}}“Meditate on one syllable being included in forty-five syllables.”
Meditate on the meditative stabilizations of the forty-five syllables being in just the a. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1348,id:UT23703-093-001-21237}}}“All dharmas, Subhūti, being the appearance of that for which there are no letters, are magical creations.”{{note:{index1822,id:UT23703-093-001-21238}}}
This means they are generated as an appearance of the inexpressible dharma-constituent.
{{milestone:{label:5.1349,id:UT23703-093-001-21240}}} With
“how do bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom arisen from maturation,”
and so on,{{note:{index1823,id:UT23703-093-001-21243}}} he is asking: If
“a being… and a dharma… cannot be apprehended,”
which is to say, do not appear when they practice what has arisen from maturation because what has arisen from maturation is an absence of conceptual thinking, how could they give an explanation of the Dharma? How, given that they would be connecting them with dharmas on the side of awakening that do not exist, would they not
“be connecting them with error?”
{{milestone:{label:5.1350,id:UT23703-093-001-21247}}} Having asked that, 
the Lord said, “Exactly so, Subhūti, exactly so!” 
and so on, delighting in those words. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1351,id:UT23703-093-001-21250}}}“Having thus seen that all those dharmas are empty, teach the doctrine to beings,”
and so on,{{note:{index1824,id:UT23703-093-001-21252}}} teaches that although it is true that Subhūti, {{page:{number:539,id:UT23703-093-001-22206,folio:F.270.b}}} beings, and dharmas are empty, still beings do not know them as emptiness. Hence the Lord teaches the doctrine in order that they will know, and when he teaches the doctrine, he teaches the doctrine so that one way or the other it does not disagree with that emptiness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1352,id:UT23703-093-001-21253}}}“They see that all dharmas are without obscurations”
means they see them separated from falsely imagined obscurations, as absolutely pure.
{{milestone:{label:5.1353,id:UT23703-093-001-21255}}} The similarity based on the analogy of a tathāgata’s magical creation has been dealt with already.{{note:{index1825,id:UT23703-093-001-21256}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1354,id:UT23703-093-001-21257}}}“By way of their not being bound and not being freed”{{note:{index1826,id:UT23703-093-001-21258}}}—
during the period when the true dharmic nature of form has stains it is a falsely imagined thing isolated from an intrinsic nature, so it is “not bound”; and even during the period when it is stainless there is no purification plucked out of thin air, so it is “not freed.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1355,id:UT23703-093-001-21260}}}“Form’s state of not being bound and not being freed is not form.”
The “state of not being bound and not being freed” is the thoroughly established state. This means it is not the intrinsic nature of a falsely imagined form.{{note:{index1827,id:UT23703-093-001-21262}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1356,id:UT23703-093-001-21263}}}“Are absolutely pure”—
“in their basic nature” is intended.
{{milestone:{label:5.1357,id:UT23703-093-001-21265}}}“Something nonexistent is not located in something nonexistent,”
because it does not rest on it, just as, to illustrate, space is not located in space. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1358,id:UT23703-093-001-21267}}}“Something’s own existence is not located in something nonexistent,”
because it does not exist, just as, to illustrate, sharpness is not located in a rabbit’s horns and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.1359,id:UT23703-093-001-21269}}}“And something else’s existence is not located in something nonexistent or in something’s own existence,”{{note:{index1828,id:UT23703-093-001-21270}}}
because both something else’s existence and something’s own existence are nonexistent. Connect the others{{note:{index1829,id:UT23703-093-001-21272}}} like that as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1360,id:UT23703-093-001-21273}}}“The lord buddhas, the bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, worthy ones, and all the noble beings understand{{note:{index1830,id:UT23703-093-001-21274}}} just that true dharmic nature of dharmas”
teaches that all have {{page:{number:540,id:UT23703-093-001-22207,folio:F.271.a}}} just the one clear dharma realization. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1361,id:UT23703-093-001-21276}}}“Without going beyond that true dharmic nature of dharmas”—
when giving an exposition of the Dharma they do not go beyond that. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1362,id:UT23703-093-001-21278}}}“Subhūti, the dharma-constituent does not go beyond anything, and suchness and the very limit of reality do not go beyond anything either.”
Take them specifically with their particulars: the lord buddhas’ “dharma-constituent,” which is to say, dharma body, does not go beyond anything; the bodhisattvas’ “suchness” does not go beyond anything; and the śrāvakas’ and pratyekabuddhas’ “very limit of reality” does not go beyond anything.
{{milestone:{label:5.1363,id:UT23703-093-001-21280}}}“Because they have no intrinsic nature that goes beyond anything”
means an intrinsic nature that can be gone beyond does not exist. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1364,id:UT23703-093-001-21282}}}“Lord, if, in the dharma-constituent, there is no going beyond, and in suchness and at the very limit of reality there is no going beyond,”
and so on, poses the following question: Form, feeling, and so on are in their intrinsic nature changeable, so it appears they go beyond something. Thus, there is a going beyond something when it comes to form and so on, but there is none when it comes to the dharma-constituent and so on, so, at that time are form and so on and the dharma-constituent and so on different?
{{milestone:{label:5.1365,id:UT23703-093-001-21284}}}“No, Subhūti,” the Lord replied,
and so on, teaches that the dharmas—form, feeling, and so on—and the three, the dharma-constituent and so on, are not different. The intention of this is that “ultimate form does not go beyond anything.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1366,id:UT23703-093-001-21286}}} Then the elder Subhūti said,
“Lord, if form is not one thing and the dharma-constituent is not another,”
and so on—he asks: if there is no difference between form, feeling, and so on, and the dharma-constituent and so on, well then, will there not be 
“a detailed presentation of the results”
of wholesome and unwholesome actions because {{page:{number:541,id:UT23703-093-001-22208,folio:F.271.b}}} all dharmas will be uncompounded just as the dharma-constituent and so on are? Then the Lord says, 
{{milestone:{label:5.1367,id:UT23703-093-001-21291}}}“Subhūti, … based on conventional truth,”
and so on. This is saying that even though all phenomena are uncompounded in their intrinsic nature, nevertheless for 
“simple… folk,”
who make them into falsely imagined objects, there are falsely imagined wholesome and unwholesome things, and through the force of that there are also bright and bad maturations. The Lord, governed by that, has given an exposition of them by way of their being “conventional truth.” Ultimately all dharmas are the intrinsic nature of suchness, so
“an exposition of a detailed presentation of”
karma and maturation is impossible because ultimately they 
“are undifferentiated”—
those dharmas “are undifferentiated,” are not something that can be expressed, hence they are
“not something that can be talked about,”
and thus
“name and form are not produced and do not stop, are not defiled and not purified.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1368,id:UT23703-093-001-21302}}}From among the formless phenomena and form phenomena, saying “name” and “form” is conventional truth mode. Ultimately that suchness is thoroughly established and hence is undifferentiated. It cannot be expressed, so it is “not something that can be talked about.” It is uncompounded so it is “not produced”; it is not produced so it does “not stop”; it is isolated from an intrinsic nature so it is “not defiled”; and it is pure in its intrinsic nature so it is “not purified.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1369,id:UT23703-093-001-21303}}}“They are an emptiness of what transcends limits and an emptiness of no beginning and no end.”
Those same phenomena, undifferentiated and so on, are talked about as the two emptinesses. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1370,id:UT23703-093-001-21305}}}Subhūti said, “Lord, if the detailed presentation of results is based on conventional truth,” 
and so on. He is asking: if you are going to make a presentation {{page:{number:542,id:UT23703-093-001-22209,folio:F.272.a}}} of results that are unreal why would you not make a presentation of 
“simple, ordinary folk,”
and so on,
“in the result of stream enterer,”
and so on? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1371,id:UT23703-093-001-21311}}}Then the Lord said, “Subhūti, were simple, ordinary folk to know the conventional truth or the ultimate truth,” 
and so on. He is saying that while there is no detailed presentation of results, nevertheless there is a presentation of the falsely imagined result of stream enterer, and so on, because of the comprehension of falsely imagined things. Simple, ordinary folk do not comprehend, therefore they do not cultivate the path. Noble persons do comprehend, therefore just for them there should be a detailed presentation of the path, and what is not the path, and the results.
{{milestone:{label:5.1372,id:UT23703-093-001-21313}}} The elder Subhūti asks,{{note:{index1831,id:UT23703-093-001-21314}}}
“Lord, when they have become habituated to the path”
as cause,
“does the result appear and do they attain the result?”
If it does, it would happen just as an ultimate.
{{milestone:{label:5.1373,id:UT23703-093-001-21319}}} Then the Lord said, 
“No, Subhūti. The result does not appear, and they do not attain the result from having become habituated to the path.”
He has refuted both the path and result because they are falsely imagined phenomena.
{{milestone:{label:5.1374,id:UT23703-093-001-21322}}}“Nor, Subhūti, do they attain the result from having not become habituated to the path.”
This is explaining that they are falsely imagined phenomena, but not arbitrary.
{{milestone:{label:5.1375,id:UT23703-093-001-21324}}}“A result to be attained with the path does not exist, it will not be attained with what is not the path, and it does not exist on the path either”{{note:{index1832,id:UT23703-093-001-21325}}}
teaches the certification of dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1376,id:UT23703-093-001-21327}}}“In the dharma-constituent they do not make a presentation of the results by way of apportioning them.”{{note:{index1833,id:UT23703-093-001-21328}}}
This means that in the dharma-constituent, {{page:{number:543,id:UT23703-093-001-22210,folio:F.272.b}}} having apportioned them like that, there is ultimately no detailed presentation.
{{milestone:{label:5.1377,id:UT23703-093-001-21330}}} With
“Lord, if the compounded element and uncompounded element have not been apportioned,”
and so on, the elder Subhūti asks why, then, has a detailed presentation been given having specified particular abandonments, paths, and results. Then the Lord said,
 “Subhūti, … is the result of stream enterer… compounded or… uncompounded?”{{note:{index1834,id:UT23703-093-001-21334}}}
and so on. Ultimately they have no stages of comprehension and awakening. Thus the “result of stream enterer,” and so on, are uncompounded and in them there is no division into stages. Therefore, given that they are all an awakening to emptiness, none has been apportioned.
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-6}}}Explanation of Chapters 74 to 82
{{milestone:{label:5.1378,id:UT23703-093-001-21336}}}“Lord, how have… they realized well what marks dharmas as dharmas”{{note:{index1835,id:UT23703-093-001-21337}}}
means how have they, if ultimately there is no realization of what has not been apportioned. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1379,id:UT23703-093-001-21339}}}“Lord, how do they meditate on the path of a magical creation?”
is asked using the analogy of a magical creation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1380,id:UT23703-093-001-21341}}}“Subhūti, it is based on meditating on a path,”
and so on, says the achievement is just analogous to a magical creation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1381,id:UT23703-093-001-21343}}}“Lord, how do bodhisattva great beings realize all dharmas that are nonexistent things”
means how, if they are nonexistent, is there a realization? There is no achievement of the realization of a rabbit’s horns and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1382,id:UT23703-093-001-21345}}}“Is there any existent thing apprehended in a tathāgata’s magical creation, thanks to which it is defiled and is purified?”
This teaches that for the tathāgatas there is no defilement and there is no purification. There is no realization because the forms of suffering life and liberation are similar; it is nothing at all because it is simply posited as just nonexistent. {{page:{number:544,id:UT23703-093-001-22211,folio:F.273.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1383,id:UT23703-093-001-21347}}}“Lord, … if the five forms of life in saṃsāra from which beings will be liberated do not exist, how is there going to be a bodhisattva’s personal heroic power?”{{note:{index1836,id:UT23703-093-001-21348}}}
This means that in its basic nature saṃsāra is unreal, so in its intrinsic nature it is liberated. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1384,id:UT23703-093-001-21350}}}Then the Lord said, “What do you think, Subhūti,” 
and so on. Bodhisattvas do not see beings or a cycle of existences. Those analogies of a dream and so on teach that they did see earlier, but beings do not know they are nonexistent, so their “personal heroic power” is causing them to understand.{{note:{index1837,id:UT23703-093-001-21352}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1385,id:UT23703-093-001-21353}}}“Subhūti, if, just on their own, beings knew that all dharmas are like a dream, up to are like a magical creation,”
and so on,{{note:{index1838,id:UT23703-093-001-21355}}} teaches just that. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1386,id:UT23703-093-001-21356}}}“The basic nature of all dharmas is name because they point somewhere.”{{note:{index1839,id:UT23703-093-001-21357}}}
All falsely imagined dharmas with a falsely imagined basic nature are called “name.” Therefore, they point like that to that intellectually active mind of beings, or that basic nature points to that intellectually active mind.{{note:{index1840,id:UT23703-093-001-21359}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1387,id:UT23703-093-001-21360}}} With
“is signlessness one thing and śrāvaka dharmas another?” 
and so on,{{note:{index1841,id:UT23703-093-001-21363}}} the Lord explains that if, given that all dharmas are signless, he had presented śrāvaka dharmas and so on as having signs, then there would be a fault, but because they are all signless there is therefore no fault.
{{milestone:{label:5.1388,id:UT23703-093-001-21364}}}“Does that not complicate the dharma-constituent?”{{note:{index1842,id:UT23703-093-001-21365}}}
This means it would complicate it, because, when they realize defining marks in dharmas that have no defining marks, they would grasp each differently even though they are in fact suchness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1389,id:UT23703-093-001-21367}}}“Subhūti, the dharma-constituent {{page:{number:545,id:UT23703-093-001-22212,folio:F.273.b}}} would be complicated if there were to be any other dharma not included in the dharma-constituent,”
and so on. With this the Lord teaches that even though they conceive of dharmas like that, still, later they realize with wisdom that all are not different because of having the dharma-constituent as their intrinsic nature. Therefore, they do not complicate the dharma-constituent. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1390,id:UT23703-093-001-21369}}}“Subhūti, the form constituent is the dharma-constituent”{{note:{index1843,id:UT23703-093-001-21370}}}
is the suchness of form. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1391,id:UT23703-093-001-21372}}}“Do they train in form?”
Subhūti is asking: since all dharmas are exhausted in the dharma-constituent, the dharmas, form and so on, would be absolutely nonexistent, so, when they train in them would it not be similar to an error? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1392,id:UT23703-093-001-21374}}}“Are aware of all dharmas as they really are, the dharma-constituent,”{{note:{index1844,id:UT23703-093-001-21375}}}
and so on, says: They see the dharmas, form and so on, as just the dharma-constituent, not as something else. They cannot inspire beings to take it up in some other way, so they teach the dharma-constituent with skillful means, having designated form and so on as signlessness. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1393,id:UT23703-093-001-21377}}}“Subhūti, if the dharma-constituent were not exactly the same later as it was before, and if it were not like that in between as well,”{{note:{index1845,id:UT23703-093-001-21378}}}
and so on, is teaching: “before,” at the time of a foolish, ordinary person, the dharma-constituent was impure; “in between,” at the time of a bodhisattva, it is pure and impure; and “later,” at the end, it is absolutely pure. So far so good, but you should not understand from this that there are specific features there. In its intrinsic nature it is pure at all times, pure in its absolutely pure nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1394,id:UT23703-093-001-21380}}}“Subhūti, having taken the very limit of reality as the measure”{{note:{index1846,id:UT23703-093-001-21381}}}
is saying: Bodhisattvas do not practice the perfection of wisdom for the sake of beings, they practice for the sake of the very limit of reality. Thus, having set aside nonexistent beings {{page:{number:546,id:UT23703-093-001-22213,folio:F.274.a}}} because they are not existent, they establish them in the very limit of reality that is their intrinsic nature. The very limit of beings is made into the very limit of reality.
{{milestone:{label:5.1395,id:UT23703-093-001-21383}}}“Lord, if just the very limit of reality is also the limit of beings”
is asking: if a “limit of beings” were not to exist as anything other than the very limit of reality, well then, beings and the very limit of reality would be the same, so what you have said, that they
“establish beings at the very limit of reality” 
would not be right. If they were to establish just that in that, they would be saying “the very limit of reality enters into the very limit of reality,” and that is not right either. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1396,id:UT23703-093-001-21387}}} The Lord says, 
“With skillful means they establish the limit of beings at the very limit of reality without complicating the very limit of reality.”
An intrinsic nature does not enter into an intrinsic nature. Having eliminated a falsely imagined limit of beings and a falsely imagined real basis of beings with skillful means, they establish them in their intrinsic nature, which is absolutely pure suchness, “establishing them at the very limit of reality.” Therefore, this means that the very limit of reality and the limit of beings are an undivided unity, 
“are not two.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1397,id:UT23703-093-001-21391}}} Then he asks,
“What are the skillful means?”{{note:{index1847,id:UT23703-093-001-21393}}}
And 
“Subhūti, here, starting from the first production of the thought, bodhisattva great beings,”
and so on, teaches that having transformed all dharmas into the very limit of reality, the completion of the six perfections is skillful means.
{{milestone:{label:5.1398,id:UT23703-093-001-21397}}} The instruction in the perfections is easy to understand.{{note:{index1848,id:UT23703-093-001-21398}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1399,id:UT23703-093-001-21399}}}“Lord, if all phenomena are empty of a basic nature, and if in the emptiness of a basic nature a being is not apprehended, nor are a dharma and a path apprehended,”
and so on,{{note:{index1849,id:UT23703-093-001-21401}}} asks the following: {{page:{number:547,id:UT23703-093-001-22214,folio:F.274.b}}} if all phenomena are empty of an intrinsic nature and “a being… a dharma, and a path” do not exist,
“how will bodhisattva great beings,” 
having brought beings to maturity, having purified a buddhafield, and having cultivated the knowledge of path aspects,
“stand in the knowledge of all aspects?”
{{milestone:{label:5.1400,id:UT23703-093-001-21405}}} Then the Lord, with
“Subhūti, were all phenomena not empty of a basic nature,”
and so on, teaches that if dharmas or paths were to exist separately, it would be right to apprehend something, and in that case there would be all living beings and so on, and bodhisattvas would not, therefore, having stood in emptiness, become buddhas, and would not explain all dharmas, form and so on, as emptiness. But there are no such dharmas or paths in the emptiness of a basic nature. Therefore, that emptiness is established. Having stood in emptiness they therefore become buddhas and explain all the emptiness dharmas. Hence it is established that they enter into the knowledge of all aspects thanks to the emptiness of a basic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1401,id:UT23703-093-001-21408}}} He continues with
“Subhūti, if inner emptiness were not empty of a basic nature,”
and so on, teaching that not only the trivial dharmas, form and so on, are empty, but that the sixteen emptinesses, inner emptiness and so on, are empty of a basic nature too. Were inner emptiness and so on not empty of a basic nature, the explanation of all dharmas as emptiness would not be well founded. 
{{milestone:{label:5,id:UT23703-093-001-section-5-2-6-1}}}Emptiness of a basic nature
{{milestone:{label:5.1402,id:UT23703-093-001-21411}}}“The emptiness of a basic nature would have been destroyed.”{{note:{index1850,id:UT23703-093-001-21412}}}
If inner emptiness and so on were not also empty of a basic nature, the teaching 
“that ‘all dharmas are empty of a basic nature’ ”
would get damaged, in the sense of being destroyed. Then 
“the emptiness of a basic nature does not perish, is not immovable, and is not nonrecurring”{{note:{index1851,id:UT23703-093-001-21417}}}
teaches {{page:{number:548,id:UT23703-093-001-22215,folio:F.275.a}}} the emptiness that is the mark of the establishment of dharmas. This mark of the establishment of dharmas, furthermore, is taught fourfold:{{note:{index1852,id:UT23703-093-001-21419}}} not perishing and so on; not increasing or decreasing and so on; not being established and not being established after having set out; and not obstructing. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1403,id:UT23703-093-001-21420}}}There, the first of those subsections is: it “does not perish” because it is uncompounded; it “is not immovable” because it is constituted as a nonexistent thing; and it “is not nonrecurring” because it is freedom from forms of life. Then it again teaches these same three in detail with
“it does occupy a location,”{{note:{index1853,id:UT23703-093-001-21422}}}
teaching that it is in an uncompounded state because something compounded occupies a location; it
“does not stand in a place,”
because it is pervaded by a nonexistent thing; and it
“does not come from anywhere and does not go anywhere,” 
because it is freedom from forms of life.
{{milestone:{label:5.1404,id:UT23703-093-001-21428}}}The second subsection on not increasing and so on is as before.{{note:{index1854,id:UT23703-093-001-21429}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1405,id:UT23703-093-001-21430}}}“All dharmas are not established”{{note:{index1855,id:UT23703-093-001-21431}}}
because they are in their intrinsic nature not established, 
“and not established after having set out”
because an escape does not exist. These two teach the investigation of the two—the “established” and the “established after having set out”—in the statement about dharmas other than these two, “established in which bodhisattvas are, after setting out, established in unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.”{{note:{index1856,id:UT23703-093-001-21435}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1406,id:UT23703-093-001-21436}}}“They do not see any dharma at all as obstructing”
as an attachment to emptiness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1407,id:UT23703-093-001-21438}}}“They see all dharmas as not obstructing”
means they see all dharmas are empty. Then, they 
“do not apprehend… a self,”
and so on, teaches
“the emptiness of a basic nature.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1408,id:UT23703-093-001-21443}}}“In that”—
in this emptiness of a basic nature. The “emptiness of a basic nature” {{page:{number:549,id:UT23703-093-001-22216,folio:F.275.b}}} teaches that persons have no self, and dharmas have no self. The illustration of 
“a tathāgata’s… magically created monk or nun”
establishes those two selflessnesses. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1409,id:UT23703-093-001-21447}}}“Just that error is itself not error.”{{note:{index1857,id:UT23703-093-001-21448}}}
Earlier, in the context of the falsely imagined, “just that” foundation “is itself error”; in the context of the thoroughly purified it is “not error.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1410,id:UT23703-093-001-21450}}}“Because of having thought construction as cause”{{note:{index1858,id:UT23703-093-001-21451}}}—
it has in mind a falsely imagined result. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1411,id:UT23703-093-001-21453}}}“They, furthermore, are not exactly like the ultimate there” 
means 
“the applications of mindfulness,”
and so on, are falsely imagined, they are not the ultimate. That emptiness of a basic nature is also called “perfection.”{{note:{index1859,id:UT23703-093-001-21457}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1412,id:UT23703-093-001-21458}}}“That emptiness of a basic nature, furthermore, is the emptiness of a basic nature at the prior limit,”{{note:{index1860,id:UT23703-093-001-21459}}}
and so on, teaches it is emptiness at all three times. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1413,id:UT23703-093-001-21461}}}“Thus, it is amazing how they practice all dharmas that are the emptiness of a basic nature without complicating the emptiness of a basic nature.”{{note:{index1861,id:UT23703-093-001-21462}}}
The idea is that engaging with dharmas that do not exist would complicate emptiness. So, he says
“form is not one thing and the emptiness of a basic nature another.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1414,id:UT23703-093-001-21465}}}Thus, it is saying “it is amazing” how when bodhisattvas engage with phenomena, they see that form and so on “is not one thing and the emptiness of a basic nature another,” that just those, form and so on, are the emptiness of a basic nature.
“Fully awaken to form itself as the knower of all aspects”—
this means fully awakening to the dharmas, form and so on, at the time of the knowledge of all aspects because there is no difference between them. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1415,id:UT23703-093-001-21468}}}“On the contrary, the world together with the gods, together with Māra, together with Brahmā”{{note:{index1862,id:UT23703-093-001-21469}}}— 
“on the contrary,” {{page:{number:550,id:UT23703-093-001-22217,folio:F.276.a}}} they do not know that form and so on are only one. It means ordinary beings 
“do not know”
as they really are that form and so on are only one, and
“on account of not knowing,”
they
“settle down on”
them and accumulate karma, grasp hold of and
“appropriate form,”
and so on, that are its maturation. On account of that they come into suffering existence caused by appropriation, and 
“are not liberated from”
suffering. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1416,id:UT23703-093-001-21481}}}“…the emptiness of a basic nature … [they] do not complicate form with ‘it is empty, or it is not empty.’ ”{{note:{index1863,id:UT23703-093-001-21482}}}
Form does not make emptiness complicated on account of the perception of duality, because there is no duality. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1417,id:UT23703-093-001-21484}}}“It is because the ‘this is form,’ and ‘this is emptiness’… that might make that sort of complication have no intrinsic existence”{{note:{index1864,id:UT23703-093-001-21485}}}—
no intrinsic existence that constitutes an existent thing.
{{milestone:{label:5.1418,id:UT23703-093-001-21487}}}“Bodhisattva great beings do not practice awakening and form within having made a division.”{{note:{index1865,id:UT23703-093-001-21488}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1419,id:UT23703-093-001-21489}}}“They do not practice form having made a division in awakening.”
This means they do not engage with form having made a division into the bodhisattva and the awakening in “bodhisattvas practice awakening.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1420,id:UT23703-093-001-21491}}}“Subhūti, bodhisattva great beings do not think, ‘I am practicing awakening and form.’ ”
They do not, making a division, engage with form, thinking, “I am practicing awakening.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1421,id:UT23703-093-001-21493}}}“A practice of taking anything up”{{note:{index1866,id:UT23703-093-001-21494}}}— 
engaging with a causal sign. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1422,id:UT23703-093-001-21496}}}“Stand in the basic nature of form”{{note:{index1867,id:UT23703-093-001-21497}}}—
stand in the emptiness of form.
{{milestone:{label:5.1423,id:UT23703-093-001-21499}}}“Moreover, … simply based on… labeled by way of ordinary convention”{{note:{index1868,id:UT23703-093-001-21500}}}
teaches that ultimately even unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening does not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5.1424,id:UT23703-093-001-21502}}} When they practice just those dharmas it means they practice just those, giving and so on,
“without apprehending giving, … a benefactor,”{{note:{index1869,id:UT23703-093-001-21504}}}
and so on.
{{milestone:{label:5.1425,id:UT23703-093-001-21506}}}“Lord, how, when bodhisattva great beings are practicing the perfection of wisdom, {{page:{number:551,id:UT23703-093-001-22218,folio:F.276.b}}} do they make an effort at the awakening path?” {{note:{index1870,id:UT23703-093-001-21507}}}
How, if all the awakening path does not exist, is the idea.
{{milestone:{label:5.1426,id:UT23703-093-001-21509}}}“[They] do not disengage from form,”
because form and so on do not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5.1427,id:UT23703-093-001-21511}}}“How will the perfection of wisdom… be accomplished”{{note:{index1871,id:UT23703-093-001-21512}}}
given that it does not exist?
{{milestone:{label:5.1428,id:UT23703-093-001-21514}}} The explanations of skillful means and of the perfection of wisdom that cannot be grasped are easy to understand.{{note:{index1872,id:UT23703-093-001-21515}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1429,id:UT23703-093-001-21516}}} The question,
“Has there been or will there be a real basis of form in the way a foolish ordinary person has settled down on it?”{{note:{index1873,id:UT23703-093-001-21518}}}
is a statement about the three times.
{{milestone:{label:5.1430,id:UT23703-093-001-21520}}}“If something that really existed was there before”{{note:{index1874,id:UT23703-093-001-21521}}}—
this means that if they were to grasp all those they grasped as there before as not there later, 
“there would be the fault.”{{note:{index1875,id:UT23703-093-001-21524}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1431,id:UT23703-093-001-21525}}}“Lord, what is the bodhisattva great beings’ path?”{{note:{index1876,id:UT23703-093-001-21526}}}
is a question about the path that comprises bringing beings to maturity and purifying a buddhafield. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1432,id:UT23703-093-001-21528}}} Then the explanation of the six perfections, the explanation of the path, the explanation of the training in all dharmas, and the explanation of no location can be grasped from a close reading of the scripture.{{note:{index1877,id:UT23703-093-001-21529}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1433,id:UT23703-093-001-21530}}}“Lord, if all dharmas are unproduced, well then, Lord, how will bodhisattva great beings produce a path to awakening?”{{note:{index1878,id:UT23703-093-001-21531}}}
This intends that the statement “they should produce the unproduced” is not logical. With,
{{milestone:{label:5.1434,id:UT23703-093-001-21533}}}“All dharmas have not been produced. How so? All dharmas have not been produced for those who do not occasion anything,”{{note:{index1879,id:UT23703-093-001-21534}}}
it says that all dharmas have not been produced just for those abiding in nonconceptual meditative stabilization who do not occasion anything good or bad and so on, but they are indeed produced for those foolish, noncomprehending ordinary people who do occasion things. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1435,id:UT23703-093-001-21536}}} With
“Lord, {{page:{number:552,id:UT23703-093-001-22219,folio:F.277.a}}} whether the tathāgatas arise or whether the tathāgatas do not arise,”
and so on,{{note:{index1880,id:UT23703-093-001-21539}}} the elder asks how, if the true nature of dharmas is at all times marked as completely unmistaken, could it be logical that it comes to possess the attribute of production for ordinary beings and does not come to do so for the learned? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1436,id:UT23703-093-001-21540}}}Having said that, the Lord said, “Exactly so, Subhūti,”
and so on. He is teaching that in the true nature of dharmas there is never any mistake, but, because of the fault of not comprehending, foolish ordinary people say of falsely imagined phenomena that “they are produced.” He intends to say that production is just of falsely imagined phenomena from falsely imagined phenomena. He does not intend that it is from the true nature of dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1437,id:UT23703-093-001-21542}}}Having said that, the elder Subhūti said,
 “Lord, do they reach awakening on that path that has been produced?”
and so on, is an inquiry about the production and nonproduction of dharmas without outflows. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1438,id:UT23703-093-001-21546}}}“Just awakening is the path, and just the path is awakening.”
The Lord is saying there is no difference between the path and awakening because both are divisions of the pure dharma-constituent, but still, during the earlier time period it is called “path” because it is the cause, and during the later time period it is called “awakening.” He is explaining that ultimately, because those two are not different, it is not suitable to say “they reach awakening on the path” or “they reach it without a path.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1439,id:UT23703-093-001-21548}}} With
“Lord, if just awakening is the path, and just the path is awakening,”
and so on, the elder asks: if the path and awakening are not different, in that case bodhisattvas who have reached the path will have reached awakening, in which case bodhisattvas will have obtained {{page:{number:553,id:UT23703-093-001-22220,folio:F.277.b}}} all the buddhadharmas included in the form body and included in the dharma body. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1440,id:UT23703-093-001-21551}}}Having asked that, the Lord,
who does not accept the statement that “a buddha reaches awakening,” 
asked him in return, “Subhūti, what do you think, does a buddha reach awakening?”
and so on. He is saying that what he said is not right because a buddha and awakening are not different. He is teaching that just as that statement is not right, similarly what he said about “bodhisattvas reaching awakening” is not right either. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1441,id:UT23703-093-001-21555}}} Then, accepting that even though a bodhisattva and awakening are not different, still, that bodhisattvas reach awakening exists as a conventional designation, with
“Subhūti, here bodhisattva great beings, having completed the six perfections,”
and so on, he teaches the steps for reaching awakening. Hence, without totally rejecting such falsely imagined steps as those, he is explaining that they will reach awakening, but not attain it immediately. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1442,id:UT23703-093-001-21558}}} Then the question about how they will 
“purify a buddhafield”
and the parts to that are easy to understand.{{note:{index1881,id:UT23703-093-001-21561}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1443,id:UT23703-093-001-21562}}}“Lord, are bodhisattva great beings ‘destined’ or rather ‘not necessarily destined’?”{{note:{index1882,id:UT23703-093-001-21563}}}
is asking whether bodhisattvas are so called when “destined,” or rather bodhisattvas are so called also when “not necessarily destined”;
“the śrāvaka group or the pratyekabuddha group”
is asking are bodhisattvas so called when destined to be śrāvakas or when destined to be pratyekabuddhas.
{{milestone:{label:5.1444,id:UT23703-093-001-21567}}}“He intentionally, with skillful means, appropriated whatever sort of body would be of benefit to beings.”{{note:{index1883,id:UT23703-093-001-21568}}}
He took birth by obtaining control over birth, not as something unwanted, under the control of karma. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1445,id:UT23703-093-001-21570}}}“Through a noble action without outflows, do they… take birth in terrible forms of life or…”{{note:{index1884,id:UT23703-093-001-21571}}}—
from the eighth level {{page:{number:554,id:UT23703-093-001-22221,folio:F.278.a}}} all their actions are noble, without outflows.{{note:{index1885,id:UT23703-093-001-21573}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1446,id:UT23703-093-001-21574}}}“But they have no contact with them at all”{{note:{index1886,id:UT23703-093-001-21575}}}— 
with the contact of existence,{{note:{index1887,id:UT23703-093-001-21577}}} or the contact of looking, or the contact of conceptualizing.
{{milestone:{label:5.1447,id:UT23703-093-001-21578}}} Subhūti asks,
“How could all dharmas be included in the perfection of wisdom?”{{note:{index1888,id:UT23703-093-001-21580}}}
having found unbearable the statement that all dharmas are included because the perfection of wisdom is empty of an intrinsic nature. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1448,id:UT23703-093-001-21582}}} With
“Subhūti, … all dharmas are empty of all dharmas, are they not?”
and so on, the Lord explains that it does not make sense that when the perfection of wisdom does not exist then other dharmas exist, and when dharmas other than it do not exist the perfection of wisdom exists. It therefore makes sense that they are all empty and included because they have emptiness as a defining mark.
{{milestone:{label:5.1449,id:UT23703-093-001-21585}}}“Lord, how do [they]… standing in the emptiness of all dharmas find and produce within themselves the perfection of clairvoyance”
is asking how, if they are empty, is it established that they find and produce within themselves the clairvoyances that bring beings to maturity?
{{milestone:{label:5.1450,id:UT23703-093-001-21587}}} In order to teach that they find and produce them within themselves through the gateway of emptiness, with
the Lord said, “Subhūti, here bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom see all those world systems,”{{note:{index1889,id:UT23703-093-001-21589}}}
and so on, it teaches the different clairvoyances, explains the dharmas that are 
“branches of… awakening,”{{note:{index1890,id:UT23703-093-001-21592}}}
teaches the different persons, asks about freeing beings, responds, and explains that security is close by. These are easy to understand.{{note:{index1891,id:UT23703-093-001-21594}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1451,id:UT23703-093-001-21595}}}“Lord, will beings pass into complete nirvāṇa on account of knowing suffering or will they pass into complete nirvāṇa on account of suffering?”{{note:{index1892,id:UT23703-093-001-21596}}}
This question intends that were they to pass into nirvāṇa on account of suffering and its origination and so on, all foolish, ordinary persons would also pass into nirvāṇa because they have {{page:{number:555,id:UT23703-093-001-22222,folio:F.278.b}}} suffering and the origination and so on; but if they pass into nirvāṇa on account of knowing suffering and knowing its origination and so on, in that case, like śrāvakas, they will have reached the result of stream enterer and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1452,id:UT23703-093-001-21598}}} Then the Lord teaches that they do not pass into nirvāṇa in either way, but rather pass into nirvāṇa on account of the realization of
“the sameness”{{note:{index1893,id:UT23703-093-001-21600}}}
called suchness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1453,id:UT23703-093-001-21602}}}“Those dharmas included in the truths or not included in the truths”{{note:{index1894,id:UT23703-093-001-21603}}}—
the inner aggregates are those “included in the truths,” the external ones are “not included in the truths.”{{note:{index1895,id:UT23703-093-001-21605}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1454,id:UT23703-093-001-21606}}}“Subhūti, such a dharma as that, which bodhisattva great beings see, does not exist.”{{note:{index1896,id:UT23703-093-001-21607}}}
All phenomena do not exist just in their thoroughly established state.
{{milestone:{label:5.1455,id:UT23703-093-001-21609}}}“Those bodhisattvas standing at the Gotra level do not fall onto a peak”{{note:{index1897,id:UT23703-093-001-21610}}}
means there they do not entertain the craving that causes acting on the desire for the śrāvaka dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1456,id:UT23703-093-001-21612}}}“Even though they comprehend suffering, they do not produce any thought with suffering as its objective support”{{note:{index1898,id:UT23703-093-001-21613}}}
means they only master it with the knowledge of thorough mastery in the way explained before.{{note:{index1899,id:UT23703-093-001-21615}}} They do not actualize it with those sixteen mental states knowing impermanence and so on because they fear falling to the śrāvaka level after having done so. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1457,id:UT23703-093-001-21616}}}“Awakening is a nonexistent thing.”{{note:{index1900,id:UT23703-093-001-21617}}}
“Existent things” are compounded and uncompounded, constructed and unconstructed phenomena. Because it is separated from their intrinsic nature, the inexpressible ultimately abiding awakening is called “a nonexistent thing.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1458,id:UT23703-093-001-21619}}} Then again, with
“unlettered,{{note:{index1901,id:UT23703-093-001-21621}}} foolish, ordinary people,”
and so on,{{note:{index1902,id:UT23703-093-001-21623}}} it teaches that the dharmas of the three realms are just falsely imagined. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1459,id:UT23703-093-001-21624}}}“That which is not real is just not real”{{note:{index1903,id:UT23703-093-001-21625}}}
means because it is falsely imagined it is simply unreal in itself. {{page:{number:556,id:UT23703-093-001-22223,folio:F.279.a}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1460,id:UT23703-093-001-21627}}}“The path is a nonexistent thing, the result of stream enterer is a nonexistent thing,”{{note:{index1904,id:UT23703-093-001-21628}}}
and so on, teaches there is no “listening”{{note:{index1905,id:UT23703-093-001-21630}}} at all because they are in their intrinsic nature nonexistent things.
{{milestone:{label:5.1461,id:UT23703-093-001-21631}}}“Lord, is there some real basis called suchness and unmistaken suchness, that was or is,”{{note:{index1906,id:UT23703-093-001-21632}}}
and so on, is asking: does a past, or future, or present intrinsic nature of “suchness” or intrinsic nature of “unmistaken suchness” that is a compounded phenomenon ultimately exist at all? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1462,id:UT23703-093-001-21634}}} The six analogies, 
“like a dream”
and so on, are easy to understand.{{note:{index1907,id:UT23703-093-001-21637}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1463,id:UT23703-093-001-21638}}}“Subhūti, … what do you think, those dharmas… are like an illusion, like a dream, … are they not?”{{note:{index1908,id:UT23703-093-001-21639}}}
and so on teaches the perfection of giving and so on, ending with all those dharmas spoken by
“Brahmā’s melodious voice”
are like an illusion. So, since all are like an illusion there is no fault. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1464,id:UT23703-093-001-21643}}}“Subhūti, it is because all these dharmas have been brought into being and are the outcome of intentions”{{note:{index1909,id:UT23703-093-001-21644}}}
is teaching that the perfection of giving and so on are constituted out of virtue so they have been brought into being. Because they are preceded by an intention, they are the outcome of intention, so they are falsely imagined phenomena.
{{milestone:{label:5.1465,id:UT23703-093-001-21646}}}“But still, Subhūti, all those dharmas establish the path and bring about the path, even though they do not cause a result to be obtained”
is teaching that all the dharmas, the perfection of giving and so on, cause a purification of the foundation, and when they cause a purification of the foundation the continuum of the path comes into being.{{note:{index1910,id:UT23703-093-001-21648}}} Those nonexistent things constituted out of what is not produced and does not stop do not cause a result to be obtained, but they are marked by an unfabricated nature—the foundation.
{{milestone:{label:5.1466,id:UT23703-093-001-21649}}}“The perfection of giving cannot be grasped.”{{note:{index1911,id:UT23703-093-001-21650}}}
It is not appropriate to grasp it as an existent thing or as a nonexistent thing.
{{milestone:{label:5.1467,id:UT23703-093-001-21652}}}“Subhūti, {{page:{number:557,id:UT23703-093-001-22224,folio:F.279.b}}} there is no clear realization dualistically and there is no clear realization nondualistically either.”{{note:{index1912,id:UT23703-093-001-21653}}}
This is teaching: If any compounded or uncompounded existent thing were to be seen, there would be a “clear realization dualistically.” And even if it were an absolutely nonexistent thing, like a rabbit’s horns and so on, there would be a “clear realization nondualistically.” The reverse from both of those is therefore the realization of sameness called 
“clear realization.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1468,id:UT23703-093-001-21656}}}“Is inexpressible”{{note:{index1913,id:UT23703-093-001-21657}}}
is not something that can be expressed is not something that can be discussed, or that can be explained, so, “Subhūti, take it as an ordinary convention.”{{note:{index1914,id:UT23703-093-001-21659}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1469,id:UT23703-093-001-21660}}}“Is the dharma a tathāgata has fully awakened to…”{{note:{index1915,id:UT23703-093-001-21661}}}
is teaching that the absolutely final transformation of the basis where conceptualization and thought construction have been eliminated remains a sameness, so a knowable state does not exist and an object that will become knowable is not seen, so what will be fully awakened to? 
{{milestone:{label:5.1470,id:UT23703-093-001-21663}}}“Lord, given that dharmas are the nonexistence of an intrinsic nature, what is this ‘sameness of dharmas’?”{{note:{index1916,id:UT23703-093-001-21664}}}
The intention is: were dharmas to exist there would also be a “sameness.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1471,id:UT23703-093-001-21666}}}“Subhūti, here just that is the sameness of dharmas.”{{note:{index1917,id:UT23703-093-001-21667}}}
This is saying the sameness of dharmas that is the intrinsic nature of nonexistent things is the intrinsic nature of nonexistent things because even the conceptualization of it as an existent thing has also been eliminated.{{note:{index1918,id:UT23703-093-001-21669}}}
{{milestone:{label:5.1472,id:UT23703-093-001-21670}}}“Subhūti, that sameness of dharmas is not within the range of… even tathāgatas.”
The sameness of dharmas is not within the range of anyone. Even the tathāgatas do not see an intrinsic nature of the sameness of dharmas. “The sameness of foolish ordinary people,” of all noble beings, and “of tathāgatas is the same.”
{{milestone:{label:5.1473,id:UT23703-093-001-21672}}}“Makes a presentation of dharmas without moving from the sameness of dharmas”{{note:{index1919,id:UT23703-093-001-21673}}}— {{page:{number:558,id:UT23703-093-001-22225,folio:F.280.a}}}
as an ultimate truth they do not move; but conventionally they make a presentation. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1474,id:UT23703-093-001-21675}}}“Lord, is that true nature of dharmas a compounded phenomenon or is it an uncompounded phenomenon?”{{note:{index1920,id:UT23703-093-001-21676}}}
What does this intend? He is asking with the thought that if that true dharmic nature of these dharmas, form and so on, is an uncompounded phenomenon, then it will not be the true dharmic nature of form and so on that are compounded phenomena; and if it is a compounded phenomenon, then it, like that form and so on, will be falsely imagined, because it will be subject to production and stopping. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1475,id:UT23703-093-001-21678}}}The Lord said, “Subhūti, it is not a compounded phenomenon and it is not an uncompounded phenomenon either.”
He eliminates them both because both are open to criticism. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1476,id:UT23703-093-001-21680}}}“An uncompounded phenomenon other than a compounded phenomenon cannot be apprehended, and a compounded phenomenon other than an uncompounded phenomenon cannot be apprehended either.”
Here the impure suchness of the aggregates, constituents, sense fields and so on cannot be apprehended as something aside from the aggregates and so on, and the aggregates and so on cannot be apprehended as something other than suchness either, so it is inappropriate to say about that impure suchness that it is exactly the same as or different from them.
{{milestone:{label:5.1477,id:UT23703-093-001-21682}}}Thus, neither can be apprehended as other than the other. It is therefore not appropriate to say “they are both the same,” so they
“are not conjoined”;
{{milestone:{label:5.1478,id:UT23703-093-001-21684}}}it is not appropriate to say “they are different,” so they
“are not disjoined”;
{{milestone:{label:5.1479,id:UT23703-093-001-21686}}}they have no form and are without conceptualization, so they
“are formless”;
{{milestone:{label:5.1480,id:UT23703-093-001-21688}}}words and so on cannot explain them, so they
“cannot be pointed out”;
{{milestone:{label:5.1481,id:UT23703-093-001-21690}}}they do not obstruct as do objects of the senses, and grasped and grasper are nonexistent, so they
“do not obstruct”;
{{milestone:{label:5.1482,id:UT23703-093-001-21692}}}and both have no defining mark. They have only a single mark, therefore they
“have only one mark—that is, no mark.”
Here a compounded phenomenon is unreal so “it has no mark.” An uncompounded phenomenon, as signlessness, {{page:{number:559,id:UT23703-093-001-22226,folio:F.280.b}}} cannot be grasped as a causal sign so “it has no mark.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1483,id:UT23703-093-001-21695}}}“A tathāgata employs this language according to ordinary convention.”
Even though compounded phenomena are not real they are designated by ordinary conventional designations. The uncompounded is inexpressible but can be talked about conventionally. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1484,id:UT23703-093-001-21697}}} Having said that, with 
“in the ultimate there is no physical volitional factor, no verbal volitional factor, and no mental volitional factor,”
it explains that those designations are not real because all three types of karma are also falsely imagined phenomena. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1485,id:UT23703-093-001-21700}}}“Subhūti, emptiness is not anything at all, there is nothing at all.”{{note:{index1921,id:UT23703-093-001-21701}}}
Because it does not do anything at all, it is “not anything at all”; because it is the intrinsic nature of a nonexistent thing, “there is nothing at all.” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1486,id:UT23703-093-001-21704}}}“This is not what makes a tathāgata the bull that leads the herd.”{{note:{index1922,id:UT23703-093-001-21705}}}
This is teaching that the work of a tathāgata is simply just mere representation.{{note:{index1923,id:UT23703-093-001-21707}}} Were these beings to understand by themselves there would be no need{{note:{index1924,id:UT23703-093-001-21708}}} for a tathāgata. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1487,id:UT23703-093-001-21709}}}“Lord, why is it empty?”{{note:{index1925,id:UT23703-093-001-21710}}}
This means “empty through the nonexistence of what?” 
{{milestone:{label:5.1488,id:UT23703-093-001-21712}}}“Whatever the perception of it, it is empty of that.”{{note:{index1926,id:UT23703-093-001-21713}}}
A perception that in its nature grasps a causal sign of any “compounded phenomenon” does not exist, so it is empty of it. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1489,id:UT23703-093-001-21715}}}“Subhūti, when someone magically creates a magical creation,”{{note:{index1927,id:UT23703-093-001-21716}}}
and this magical creation 
“magically creates other magical creations”
there,
“is there any real thing there that is not empty?”
This is saying that when one magical creation magically creates another magical creation, is there any entity there that is not empty?
{{milestone:{label:5.1490,id:UT23703-093-001-21722}}}“Subhūti, what do you think, is it concealed…”{{note:{index1928,id:UT23703-093-001-21723}}}
means has 
“ ‘this is a magical creation; this is an emptiness’ ”
been made obscure by emptiness?
{{milestone:{label:5.1491,id:UT23703-093-001-21727}}} The four statements,{{note:{index1929,id:UT23703-093-001-21728}}}
“some are magically created by śrāvakas,”
and so on, teach the ordinary applications of mindfulness, and so on, and the extraordinary dharmas— {{page:{number:560,id:UT23703-093-001-22227,folio:F.281.a}}}
“some are magically created by afflictive emotions”
teaches sentient beings, living beings, and so on; 
“and some are magically created by actions”
teaches the aggregates, constituents, sense fields, and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1492,id:UT23703-093-001-21735}}}“Be it a production or cessation”{{note:{index1930,id:UT23703-093-001-21736}}}
means the compounded dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1493,id:UT23703-093-001-21738}}}“It is nirvāṇa—that which has the quality of not coaxing you into believing it is true.”
In regard to “nirvāṇa,” it is said it is “that which has the quality of not coaxing you into believing it is true” because an attribute that can deceive you, or that needs to be taken away, or that needs to weaken, or that needs to be added does not exist.
{{milestone:{label:5.1494,id:UT23703-093-001-21740}}}“According to what you have said, Lord, that ‘not moving from emptiness and not stained by duality either…’ ”{{note:{index1931,id:UT23703-093-001-21741}}}
This is saying that since you have said “nirvāṇa does not move from emptiness,” therefore you are saying that emptiness does not move but dharmas other than it do move. Since you have said “it is not stained by duality either,” you are teaching that it is not stained by either existence or nonexistence. In regard to that, if any dharma called “nirvāṇa” exists, something else, setting aside emptiness, would exist, and by existing there would still be a stain. Therefore, having worked on that statement, you must be saying that nirvāṇa is a magical creation as well. 
{{milestone:{label:5.1495,id:UT23703-093-001-21743}}} Then, with
“exactly so, Subhūti, exactly so!”
the Lord teaches that a different dharma called “nirvāṇa” that is constituted as an existent thing does not exist at all, so it too is emptiness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1496,id:UT23703-093-001-21746}}}“Lord, … a person who is beginning the work… how should they be advised?”{{note:{index1932,id:UT23703-093-001-21747}}}
He is asking for advice to be able to comprehend such a deep intrinsic nature, emptiness.
{{milestone:{label:5.1497,id:UT23703-093-001-21749}}}The Lord again says that if
“a thing that really existed before”
through the power of the understanding of yogic practitioners
“becomes a thing that does not exist later”
on account of an emptiness of its intrinsic nature, in that case a person who is beginning the work would be undertaking a difficult practice. But 
“there is no existent thing”
falsely imagined as constituted by an existent thing, 
“nor a nonexistent thing” {{page:{number:561,id:UT23703-093-001-22228,folio:F.281.b}}}
like a rabbit’s horns, and
“there is not something’s own existence”—
anything under its own power— 
“nor any existence from something else”—
anything through the power of cause and conditions—
“so how will there ever be”
some other dharma called “an intrinsic nature?” Therefore, there is no fault because they understand even the emptiness of an intrinsic nature is of “something’s own existence.” 
{{milestone:{label:6,id:UT23703-093-001-section-6}}}Explanation of the Maitreya Chapter: Chapter 83
{{milestone:{label:6.1,id:UT23703-093-001-17691}}} Having thus finished explaining Her Ladyship the One Hundred Thousand, I will now explain what is in the Twenty-Five Thousand.{{note:{index1933,id:UT23703-093-001-17692}}}
{{milestone:{label:6.2,id:UT23703-093-001-17693}}} Then, for the sake of future living beings and for the sake of those gathered in the retinue at that time, the noble 
Maitreya asked… “Lord, how do bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom who want to train in a bodhisattva’s training train in form?”
{{milestone:{label:6.3,id:UT23703-093-001-17695}}}A bodhisattva’s training is in the correct comprehension of all dharmas, so he asks, “how do bodhisattvas who want to train in a bodhisattva’s training train in form,” and so on, up to, finally, 
“the buddhadharmas.”
{{milestone:{label:6.4,id:UT23703-093-001-17697}}} Then the Lord, to teach that the training in emptiness is a bodhisattva’s training, says
“[they] should train in ‘form is a mere name,’… up to ‘buddhadharmas are a mere name’ ”—
all dharmas are simply mere names. 
{{milestone:{label:6.5,id:UT23703-093-001-17700}}}“Lord, when this—namely, the designation{{note:{index1934,id:UT23703-093-001-17701}}}form—is apprehended together with a basis,”
and so on, teaches the following. He asks: How could form and so on be just a name? The designation of “form,” “feeling,” and so on does not indicate simply a mere name, it indicates a basis, because the name is first given and then the aspect of the basis presents itself to the mind. He means: Were that name to be without a basis, {{page:{number:562,id:UT23703-093-001-22229,folio:F.282.a}}} either it would be illogical to say “a mere name,” or else, if it is taken to exist as form and so on that is not a basis, as a name, based on what and on account of what basis would that name be referring to something? That word would not exist either. Therefore, it is illogical to say “mere name.” 
{{milestone:{label:6.6,id:UT23703-093-001-17703}}}“This—namely, form—is a name plucked out of thin air… for this or that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon.”
The Lord is saying that form and so on is not a nominal entity.{{note:{index1935,id:UT23703-093-001-17705}}} If it were a nominal entity, then it would be feasible that by merely saying it even those who do not know what it is connected to would know what those bases are, as entities with their various specific attributes. But they do not know those, so words are one thing and the bases, form and so on, are something else. He means it is simply conventionally suitable that later on there are those words “for this or that basis.” Therefore, form and so on is not in its intrinsic nature a name. “Plucked out of thin air” means comes about later, in the sense of “fabricated.” As for a “basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon,” it is “compounded” because it has arisen from cause and conditions; a “causal sign” because it appears to consciousness; and a “basis” because it is in the form of a basis. A place for an appearance as a compounded dharma is called a “basis.” 
{{milestone:{label:6.7,id:UT23703-093-001-17706}}} Having said that, the noble Maitreya, unable to bear the thought of a word plucked out of thin air, asks,
“Lord, is it not the case that in the absence of the name form, there is no being aware of, realizing, or knowing the name form through a basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon?”
and so on. Without the name, from seeing simply the mere basis, you do not become aware “this is form”;{{note:{index1936,id:UT23703-093-001-17709}}} and without seeing the basis, just from the word being said you do not become aware of the basis. He means: There, logically, if the name for form were to come about later and is not its entity,{{note:{index1937,id:UT23703-093-001-17710}}}{{page:{number:563,id:UT23703-093-001-22230,folio:F.282.b}}} even without the name being said those who do not know what the name is connected to will comprehend “it is form.” And even after the name has been said, since the word would be plucked out of thin air the awareness that arises would not be of the actual reality of the basis. Either way it is one of these two,{{note:{index1938,id:UT23703-093-001-17711}}} so form and so on is not in its intrinsic nature a name. 
{{milestone:{label:6.8,id:UT23703-093-001-17712}}} In regard to “in the absence of the name… through that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon:” construe “in the absence” as when the word is set aside; “through that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon” it is not tenable that there is awareness that that basis “is form.”
{{milestone:{label:6.9,id:UT23703-093-001-17713}}} With,
 “So then, Maitreya, I will ask you a question,”
and so on, the Lord teaches in three parts that names are plucked out of thin air and that bases are not in their intrinsic nature names.
{{milestone:{label:6.10,id:UT23703-093-001-17716}}} He makes it known that names are plucked out of thin air in three parts: because you do not know what something is from just the basis without the name being said; because there are many names for a single basis; and because there is one name for many bases. 
{{milestone:{label:6.11,id:UT23703-093-001-17717}}} There, in reference to the first part, it says
“Maitreya, what do you think—without resorting to, without standing on, without having to stand on the designation form for this or that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon, do you think this—namely, ‘this is form’—about this or that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon?”
and so on. If that form is taken to be a nominal entity, why do those who are ignorant of the term, who do not know that the word form stands for the form that is the basis, not have the realization in words that “this is form” by seeing just that basis? If that name is taken to be that entity that is a basis, just as a consciousness that grasps the specific defining marks of the basis arises from properly seeing the basis, similarly it would make sense that a consciousness that knows the name would arise as well. But it does not arise, so form and so on is not the nominal entity.
{{milestone:{label:6.12,id:UT23703-093-001-17720}}} In reference to the second part it says,
“Maitreya, what do you think, do a variety of kinds of words, conventional terms, conventional labels, and designations {{page:{number:564,id:UT23703-093-001-22231,folio:F.283.a}}} designate, or conventionally refer to, or label, or apply to this basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon?”
and so on. Let a basis be taken to be a nominal entity. There are many names for a single basis; for example, just the one feeling is called feeling, experience, state of awareness, pleasure, suffering, and equanimity. There, if that basis is taken to be a nominal entity, whereas it would make sense that when the single basis, feeling, is spoken about with many names it would become many entities,{{note:{index1939,id:UT23703-093-001-17723}}} that is not the case. Therefore, you should know that form and so on is not a name entity.
{{milestone:{label:6.13,id:UT23703-093-001-17724}}} In reference to the third part it says,
“Maitreya, what do you think—here, does someone designate… to just that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon a name for a basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon different from it?”
and so on. Were that basis taken to be the nominal entity, then when a name for many bases has been said, like, for example, “aggregates, sense fields, and constituents,” then all the dharmas would become a single entity.{{note:{index1940,id:UT23703-093-001-17727}}} But that is not the case. Therefore, you should know that form and so on is not a nominal entity. 
{{milestone:{label:6.14,id:UT23703-093-001-17728}}} What is being taught with,
Having said that, the noble Maitreya asked him, “In that case, Lord, would it not then be just that basis that is the causal sign of a compounded phenomenon that is apprehended as the form entity?”{{note:{index1941,id:UT23703-093-001-17730}}}
This is teaching: The Lord has taught that the word labeled onto a basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon is together with a basis and together with a foundation; he has not taught that it is without a basis and without a foundation. Therefore, because it{{note:{index1942,id:UT23703-093-001-17732}}} is grounded in the basis that is causal sign of a compounded phenomenon, it seems that the entity that is the basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon is the word. 
{{milestone:{label:6.15,id:UT23703-093-001-17733}}} Then the Lord, with
“Maitreya, what do you think, … the form entity, or is it simply merely designated?”{{note:{index1943,id:UT23703-093-001-17735}}}{{page:{number:565,id:UT23703-093-001-22232,folio:F.283.b}}}
sorts out Maitreya’s statement, teaching: Are you saying that those who use the word form for that basis are giving voice to the entity that is its defining mark, or are they just saying a word? He{{note:{index1944,id:UT23703-093-001-17737}}} thus says that they are saying a word. Therefore, it is apparent that those words are giving voice to the name of that basis, not the entity, like, for example, in common parlance the child’s name Devadatta (“God-given”) and so on. Therefore, it is teaching that form and so on is not the name entity.{{note:{index1945,id:UT23703-093-001-17738}}}
{{milestone:{label:6.16,id:UT23703-093-001-17739}}}Having said that, the noble Maitreya asked him, “Lord, … if form is simply just a designation, name, conventional term, label, and conventional designation,” 
and so on, is saying that it is the entities of form and so on that are bases that are apprehended. It is saying: given that the Lord has said “form is a mere name,” and “feeling is a mere name” too, in that case the name form becomes the form entity and the name feeling becomes the feeling entity.
{{milestone:{label:6.17,id:UT23703-093-001-17741}}} In order to sort that out as well,
Having asked that, the Lord asked him in return, “Maitreya, what do you think, is that form that is simply just a designation, name, conventional term, label, and conventional designation produced or stopped, or defiled or purified?”
and so on. It is understood in the world that form and so on are subject to production and stopping and are subject to defilement and purification. If the dharmas, form and so on, were taken to be name entities, there would then be no production or stopping, or defilement or purification over and above that of the name,{{note:{index1946,id:UT23703-093-001-17744}}} but such does occur. Therefore, you should know that a name is not the intrinsic nature of the dharmas. 
{{milestone:{label:6.18,id:UT23703-093-001-17745}}}“Lord, does form just not exist at all? Is it without any mark at all?” {{page:{number:566,id:UT23703-093-001-22233,folio:F.284.a}}}
and so on. The bodhisattva is asking: What about what you have said before, Lord, that “form is a mere name,” and “feeling is a mere name?” By saying that, do you intend that a mark of form and so on does not exist in any way at all, or that form just does not exist at all?
{{milestone:{label:6.19,id:UT23703-093-001-17747}}} Having said that, the Lord, concerned about it being taken nihilistically, refutes it with,
“Maitreya, I do not say ‘form just does not exist at all without any mark at all.’ ”
{{milestone:{label:6.20,id:UT23703-093-001-17749}}} Then the bodhisattva asks about its mode of existence with, 
“How then, Lord, does form exist?”
and so on. 
{{milestone:{label:6.21,id:UT23703-093-001-17752}}} With,
“Maitreya, form exists as an ordinary term and convention,”
and so on, the Lord differentiates and teaches that it exists from the perspective of the conventional truth but does not exist from the perspective of the ultimate truth. 
{{milestone:{label:6.22,id:UT23703-093-001-17755}}} Then the noble Maitreya says, 
“Lord, the way I understand what you have said,”{{note:{index1947,id:UT23703-093-001-17757}}}
and so on. He is saying: If you are saying that ultimately form and so on do not exist at all, in that case, you have gone to the extreme of the nihilists and so on. There the Lord’s intention in saying “ultimately it does not exist” is this: a basis{{note:{index1948,id:UT23703-093-001-17759}}} that can be designated by a name form and so on ultimately does not exist; a basis that cannot be named, that is
“inexpressible,”
has an ultimate existence. Having said that he asks, 
{{milestone:{label:6.23,id:UT23703-093-001-17762}}}“Lord, if that inexpressible element ultimately exists, then how can it be a basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon designated by the name form plucked out of thin air?”
and so on. If the ultimate element is inexpressible by the entity that is the name and word for form and so on, {{page:{number:567,id:UT23703-093-001-22234,folio:F.284.b}}} how could that basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon designated by the name ever have any sort of existence or nonexistence? Having asked that, Maitreya also asks,
“And if ultimately it does not exist, then how could it be an inexpressible element?”
{{milestone:{label:6.24,id:UT23703-093-001-17765}}}What does this teach? It is teaching that he has asserted that very basis that is the causal sign of a compounded phenomenon is its base because there is nothing else serving as a base of the inexpressible ultimate element. If that basis that is the causal sign of a compounded phenomenon ultimately does not exist, it does not make sense to say that “the inexpressible element is based on the basis that is the causal sign of a compounded phenomenon.” He is saying that you cannot call the basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon the “inexpressible element.”
{{milestone:{label:6.25,id:UT23703-093-001-17766}}} Then the Lord, wanting to teach the way in which the basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon does not exist, and how, even though it does not exist, it serves as the foundation,{{note:{index1949,id:UT23703-093-001-17767}}} with,
“So then, Maitreya, I will ask you a question,”
and so on, asks him about just that. With,
“Maitreya, what do you think—when abiding in the correct practice of wisdom connected with the inexpressible element,”{{note:{index1950,id:UT23703-093-001-17771}}}
and so on, he goes on to say: “Maitreya, when you take up the thoroughly purified wisdom, the inexpressible element,{{note:{index1951,id:UT23703-093-001-17773}}} at that point does the basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon appear or does it not appear?” And the bodhisattva says,
“Lord, I do not apprehend it.”
He means it does not appear.
{{milestone:{label:6.26,id:UT23703-093-001-17776}}}Then the Lord said, “From this one of many explanations, Maitreya”— 
what does this teach? It says: “Understand that since the basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon does not appear when you are cultivating attention to the ultimate, it does not exist ultimately, but it exists as a convention.” That conventional reality, furthermore, cannot ultimately be expressed as just that or as other. Therefore, it says,
{{milestone:{label:6.27,id:UT23703-093-001-17778}}}“You should know that {{page:{number:568,id:UT23703-093-001-22235,folio:F.285.a}}} this basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon is not the inexpressible element, and the inexpressible element is not other than this basis that is a causal sign of a compounded phenomenon.”
